In-Reply-To: <20030101054432.43925.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>

On Tue, 31 Dec 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:
> KDE can be made to look almost exactly like Windoze. Do you suppose
> this would make Linux look less threatening to those who were
> considering a transition?

This is just a personal comment and really has nothing to do with the
thread of screenshots for whatever Cooper's purposes might be.

I think that KDE's (or any other window/session manager's) similarity to
Windows is a Bad Thing <TM>.

The similar look and feel leads a user to do things "The Windows
Way" rather than "The Unix Way" and, thus, negate much, if not all, of the
benefit of using a unix-like operating system.

I'll admit that getting people off of proprietary software and into Free
Software use is a Good Thing <TM>, but if a person is going to make a
change, perhaps they should be encouraged to get as much long-term benefit
out of the change as possible.

For those that insist that Windows is "easier" or that familiarity is
appealling to the average user, I have only anecdotal evidence to the
contrary.  My most recent personal convert is a young woman of 21 with
almost no college education and very little computer experience outside
basic word processing for school and operating retail POS terminals.  
She's taken to The Unix Way like a duck to water.  She uses Eterm more
often than any other application in X (in number of instances... xmms is
running all the time) and things grep is the coolest thing ever invented
(I've only just introduced her to sed, but I think the learning curve is
going to take a while to climb).  Again, this is only my most recent
conversion experience and it is not unique.

I find that when moving someone from Windows instead of promising that
things will be very much LIKE what they have used in the past, better
success is achieved (and a more well-rounded user/home administrator
developed) by focussing on how DIFFERENT things are on this side of the
fence.

Just my thoughts.
J.

Jeme,

Sometimes you are hard to take, but this time I must agree with you. 
There are some good things in Windows Applications that we should
imitate or at least make a similar functionality.  But the reason to
move to any software should be that it is a better solution overall.  I
find open source software to be more reliable, less crashy (if this is a
word), and when and if the owner of the software makes it unavailable
any more for any reason (remember Bill's threat to take Windows off the
market?), the software is still usable and maintainable. 

Ken
www.cad2cam.com
www.cadtocam.com

Are you thinking of Computer and Software Factory Outlet? I've gotten a
few things from them in the past. But lately, I haven't found any
bargains in there. The best bargain I came up with from them was a low
price for a copy of Corel CAD a few years ago at their store in Hazel
Dell (I think that was where it was). Corel had already sold their
interest in it to another CAD company so I was able to talk them down
from $250 to closer to $100 (don't remember just how close).

I asked them about getting a laptop hard drive once. They gave me a
price over the phone, but when I called again about ordering it, I got
something of a run around. I ended up getting one from ENU just up the
street.

One unlikely place I've found batteries via their battery finder on 
their website is Radio Shack. Does this look like the sort of battery 
you need for your BackUPS 650?

http://www.radioshack.com/product.asp?catalog%5Fname=CTLG&category%5Fname=CTLG%5F004%5F000%5F000%5F000&product%5Fid=960%2D0462

I have several 650s that I'll eventually need to replace the batteries 
in within the next year or so. If I only need one of these batteries 
per unit the batteries are cheaper than a brand new unit.

Tony

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Thu Jan  2 11:04:03 2003
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Thu Jan  2 11:04:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Software Upgrade
Message-ID: <20030102190352.33647.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>

I have been using Caldera OpenLinux 3.1 for about a
year and a half. At the time I installed it, I did not
realize that apparently there would be no more
releases, and now it is gradually becoming obsolete.

I was hoping to use KWord to typeset foreign
characters. After reading that KWord likes Truetype
fonts, I installed a Truetype server on my system, and
KWord recognizes such fonts. With earlier versions of
Qt, however, it will not print such text correctly. It
is possible to save KWord files as plain text and use
a utility such as Enscript to print them, but this is
"below the user's expectations." Modern versions of Qt
do not have this limitation.

Installation of Qt 3.x from source is apparently not
much of a problem, but I may want to try to install
KDE 3.x as well. KDE 3.x requires automake > 1.5 and
autoconf > 2.5.

The original installation of my system was from
.rpm's, but .rpm's for current versions of automake
and autoconf involve so many dependencies that I hoped
to install these packages from source. Compilation of
autoconf was apparently successful, but when I then
attempted to install automake, I was warned that my
autoconf version was 2.13. Why?

Midnight Commander finds autoconf in the following
places:

/usr/bin               5000        Dec 13 2001
/etc                     80        May 13 2002
/usr/local/bin         7681        Jan  1 2003
/usr/share              464        May 13 2002
home/download/Autoconf-2.57/bin  7681 Jan 1 2003 

>From this I suspect that the 2.13 binary was in
/usr/bin, and a successful compile placed 2.57 in
/usr/local/bin. Perhaps what I should do is to copy
the binary in /usr/local/bin to /usr/bin, overwriting
the binary now there. Any suggestions?

http://analytic.tripod.com/

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jan  2 15:06:03 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jan  2 15:06:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic shutdown from a UPS
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301021456070.2037-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  My battery problem reminded me of another issue I haven't yet resolved:
sufficent serial ports for everything.

  One of the reasons I bought the BackUPS-Pro was its ability to shut down
the network if the power goes out and no one's here. But, it needs a
dedicated serial port for that and I don't have one on the server. On this
box, /dev/ttyS0 goes to a switch on the desktop that is the conduit for the
PDA, the digital camera and the GPS field computer (the latter two are
swapped on the empty port while the PDA is always plugged into the other
port). /dev/ttyS1 is the pointy device. Those are the only two serial ports
on the box.

  What do most folks do in a situation like this?

  Since the software is _supposed_ to shut down the entire network, I wonder
if I'd be better off putting this UPS on the other workstation and
installing the software on that. But, we have a pda and trackball on that
box, too. However, it would be easier to add a board with a third port
(/dev/ttyS2) on that box.

  Is that the way to go?

Thanks,

Rich

download only new packages and/or packages I don't already have in my
RPM directory?

From guy1656 at ados.com  Thu Jan  2 15:20:05 2003
From: guy1656 at ados.com (guy1656)
Date: Thu Jan  2 15:20:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The 'Unix Way' vs. 'Some Other Ways.'
In-Reply-To: <1041451188.1862.23.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301010743210.21808-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> <1041451188.1862.23.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
Message-ID: <20030102230650.D95DE350B9@ados.com>

: > I think that KDE's (or any other window/session manager's) similarity to
: > Windows is a Bad Thing <TM>.
: >
: > The similar look and feel leads a user to do things "The Windows
: > Way" rather than "The Unix Way" and, thus, negate much, if not all, of
: > the benefit of using a unix-like operating system.

Most users don't really want to 'use' a computer anyway - they want to 'use' 
e-mail, a word processor, a spreadsheet program, a solid modeller, an image 
editor, etc.

Keeping this in mind as a designer is sometimes counter-intuitive. I am a 
mechanical engineer, and for me, I have to remember that very few people who 
buy a cordless drill actually want to own one. What they actually want is a 
hole somewhere.

Similarly, what would happen if, when deciding to switch telephone companies, 
you had to remember to stop using your phone 'the AT&T Way' and learn all 
about 'the Sprint Way,' (insert any phone company you wish, I just picked two 
for examples.)

Now this would be lovely if the Open Source Communication device was an 
opportunity for folks to get rid of a certain evil telephony provider that 
had a habit of tapping peoples conversations 'because you agreed to let us do 
so in your service agreement with us...'

-GLL

> 
> The problem I'm stuck at: what would be the best way to automatically
> download only new packages and/or packages I don't already have in my
> RPM directory?

Couple of ideas:

1) use up2date from Red Hat.  I think it's $60/machine/year.

2) Use a copy of Paul Heinlein's rsync script (see PLUG archives) to
download the RPMs from a mirror and then look at freshmeat to find a
copy of Current (http://www.biology.duke.edu/computer/unix/current/),
which allows you to set up your own up2date server for your private
network.

Good luck,
Colin

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jan  2 15:56:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jan  2 15:56:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] The 'Unix Way' vs. 'Some Other Ways.'
In-Reply-To: <20030102230650.D95DE350B9@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301021535350.12889-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 2 Jan 2003, guy1656 wrote:
> : > I think that KDE's (or any other window/session manager's) similarity to
> : > Windows is a Bad Thing <TM>.
> : >
> : > The similar look and feel leads a user to do things "The Windows
> : > Way" rather than "The Unix Way" and, thus, negate much, if not all, of
> : > the benefit of using a unix-like operating system.
> 
> Most users don't really want to 'use' a computer anyway - they want to
> 'use' e-mail, a word processor, a spreadsheet program, a solid
> modeller, an image editor, etc.

I don't entirely agree there.  Look at people who use their computers to
do things that are done just as easily or more easily without a
computer.  Those people just want to use a computer.

I do agree that some people just want to use a spreadsheet program.  They
clearly don't want to store their data in a flexible and useful data
format with widely available tools for manipulation and maintenance...
they just wanna use a spreadsheet program.  Eighty percent of the Excel
documents that ever crossed my pc had no spreadsheet functionality
whatsoever.

I'm just bitching, though.

> Keeping this in mind as a designer is sometimes counter-intuitive. I
> am a mechanical engineer, and for me, I have to remember that very few
> people who buy a cordless drill actually want to own one. What they
> actually want is a hole somewhere.

This above part is quite true, but I don't believe it has the consequences
you believe it does.  I think of this as the primary motivator to
distinguish between products of value and products of service.  People
want food and jewelry and stuff like that.  (Most) People don't want
televisions, power drills, and stuff like that (they want television,
holes, and so on).  I think that's an interesting concept and something
that designers, manufacturers and consumers should all consider, but I
don't think it has much to do with the way people use computers and really
is more of a plug-talk kind of discussion.

> Similarly, what would happen if, when deciding to switch telephone
> companies, you had to remember to stop using your phone 'the AT&T Way'
> and learn all about 'the Sprint Way,' (insert any phone company you
> wish, I just picked two for examples.)

I'm not writing about doing things "The Windows Way" versus "The XFree
Way".  If I were, your analogy would be fairly sound and I would
understand your argument.  This isn't about the cosmetic or even
procedural differences between getting things done in one system versus
another.  This is about understanding the nature of the data and what is
required of the data for different applications.

The Unix Way involves data stored in the most generic form possible and
many small, specialized utilities to take that data, manipulate it to
reflect the desired information to be presented, and create a presentable
document.  There is a separation between data entry, storage, and
presentation that is totally ignored when doing things "The Windows Way".  
(Take Microsoft Word, for example.  The data is entered in a way that is
meant to closely reflect the one and only way in which it is conveniently
presented and the format of the stored data is just another reflection of
that one presentation method.  There are more advanced features, but that
is the basic mode of operation.)

I think doing things (and teaching people to do things) in The Unix Way
makes more apparent the infinite possibilities of the information with
which one interacts.  The reason for using a computer (versus a typewriter
or a sketchbook) ceases to simply be a matter of convenience and
time-saving and becomes a matter of new possibilities that do not exist in
the paper/stone/glass/whatever world.

> Now this would be lovely if the Open Source Communication device was
> an opportunity for folks to get rid of a certain evil telephony
> provider that had a habit of tapping peoples conversations 'because
> you agreed to let us do so in your service agreement with us...'

Well, "Open Source" doesn't really protect you from service agreements and
the like.  I think you meant to write "Free as in Freedom".  You've got to
consider successive generational iterations.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

Scott VanHoosen wrote:
> We have a few Red Hat servers at work, and I'd like to automate their
> updates, but I have one link in the chain that I'm stuck at.
> 
> I'd like to have one server automatically download any new RPMs from
> somewhere, probably an ftp server, dump them into a directory along
> with all my other RPMs, then do an "rpm -f *.rpm" to freshen any
> packages on the system. I'll probably share the directory using NFS so
> the other Red Hat servers can update too.
> 
> The problem I'm stuck at: what would be the best way to automatically
> download only new packages and/or packages I don't already have in my
> RPM directory?

Surprised that no one has mentioned this yet:

apt-rpm
http://apt-rpm.tuxfamily.org/

and cron "apt-get update". I'd do the "apt-get upgrade"s by hand, to 
avoid an automatic upgrade borking something important.

Dunno if apt-proxy could be made to work w/ apt-rpm in order to prevent 
multiple downloads. I'd just mirror the apt repository on your ftp 
server and put it the sources.list for the servers to be upgraded. You 
get your "download once, install many" setup that way too.

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District




From russj at dimstar.net  Thu Jan  2 17:43:03 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Thu Jan  2 17:43:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automating updates
In-Reply-To: <20030102231321.60209.qmail@web10408.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030102231321.60209.qmail@web10408.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <3E14EA7E.5020103@dimstar.net>

Scott VanHoosen wrote:

>The problem I'm stuck at: what would be the best way to automatically
>download only new packages and/or packages I don't already have in my
>RPM directory?
>
I use the perl script mirror. It keeps the directory up to date, 
downloading new, and removing obsolete (as in, they don't exist on the 
mirror any longer) files.

For the updates, I DON'T recommend doing an rpm freshen with a directory 
of files. I've had rpm get confused and not know what to do.

What I do here is use the fine autorpm script from Kirk Bauer. It can 
use your repository to update the installed RPMs, and follows 
dependancies if any come up.

mirror is available here:  http://sunsite.doc.ic.ac.uk/packages/mirror/

autorpm is available here:  http://www.autorpm.org/

Kirk is also the author of the wonderful logwatch script, available 
here:  http://www.logwatch.org/

I use logwatch extensively as well.

comm refers to your serial communications port...

Of which you have two 

comm 1&3 are the same
comm 2&4 are the same

do a cat on /proc/ioports  and you should get something like
this :::  

0000-001f : dma1
0020-003f : pic1
0040-005f : timer
0060-006f : keyboard
0070-007f : rtc
0080-008f : dma page reg
00a0-00bf : pic2
00c0-00df : dma2
00f0-00ff : fpu
01f0-01f7 : ide0
02f8-02ff : serial(set)
0378-037a : parport0
037b-037f : parport0
03c0-03df : vga+
03f6-03f6 : ide0
03f8-03ff : serial(set)
0cf8-0cff : PCI conf1
4000-40ff : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
5000-500f : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
6000-607f : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
c000-c00f : VIA Technologies, Inc. Bus Master IDE
  c000-c007 : ide0
  c008-c00f : ide1
:


Notice address 03f8 - 03ff   an eight bit port..

Comm 1  or comm 3

 now cat interrupts 
           CPU0       
  0:    1007032          XT-PIC  timer
  1:       6061          XT-PIC  keyboard
  2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
  4:    1531380          XT-PIC  serial
  8:          3          XT-PIC  rtc
  9:          0          XT-PIC  es1371
 10:         91          XT-PIC  usb-uhci, usb-uhci
 11:      48888          XT-PIC  ide2, ide3
 12:     273792          XT-PIC  PS/2 Mouse
 14:         11          XT-PIC  ide0
NMI:          0 

You will notice irq4 is serial or comm1

Which is ttyS0 in linux

HTH


Marvin







From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Thu Jan  2 17:53:03 2003
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Thu Jan  2 17:53:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to set base I/O on old modem?

Message-ID: <3E14ECE7.4050008@anarchysoftware.com>

Tyler F. Creelan wrote:

> There is also a table of this form, it is not situated near the jumpers:
> 
> COM	IRQ	ON
> 1	4	1,2,5
> 2	3	2,4
> 3	4	1,5
> 3	5	1,6
> 4	3	4
> 4	2	3

Here's a handy little chart to help you figure out base I/O ports from 
the standard DOS COM designations:

DOS name Linux name IRQ IO Address
COM1:  ttyS0  4  0x3F8
COM2:  ttyS1  3  0x2F8
COM3:  ttyS2  4  0x3E8
COM4:  ttyS3  3  0x2E8

COM3: (ttyS2) on IRQ 5 is nonstandard, so I wouldn't jumper it that way, 
as is COM4: (ttyS3) on IRQ 2.

Correction:  

Usually comm1 & comm3  use irq4
 
and

comm 2 & comm4 use irq3

And yes   comm1 and comm3 have different addresses.

There are only 2 UART's on the motherboard  -- or one
if you have a cheap motherboard...


So if you really need two comm ports.
The usual configuration is one even and one odd..

You can usually -- manually -- change the address in BIOS.

HTH

Marvin

> 0378-037a : parport0
> 037b-037f : parport0
> 03c0-03df : vga+
> 03f6-03f6 : ide0
> 03f8-03ff : serial(set)
> 0cf8-0cff : PCI conf1
> 4000-40ff : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
> 5000-500f : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
> 6000-607f : VIA Technologies, Inc. VT82C686 [Apollo Super ACPI]
> c000-c00f : VIA Technologies, Inc. Bus Master IDE
>   c000-c007 : ide0
>   c008-c00f : ide1
> :
> 
> 
> Notice address 03f8 - 03ff   an eight bit port..
> 
> Comm 1  or comm 3
> 
>  now cat interrupts 
>            CPU0       
>   0:    1007032          XT-PIC  timer
>   1:       6061          XT-PIC  keyboard
>   2:          0          XT-PIC  cascade
>   4:    1531380          XT-PIC  serial
>   8:          3          XT-PIC  rtc
>   9:          0          XT-PIC  es1371
>  10:         91          XT-PIC  usb-uhci, usb-uhci
>  11:      48888          XT-PIC  ide2, ide3
>  12:     273792          XT-PIC  PS/2 Mouse
>  14:         11          XT-PIC  ide0
> NMI:          0 
> 
> You will notice irq4 is serial or comm1
> 
> Which is ttyS0 in linux
> 
> HTH
> 
> 
> Marvin
>

On Thu, 2 Jan 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:
> From this I suspect that the 2.13 binary was in
> /usr/bin, and a successful compile placed 2.57 in
> /usr/local/bin. Perhaps what I should do is to copy
> the binary in /usr/local/bin to /usr/bin, overwriting
> the binary now there. Any suggestions?

Don't overwrite the binary, rename it and symlink in the new binary:

> mv /usr/bin/autoconf /usr/bin/autoconf2.13

> ln -s /usr/local/bin/autoconf /usr/local/bin/autoconf

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jan  2 20:34:03 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Jan  2 20:34:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic shutdown from a UPS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301021456070.2037-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301021456070.2037-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200301022032.41392.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think just adding another serial board is the way to go here. I've 
been using APC's PowerChute software for Linux on my SmartUPS 700 for 
nearly two years and it works quite well. The only negative was that 
the install procedure was very RedHat oriented and so some of my files 
on my system which runs SuSE Linux were mangled a bit. I had to fix a 
few things by hand.

PowerChute works quite nicely and cleanly shuts down my system when the 
power goes out for too long of a duration. I also have several other 
Linux system connected to dumb APC BackUPS 650 units for which I made 
my own signaling cables for a few dollars in parts from a second hand 
electronics store. 

I have my own hacked monitoring daemon which started life as the 
"backupsd" code which I took from the Linux UPS-HOWTO document. There 
were certain problems/shortcomings with the original daemon code and so 
I have my own "extended" version which corrects the problems I 
encountered with the original daemon. This setup has served me very 
well for nearly 4 years now. 

Tony

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jan  2 21:32:03 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Jan  2 21:32:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic shutdown from a UPS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301022037540.2504-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301022037540.2504-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200301022130.53639.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I hope you can find your cable as APC charges what I think are "highway 
robbery" prices for their cables. I'm happy that APC seems to include 
the cable with their UPS's now so there hopefully isn't any extra cost 
involved anymore. My older BackUPS 600 and 650 units didn't include any 
signaling cables. 

IIRC the cable for the "smart" type UPS is more complicated compared to 
what's involved with the basic signaling cable which simply allows the 
UPS to signal when the power goes out and when the power is restored to 
the unit. The "smart" cable is used for communication between the UPS 
and host system with a variety of graphical and textual information 
being displayed in the PowerChute client.

The PowerChute "_upsd" server is a networked daemon and so it opens a 
port and listens on it so be careful if you plan to use PowerChute on a 
firewall system or any other system that is exposed to an open network. 
I don't know if there are any remote exploits or anything with it but 
you never can be too careful these days.

Tony

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu Jan  2 22:40:05 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu Jan  2 22:40:05 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to set base I/O on old modem? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 02 Jan 2003 17:52:39 PST."
             <3E14ECE7.4050008@anarchysoftware.com> 
Message-ID: <200301030639.h036dIo11270@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

> > There is also a table of this form, it is not situated near the jumpers:
> > 
> > COM	IRQ	ON
> > 1	4	1,2,5
> > 2	3	2,4
> > 3	4	1,5
> > 3	5	1,6
> > 4	3	4
> > 4	2	3
> 
> Here's a handy little chart to help you figure out base I/O ports from 
> the standard DOS COM designations:
> 
> DOS name Linux name IRQ IO Address
> COM1:  ttyS0  4  0x3F8
> COM2:  ttyS1  3  0x2F8
> COM3:  ttyS2  4  0x3E8
> COM4:  ttyS3  3  0x2E8
> 
> COM3: (ttyS2) on IRQ 5 is nonstandard, so I wouldn't jumper it that way, 
> as is COM4: (ttyS3) on IRQ 2.
> 

But if you don't use IRQ 2 or 5, you will be sharing interrupts on an ISA
bus.  In general, this is a bad thing.  Be prepared for character loss if
the two serial ports that are sharing are active simultaneously.

galen

From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Fri Jan  3 07:43:03 2003
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Fri Jan  3 07:43:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] How to set base I/O on old modem?
References: <200301030639.h036dIo11270@tinman.seitzassoc.com>
Message-ID: <3E15AF71.2050709@anarchysoftware.com>

Galen Seitz wrote:

>>DOS name Linux name IRQ IO Address
>>COM1:  ttyS0  4  0x3F8
>>COM2:  ttyS1  3  0x2F8
>>COM3:  ttyS2  4  0x3E8
>>COM4:  ttyS3  3  0x2E8
>>
>>COM3: (ttyS2) on IRQ 5 is nonstandard, so I wouldn't jumper it that way, 
>>as is COM4: (ttyS3) on IRQ 2.
>>
> 
> 
> But if you don't use IRQ 2 or 5, you will be sharing interrupts on an ISA
> bus.  In general, this is a bad thing.  Be prepared for character loss if
> the two serial ports that are sharing are active simultaneously.

Absolutely. I was assuming the need for no more than two serial devices.

What we do at FREE GEEK with most modems is to disable all serial 
devices in BIOS (temporarily), and then boot from Tomsrtbt (or any 
version of linux with serial support). Then:

$ dmesg | grep ttyS

...shows the serial port the modem is configured to use. Then we use 
something like the above chart to determine which serial port does not 
conflict with the modem and therefore can be re-enabled in BIOS.

For most people this is extremely counterintuitive. (Why am I disabling 
something I want to use? Answer: You're not using it. It's actually in 
the way of the modem.)

Marvin,

Cramfs is basically a compressed RAM disk (zlib compressed IIRC).  My iPaq
used it before JFFS2 was stable enough. If you're using a Debian kernel
image I seem to recall they're using cramfs now to compress the initrd,
though I could be incorrect.

- Geoff

From gherteg at herteg.net  Fri Jan  3 14:46:03 2003
From: gherteg at herteg.net (Geoffrey Herteg)
Date: Fri Jan  3 14:46:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] cramfs
In-Reply-To: <20030103223114.GA13861@newcastle.devrandom.net>
References: <1041632182.592.26.camel@libranet> <20030103223114.GA13861@newcastle.devrandom.net>
Message-ID: <20030103224501.GB13861@newcastle.devrandom.net>

Well, once again I was referencing faulty memory (I need to fsck my brain
again sometime).

According to Handhelds.Org:

    Working With Cramfs
    Accessing cramfs is similar to ext2 ramdisk, except that cramfs
    is a readonly filesystem. It's new to 2.4.x so most 2.2.x-based
    development machines do not support it. Since cramfs is readonly,
    you cannot 'mkfs -t cramfs' and then populate. The mkcramfs utility
    creates an image of a cramfs filesystem from a directory tree.

    On a Linux 2.4.x Desktop Computer 
    bash# mkdir mntpoint 
    bash# mkdir temp 
    bash# mount -t cramfs init-2-40.cramfs mntpoint -o loop 
    bash# cp -a mntpoint temp 
    (do what you need to do) 
    bash# cd .. 
    bash# mkcramfs temp init-2-41.cramfs

So Marvin, I'm hoping you're using a 2.4 Kernel w/ cramfs support built in
(if using a cramfs initrd) or a module (if you're trying to access it
somewhere after mounting / or /lib/modules amd modprobing)...

- Geoff

On Sat, 2003-01-04 at 19:47, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> For some testing, I flushed my ipchains file but backed up the output of
> ipchains --list to a text file.  Is there a quick way to restore my
> ipchains file using this backup?

> Robbert van Andel

> Oregon Swimming, Inc.

Look at ipchains-save and ipchains-restore.  You may have to edit the
listing and place /usr/sbin/ipchains (or whereever you have ipchains
installed) in front of it.  The rules are stated slightly different when
defined from when they are listed.

Subject: [PLUG] Compiling KDE from source
Message-ID: <20030105054427.12943.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>

I am presently undertaking the compilation of KDE from
source code, partly because I think the experience
gained might be valuable. I am attempting to install
3.0.5 on a system that now has an older version. I
have already compiled Qt with the appropriate options,
and have downloaded the KDE source files for 3.0.5.

There is only one regular user on my computer
("normal?") Under these circumstances, the path can be
set in the user account by adding lines to .bashrc in
this manner:

QTDIR=/usr/local/qt
KDEDIR=/usr/local/kde
KDEHOME=/home/example/.kde
PATH=$PATH:$QTDIR/bin:$KDEDIR/bin
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$QTDIR/lib:$KDEDIR/lib
export QTDIR KDEDIR PATH LD_LIBRARY_PATH 

The instructions on KDE's site imply that this file is
to be made active BEFORE compilation of the new KDE
source files. Although it is not explicit about
another point, it seems that one would have to be in
console mode to do these operations, since the present
version of KDE would no longer be in the path. 

Is that right? Should I boot at runlevel 3 to compile
the KDE source files?

References: <20030105054427.12943.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030104234629.A15862@mentorg.com>

Hi Robert,

I have compiled KDE several times in the last few months, and each time I
followed the KDE website directions (including the variables) and the process
has worked fine for me without switching to runlevel 3 or going to console.  

In case you find it handy, here is how I test the build without leaving my
current login:

1.  Edit "/etc/kde/kdm/kdmrc" and add a new entry to the "SessionTypes" line;
    e.g. use "kde3.1rc5"

2.  Create a file in the "/usr/share/apps/switchdesk" directory named 
    "Xclients.kde3.1rc5"

3.  Put something like the following in that file:  

#!/bin/bash
export KDEDIR=/usr/local/KDE/3.1.0-rc5
export QTDIR=/usr/local/QT/qt-3.1.0
GCCDIR=/usr/local/gcc/gcc-3.2
FAMDIR=/usr/local/fam/fam-2.6.9
export PATH=$KDEDIR/bin:$QTDIR/bin:$PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$FAMDIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$GCCDIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$QTDIR/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
exec startkde

4.  Make that file executable

5.  Start a VNC server/client session, and run that file 
    (/usr/share/apps/switchdesk/Xclients.kde3.1rc5) and you
    should see a new KDE session with the VNC window

If it all works properly, you should also have the new "kde3.1rc5" entry in the
pulldown menu on the KDM login screen (if you're using it.)

Good luck,

Marc

From m at netpro.to  Sun Jan  5 17:11:02 2003
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Sun Jan  5 17:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] MS changes IE and IIS TCP/IP behavior?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0301051713280.19856-100000@lukem.com>

Interesting...  Microsoft is supposedly using TCP/IP in a way that makes
IE respond faster to IIS and slower to non-IIS webservers:

http://grotto11.com/blog/?+1039831658

Could someone with IE and IIS please verify this?  A dump of TCP/IP
traffic with different versions of IE and IIS would be ideal.

Of course covered on Slashdot:

http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=03/01/05/2025254

This post sums things up:

 The parent +5 post is flat out wrong. This is not about persistant
 connections, which is a high-level HTTP feature that keeps a connection
 open so that the browser can send more requests. This is about a
 low-level TCP hack that IE uses to get a small speed boost on IIS
 servers, while breaking TCP standards compliance.

 If I read the article correctly, instead of creating a new TCP connection
 and then sending a request, IE sends the request immediately without
 bothering to finish the TCP handshake. Microsoft IIS web servers deal
 with it automatically, and it is faster because it saves a round-trip
 wait for the ACK and the following requset.

 The down side is that non-IIS servers have no clue what this incoming
 packet is. It must be invalid because it is not a SYN. So it gets thrown
 away, and the server might or might not reset the connection. If a
 non-IIS server resets the connection, IE goes with a standard TCP
 handshake and has wasted only the round trip time for the request packet
 and the RST. But if the server swallows the invalid packet and does not
 send a RST, then Internet Explorer will just sit around for a few seconds
 until it times out and falls back to a standard TCP conection.

 The summary is that IE is breaking the TCP protocol for a small speed
 boost when connecting to IIS servers. It results in a small speed penalty
 when connecting to most non-IIS servers. When connecting to non-IIS
 servers that do not reset the connetion, it results in a very noticable
 delay.

 It could also be a potential security risk, because if this is true, then
 it makes it very easy to IP-spoof a HTTP request against IIS (since the
 request is a self-contained packet instead of a long connection
 sequence).

Sounds like the startx process (process id 3415) went into the background (as
job #1); were there any errors after this?  If not, it seems startx did start.
Does pressing Alt-F7 do anything?

> I set a path to this installation for a single user in
> .bashrc. One thing to check is whether "echo $PATH"
> will return any reference to the olde installation,
> and unfortunately it does.The path is set in .bashrc

Having the "old" programs in your path is not really a problem, as long as 
the one you want is the first in the path.  For example:

    % which konqueror
    konqueror is /usr/local/KDE/3.1.0-rc5/bin/konqueror
    konqueror is /usr/bin/konqueror

The "/usr/bin/konqueror" is from some old RPM that I still have installed, but 
I have not used that version of KDE for months.

> I really am embarrassed to ask this question: where does $PATH come from?

Looks like it comes from /etc/profile, with /etc/bashrc and /etc/profile.d/*.sh
contributing to shell startup.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Jan  5 23:20:02 2003
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Sun Jan  5 23:20:02 2003
Subject: cramfs initrd, make-kpkg, dpkg-www (Re: [PLUG] cramfs)
Message-ID: <1041837542.12734.6.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2003-01-03 at 14:16, Marvin J. Kosmal wrote: 
> I  get this message on boot.
> 
> cramfs: wrong magic
>
> What is cramfs??????

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/kernel-doc-2.4.18/

(ObArchive: the version number part will likely change in the future)

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/kernel-doc-2.4.18/Documentation/filesystems/cramfs.txt.gz


Debian kernel's have been patched (the patch is supposed to have been
submitted upstream, and may make it into the mainstream kernel at some
point) to support a cramfs initrd.  You are booting without an initrd,
and it prints that message on booting.  (Perhaps the patch should be
updated to have it suppress that confusing error message?)

The Debian "kernel-package"'s make-kpkg generated .deb's have a
postinstall script that calls on the "initrd-tools" to generate a
potentially customized initrd image on installation of the
"kernel-image".  RTFM:

https://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/dpkg?search=++Search++&query=kernel-package
https://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/dpkg?search=++Search++&query=initrd-tools

(I hope that we don't get "cracked" by somebody who digs around in there
and finds software versions with remote exploits...  I suppose that it
COULD happen, but that it probably won't, and that exposing this tool is
beneficial enough to the group to be worth that small risk.)

-- 
karlheg

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Jan  5 23:42:04 2003
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Sun Jan  5 23:42:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Automatic shutdown from a UPS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301021456070.2037-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301021456070.2037-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1041838905.12734.17.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

I'm using "apcupsd" on two machines with two UPS's.  One has a serial
connection, the other a USB connection.  It works very well.  "apcupsd"
can operate in a networked mode, as a slave, when you have more than one
machine plugged into the UPS.  The master signals the slave over the
network.  You could just as easily use a PLIP or firewire connection as
an ethernet, I suppose.

The problem I have with the USB version is that the HID device sometimes
moves out from under it.  It's trying for hid0, and that works, but
after it restarts, the silly device has moved to hid1.  It's some sort
of devfs bug.  I've seen the same thing happen with v4l devices too, so
it's not the HID code, afaict.

At least with the versions of apcupsd that I am presently running, the
serial version can shut off the power of the UPS, but the USB version
cannot.  There might be a newer one available; I've not checked in ages.

four years, Linux contacts for other groups, companies, & contractors --

I was at least keeping the site up to date, fixing links, keeping it
visible until either I could give it my undivided attention, or someone
who wanted to work full time on it volunteered to take it to the next stage.

potential to be a useable resource; but your slap-dash work now put what's
there back a year. BTW, not only did I solicit feedback & talked to people
about what the site needed, I made an effort to keep all of the existing
content where anyone could see it.

If you want people to help you, learn to work with people.

I became webmaster when I took the initiative and reimplemented the
website backend.  We now have validated HTML, and readable source.  All
that remains is to port the content.  The difficult part is finished!

XEmacs on drizzle is configured globally with the "mmm-mode" support
required for maintaining the site.  If you do not have DSL or would like
to edit locally, you can check it out of CVS.  Install "mmm-mode", copy
the relevant setups from /etc/xemacs21/site-start.d/* (grep mmm there),
and also grab "mmm-ext.el" (locate it).  Tested in XEmacs only, YMMV,
ask me for help if you need any.  It should be fairly straightforward to
get working -- 10 minutes.

> In other words, the FAQ for PLUG, the list of presentations for the last

and this is what you'll see:

   <!DOCTYPE div PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">
   <div class="contentbody">
    
   </div>
   <%method BROWSER_TITLE>
   __DEFAULT__BROWSER_TITLE__
   </%method>
   <%method TITLE>
   Portland Linux / Unix Group (PLUG)
   </%method>
   <%method last_updated>
   <!-- Created: Sun Jul 21 21:33:22 PDT 2002 -->
   <!-- hhmts start -->
   Last modified: Mon Jan  6 13:49:07 PST 2003
   <!-- hhmts end -->
   </%method>
   %# Local variables:
   %# mode: xml
   %# mmm-classes: (mason embedded-css embedded-javascript)
   %# sgml-omittag:t
   %# sgml-shorttag:t
   %# sgml-namecase-general:t
   %# sgml-general-insert-case:lower
   %# sgml-minimize-attributes:nil
   %# sgml-always-quote-attributes:t
   %# sgml-indent-step:1
   %# sgml-indent-data:t
   %# sgml-parent-document:nil
   %# sgml-exposed-tags:nil
   %# sgml-local-catalogs:("/etc/sgml/catalog")
   %# sgml-local-ecat-files:("ECAT" "~/sgml/ECAT" "/usr/lib/sgml/ECAT" "/usr/local/lib/sgml/ECAT")
   %# End:

Looks more-or-less like text to me.  

If you are suffering Emacs-phobia, you can ignore the "%# ..." stuff,
I think.  Those are comments wrapping emacs local variables for the
file.  Emacs magic.

  <http://cvs.pdxlinux.org/viewcvs.cgi/website/faq.html?rev=1.3&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup>

None of this message should be construed as taking a position who
should be doing what, when, where or with what vegetable.

From derek at infotects.com  Tue Jan  7 10:28:01 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Jan  7 10:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Screen Resolution problem with CYCAS
In-Reply-To: <3E1A11F7.403F1C30@attbi.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301030746160.7395-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
	 <3E1A11F7.403F1C30@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1041964061.10504.20.camel@dereklinux>

On Mon, 2003-01-06 at 15:32, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
[snip]
> I remember at some time in the past having a window that was larger than
> the screen, and by moving the mouse up to the top edge I would move
> higher up in the window. By moving the mouse to the bottom edge, I would
> move lower in the window. Same thing with left and right. In other
> words, the screen provided 800 x 600 access to a part of a 1024 x 768
> window. What I don't remember is where I experienced this. Is this
> something available with X in Linux? If so, what's it called, and where
> do I set it up?

This is a feature of Xfree86.  During the setup, available resolutions
are selected (should depend on the monitor and video card selected),
with one as the default.  The keys <ctrl>+<alt>+<keypad+> will decrease
the viewable resolution (and will decrease each time they are pressed,
unless you are at the lowest resolution, then it will cycle to the
highest), but the virtual resolution won't change (everything on your
desktop will still be there, just bigger).  Moving the mouse to the
edges of the viewable space will pan the display.  To increase viewable
resolution (makes things smaller), press <ctrl>+<alt>+<keypad->.  My
suggestion is to use your highest (legible) resolution as the default,
and adjust from there.  Don't select any resolutions that don't work on
your hardware, I have monitors that will display 1600x1200, but I don't
use this resolution because nothing is legible.  This is configured in
the XF86Config(-4) file, but your distribution probably has a tool for
changing the x-server configuration.

HTH

Derek Loree





From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Jan  7 10:59:01 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Jan  7 10:59:01 2003
Subject: Resolved: [PLUG] Screen Resolution problem with CYCAS
In-Reply-To: <3E1B1594.97653337@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301071052030.4922-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Richard Steffens wrote:

> By setting the GUI font to 8 points, the entire window becomes visible,
> and I can grab the title bar and move the window on and off screen to
> the right and left -- it's still too wide to fit within 800 pixels. This
> makes it possible to work with, and I'll be giving it a try later on.

Dick,

  A question and a suggestion. Does the application generate its own window
or does it open in a virtual terminal? In the latter case you can specify
the opening window size.

  Regarding fonts. As root, run /usr/sbin/chkfontpath to see what size fonts
are found and in which order. As I closed the thread on my spreadsheet app
on steroids I mentioned that it was the font path sequence that had become
hosed on my system. Once I put that pack in order (with the 75dpi fonts --
scaled -- first) the whole thing became visible again.

  You can run the appres tool to learn what fonts and screen resources are
used by your CAD program.

HTH,

Rich

We don't have to take away Karl's power, we just have to make sure other
people have equal power to counterbalance bad decisions (and enforcement
of control).

Karl has shown (quite unfortunately, but quite literally and explicitly)
that he cannot be trusted to enact the will of PLUG (or maybe just that he
cannot distinguish between his will FOR PLUG and the will OF PLUG).

I don't think we need to REPLACE him so much as we need to dilute his
power by giving more people control over the systems.

You can't be effective as a rogue if others can easily undo your work.

From bjh at avalongroup.net  Tue Jan  7 15:39:01 2003

Why don't we just create a web design committee?  Anyone who has changes
or enhancements to the site sends their code to the committee.  The
committee reviews the code, votes on whether to implement it or not and
goes forward.  Why won't this work?  A 5-6 person committee should be
sufficient.  Rotate the actual web admin job between the people on the
committee.  This way, the committee decides what goes on the site after
taking input from the list; lessening the possibility that one person
can take control.  If a person gets out of line, that person gets
removed from the committee by a vote.  If this is a bad idea, please
explain to me why.  It may not be perfect, but at least it is better
than arguing about it throughout the list.  

--Brian

Steven,

It's unfortunate that you saw this ugliness so quickly. I've been
participating in this listserver now for a couple of months, so I'm
fairly new here too. There definately is a lot of crap in here; a lot
of opinions like "my way is the only way and any different is
evil/stupid/inferior."

But if you manage to look past the crap, it can be a very useful
resource. In the short time I've been here, I've had two or three
problems solved quickly by several friendly people who offered
suggestions. I have also posted a few messages trying to help other
people when I had experience on a particular topic. Though the
obnoxious are vocal, they are few. The majority of the people here can
be quite helpful. Be patient, and stick around.

-Scott

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Brian Hoag wrote:
> Why don't we just create a web design committee?  Anyone who has
> changes or enhancements to the site sends their code to the committee.  
> The committee reviews the code, votes on whether to implement it or
> not and goes forward.  Why won't this work?  A 5-6 person committee
> should be sufficient.  Rotate the actual web admin job between the
> people on the committee.  This way, the committee decides what goes on
> the site after taking input from the list; lessening the possibility
> that one person can take control.  If a person gets out of line, that
> person gets removed from the committee by a vote.  If this is a bad
> idea, please explain to me why.  It may not be perfect, but at least
> it is better than arguing about it throughout the list.

Well, I just think that it's dumb to set up a committee and consolidate
the power there when we've seen very clearly what happens when power is
consolidated into the hands of the few.

It might "work", but it's a fairly soviet solution (I use that term oddly,
I know, but it just kind of fits... I mean that it has the sheen of
cooperation and community, but is actually just another way of handing
over control to a privileged few and ensuring their continued reign with
endless bureaucracy and the application of copious force).

Also consider that PLUG is a wholly open club to which one attains
membership by merely claiming membership.  Any "committee" would be about
the same.  If it were any other way, you'd have to say that some few
people have the power to say that some other few people can't participate
at whatever level they choose.  It's the path to Hell.

Please don't mistake my righteous indignation for righteous indignation.
J.

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Preston Crawford wrote:
> On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > If we restrict Karl's abilities in the future, we're justifying the
> > restriction of people's abilities.  I won't stand by that.
> 
> Oh, that's some hippy dippy crap if I ever heard it.

You heard it?  Do you always move your lips when you read?

[The attempt at a clever retort above came after considerable deliberation
(for a comment like that).  I thought about throwing out something like,
"Is 'love thy neighbor' and The Golden Rule hippy dippy crap, too?", but I
decided that maybe actual argument wasn't warranted since the comment
itself was just dismissive insult and not argument at all.  So you got
what's there.  I hope to try harder in the future.]

> Even open source software projects have people that decide what is
> allowed into the main source tree.

Even open source software projects can be oppressive tyrannies.  Why
should software projects be different than any other kind of human
organization?  Some are corrupt and destructive and others are spiritless
and dull and still others are respectful and cooperative.

> I know of no effective software IT operation where everyone has the
> same level of access.

Can you name ONE "software IT operation where everyone has the same level
of access"?

I think that perhaps you don't know of an effective one because you don't
know of any at all.  In that case, "effective" is a red herring.

I can safely say the following:

I know of no failed software IT operation where everyone had the same
level of access.

See why the adjective is meaningless and misleading?

PLUG is not a software IT operation.  PLUG is a club of friends who learn
from one another about information technology, specifically as it relates
to Unix, the GNU system, and Linux (with a healthy dose of the related
hardware and network engineering disciplines).  We have no set task or
agenda.  We're just trying to make our lives better by being involved with
one another and learning from each other.  Perhaps some of us like to use
what we learn at PLUG to draw in more members or convert our friends and
family and employers and landlords to our "enlightened" ways, but others
don't care about evangelism and just want a set of people with whom to
commiserate, share, and ask questions.  They're all welcome.

The purpose of HAVING a web site is two-fold; a) to have a place to
quickly disseminate information to people not on the mailing lists about
the group's activities and affiliations and b) to experiment for ourselves
and show each other how we might implement various features with existing
tools in our Unix/GNU/Linux arsenal.

We don't have stockholders for whom we must increase value.  We don't have
quarterly reviews for which we must show incremental improvement.  We're
just a bunch of people feeding off one another and hoping that makes our
lives better in some way.  We all have different reasons for being
involved and can only assume one thing in common:  We all have some
interest in communicating with people who have an interest in
communicating with other people within the scope of Unix, the GNU system,
and Linux.

It's pretty stupid, if you think about it.  But life is really just a
bunch of stupid associations in which we involve ourselves to feel alright
about the time we spend between meals and naps.

> > What Karl is doing is wrong (taking control away from others) and we're
> > just as wrong if we do it to him.
> 
> Oh boy.

Yeah, phew.  That's a radical nutjob's idea, huh?  Imagine!  Thinking that
a person is wrong for doing unto others as they would not have done unto
themselves!

We all know that sensible people do things like use weapons of mass
destruction against nations for the crime of possibly posessing and maybe
even intending to use weapons of mass destruction!

Ooh, it's all so circular.

Break the cycle.  Forgive.  You can't fight crime by committing crime.
J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Jan  8 00:50:03 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Jan  8 00:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PLUG-WEB] Enough.... Let's Focus on the Issue
In-Reply-To: <200301080756.h087u4029945@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301080020490.1847-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 7 Jan 2003, Felix Lee wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>:
> > When a number of peers are set with equal power, they keep each other in
> > line and there is little temptation toward abuse.
> 
> doesn't scale well.  works ok for 2 people, starts running into
> problems when you have more than that. --

Are you writing that from personal experience?  ...because mine differs by
180 degrees.

It works HORRIBLY with two people and really doesn't start to show pay-off
until you get up to ten or twelve, in my experience.

With a few people, it's almost impossible to distinguish rogue behavior
from a change in the group's overall goals.  The more people, the more the
goals of the group are narrowly defined (being the intersection of the
goals of many people).

With small numbers, disagreement becomes divisive and arguments degrade
quickly into personal opinions and unfounded bias.  With many, more call
is made for a person to explain their actions and petty bias doesn't fly.

Also, as one wise software developer wrote, all bugs are transparent to
the thousand eyes.

Consider that more people with the power to make change means more people
with the responsibility to change things for the better.

I am always amazed at the lengths people will go to preserve the
known-faulty hierarchical regimes.
J.

get the web team back on-topic again.  I cannot defend myself on two
fronts, though I shall have to try as my professional reputation may be
at stake here.  I'm being libelled left and right.

The people who suggested moving the server to another domain or box are
in my opinion arrogant and rude individuals who should not be taken very
seriously by the more businesslike and professional amoung us.

Jeme is probably mentally ill.  He sees nazi's everywhere or something.


Everyone please look at the site, and, if you want to help out:

 * test in several browsers, report to the "plug-web" list your
findings, after checking (lurker) for already reported...

 * Try the trouble ticket system if you have a feature request or
problem report.  Please don't post "test bugs" anymore... Let's get to
the real business of doing this web site right.

 * Review the markup via CVS as well.  Please compare the code in the
"oldsite" module to that in the "website" module.  What do you
experience web developers see there?  Please tell the list, as we are in
need of informed opinion here.  There's been enough ranting and raving
for one week.

 * Does anyone have any articles you would like published?  Submit them
to plug-web for approval and they will be!

 * Any feature requests?  Post a trouble ticket please!

 * Got "not invented here"?  Learn to overcome it.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Wed Jan  8 04:23:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Wed Jan  8 04:23:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PLUG-WEB] Enough.... Let's Focus on the Issue
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301080020490.1847-100000@shaft.bitmine.net> on Wed, 08 Jan 2003 00:52:14 PST.
Message-ID: <200301081221.h08CLQq30493@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>:
> With small numbers, disagreement becomes divisive and arguments degrade
> quickly into personal opinions and unfounded bias.  With many, more call
> is made for a person to explain their actions and petty bias doesn't fly.

ok, I'm not going to claim any great experience, but the
behavior you describe has a simple explanation that doesn't
fit your ideology.  successful groups of a dozen or so
people are successful because the people in the group have
the right temperament to form a successful group.  people
who can't function in the group won't stay in the group.
disruptive people who do stay in a group will alienate
people who want to work as a group, and the group will never
get very large, or fail entirely.  so the data set is
systematically biased.

I don't think you can toss an arbitrary set of people
together, follow the rules that seem to work for one
particular successful group, and expect a happy ending.  I
don't think there are any social/political structures that
are suitable for all occasions.

my experience with groups of random people with no structure
is that nothing gets done.  they rarely reach any consensus,
and nobody takes initiative or responsibility for anything.
when someone does, he becomes a de facto leader, and if he's
politic enough, people happily follow his lead.

> I am always amazed at the lengths people will go to preserve the
> known-faulty hierarchical regimes.

  Nope. Not at all. (Errata: it was about 4 years ago I bought the cdrom,
not earlier.)

  Installing the fonts is as complex as selecting the one(s) you want from
the sample sheet and using the font ID number(s) for the family to copy from
the cdrom to the hard drive.

  The complexity is working through the instructions in 'fontinst' so that
LaTeX will recognize -- and use -- fonts other than Computer Modern.

electrons shifted and the states can represent both 0 and 1 simultaneously.
They've got it working with up to 10 ions now, but expect to have hundreds
signed up for a massively parallel system comparatively soon.

Quantum Electons); can a port of linux be far behind?

From paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com  Wed Jan  8 07:31:01 2003
From: paynoattention at anarchysoftware.com (Richard Seymour)
Date: Wed Jan  8 07:31:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PLUG-WEB] Enough.... Let's Focus on the Issue
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301072237500.1847-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3E1C4403.9040509@anarchysoftware.com>

Committees can be structured to be more or less self selecting. For 
instance, the FREE GEEK policy making body has a rule that anyone who 
attends two consecutive meetings becomes part of the official decision 
making process on their third meeting. Miss three meetings in a row, and 
you're back at square one. (Gotta go to two consecutive meetings again 
before being part of official decisions.) Anyone can show up and weigh 
in on the discussion -- you just can't "vote" (participate in the 
consensus, whatever) unless you've done the prerequisite time.

PLUG could probably adapt this kind of approach if we see the need to 
become a bit more formal about how things are done, and still want to 
keep the flavor of "you're a member if you say you're a member".

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Well, I just think that it's dumb to set up a committee and consolidate
> the power there when we've seen very clearly what happens when power is
> consolidated into the hands of the few.
> 
> It might "work", but it's a fairly soviet solution (I use that term oddly,
> I know, but it just kind of fits... I mean that it has the sheen of
> cooperation and community, but is actually just another way of handing
> over control to a privileged few and ensuring their continued reign with
> endless bureaucracy and the application of copious force).
> 
> Also consider that PLUG is a wholly open club to which one attains
> membership by merely claiming membership.  Any "committee" would be about
> the same.  If it were any other way, you'd have to say that some few
> people have the power to say that some other few people can't participate
> at whatever level they choose.  It's the path to Hell.
> 
> Please don't mistake my righteous indignation for righteous indignation.
> J.

Can you believe this soap opera that's going on with this?

I know this is supposed to be an open group that allows anyone that wants
to participate to be able to join, but we have to draw the line when
certain people do more flaming, arguing, slandering and bitching than
contributing in a constructive manner.

There is no where (that I have seen) that says the group can't ban people
from participating for behaving in a destructive manner.  I believe there
are people that are being a lot more destructive than helpful.

There are options that I see that would resolve this.

1.  Move the server out of control of the current admin
Either by restricting (or removing) access to the server, or by just
deeming another server to be the PLUG server altogether.

2.  Create a separate User Group
People who are not happy with this list and/or group can start their own
user group.  They can organize their own separate meetings, web site,
mailing list, etc.

3.  Do not participate in the list/group
People who are not happy with this list and/or group can participate in
another User Group that already exists

This is just silly.

Me, and, I'll admit it. My 'home-office/job' system runs well enough to keep 
my boss from stepping in and forcing me to convert to MS-XCrud.

I've had a few recent successes (such as installing Flash into Mozilla myself 
so I could watch a 'swf' file an e-mail buddy sent me)  but for bigger 
things, I am mostly clueless and rather terrified to experiment too much.

Still haven't gotten avi's to play after all these months - I have lesiure 
time but that's for PLAYING the music/game, etc. Futzing with 'what's not 
happening now, what to I have to twiddle next, or download at 2.6Kb/sec' is 
NOT lesiure ...

I usually plonk out the Debian stuff, how to administer a workplace server, I 
don't program in perl etc. I first learned programming in BASIC in the early 
70's, and (without knowing it) I -LOVED- the feeling of riding shotgun with 
the execution. You didn't need to know what a compiler was - Just give the 
computer a list of orders (numbered to keep them straight) hit RUN, and it 
will do as many of them as it can FIRST, and only complain when it finally 
hits a nasty. If you couldn't figure out why that line number bombed, most 
times you could GOTO around it for now, run out the rest of the code anyways, 
and not be forced to fix everything perfect first before getting a even a 
glimpse of what your instructions do... What days!

But I liked the feeling that a computer will TRY to execute everything it can 
first, and complain later, if at all. Then came Pascal, followed by a desire 
to try out a splitting maul. Things went downhill from there, when computers 
said "LOGIN:" instead of "READY>"

But every once in a LONG while, someone asks a question that even I figured 
out, and I can contribute (a bit.)

-GLL

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Jan  8 11:31:02 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Jan  8 11:31:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] lost cd-rom drive under win
In-Reply-To: <ZW3LK953SN1YMJB8LJJIVT72NI6ID.3e1b7421@mike>
References: <ZW3LK953SN1YMJB8LJJIVT72NI6ID.3e1b7421@mike>
Message-ID: <1042054222.10511.33.camel@dereklinux>

On Tue, 2003-01-07 at 16:43, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> Sorry for asking this question here, but I can't google it, been trying for over an 
> hour. Can't find it in the SARC site, either.
> 
> Maybe a good flame Mike will divert attention from the recent drama on the list.
> 
> Is there a virus or something that knocks out the cd-rom drive in win9x? I've gone 
> through all of my regular tools. Damn thing just got my laptop, too. I know the 
> drive is fine, because it works great when I reboot into RH 8.0. I'd dump the win, 
> but I must run access for a customer.

Not that I'm aware of, unless you count the OS as a virus.  More than
likely, you aren't praying enough when the P'n'P detects devices.  I've
seen this many times, and the solution is never the same.  Sometimes you
have to boot into "Safe Mode", remove all CD type devices from the
device manager, then reboot.  Other times you have to change the
settings of the CD drive, like change it from slave to master, or put it
on a different controller.  Sometimes it helps to turn of the BIOS
detection of the drive (windows will find it anyway, most of the time). 
Sometimes it helps to turn on the BIOS detection of the drive.  The idea
is to change something, anything, and see what's there after it reboots.

Good Luck

Derek Loree





From tjg at craigelachie.org  Wed Jan  8 11:58:02 2003
From: tjg at craigelachie.org (Timothy Grant)
Date: Wed Jan  8 11:58:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] linux-wlan-ng and differently configured networks
Message-ID: <200301081157.18166.tjg@craigelachie.org>

Hi all,

Got an interesting one. I just got a new Thinkpad R31 running Gentoo 1.4rc1.

The R31 has build in 802.11b using the Prism 2.5 chipset. On install the 
wireless worked right off using the Orinoco drivers, but there were some 
serious issues, so I build the linux-wlan-ng stuff. It's configuration is far 
nicer than the last linux-wlan-ng stuff I used, so i'm wondering if it is 
possible to do something I've never tried before...

My wireless net at home is different from my wireless net at the office. We 
run WEP at work, the SSID is different etc. It's simple to manually change 
wlan.conf to look at the wireless options for the office or home, but it's 
kind of annoying too. 

What I'd like to do is have the wlan0 device look at the SSID of the network 
that it finds and configure itself automagically for that network. Is this 
possible?

Thanks.


-- 
Stand Fast,
    tjg.

Timothy Grant
www.craigelachie.org




From judah at opusnet.com  Wed Jan  8 12:22:02 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Wed Jan  8 12:22:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] linux-wlan-ng and differently configured networks
In-Reply-To: <200301081157.18166.tjg@craigelachie.org>
References: <200301081157.18166.tjg@craigelachie.org>
Message-ID: <1042057267.20593.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Set your ESSID string to  Any  .. when you bring your device up it will
associate with ESSID of the AP that is producing the strongest signal in
the area. 

However, this won't be able to automagically set your WEP string..
you'll have to do that when associated to your work AP. This can be done
from the command line with   iwconfig , part of the wireless-tools
package.  iwconfig eth0 enc XXXX-XXXX see the man page for more
information.. 

A-

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jan  8 13:19:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jan  8 13:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] linux-wlan-ng and differently configured networks
In-Reply-To: <1042057267.20593.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301081309010.10341-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 8 Jan 2003, Aaron Baer wrote:

> Set your ESSID string to Any .. when you bring your device up it
> will associate with ESSID of the AP that is producing the strongest
> signal in the area.

Right. The SSID string is only of real use in areas where there are 
overlapping wireless networks. In most cases, the 'any' string is what 
you want.

On a related note, I'm right now installing Red Hat 8.0 on a Compaq
Evo using the built-in wavelan card. It's very cool: boot cd, type
"linux askmethod" at the boot prompt, tell it the nfs server and path, 
et voila!

If I'd worked a bit harder, I could have retrieved the installation
image from a PXE server. :-)

And since I maintain a fully patched installation tree (via anaconda
and Eric Harrison's online HOWTO), complete with some locally built
RPMS, there's no post-installation or patching needed.

No cables. No fuss. No unnecessary reboots.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

           A CALL FOR A MORATORIUM ON PERSONAL ATTACKS

People,

    We seem to have a number of very serious problems in the PLUG
group at the moment, which I'm going to try to address in
next few days.  This will involve a number of postings, some
personal email, some phone calls, and very likely result in
an meeting or two.

    In the mean time, let's have a moratorium on flames and
personal attacks on the mailing lists - especially on
plug at pdxLinux.org.  We used to have a well described reputation
for having an excellent mailing list - with very few off topic
postings and very very few personal attacks.  However, we have
changed in the last year or so; and personal attacks have
become common place.  LET'S CHANGE THIS BACK - at least for
a week or two.

    Also, don't respond to personal attacks.  It isn't worth
the effort and only fuels the flames.  If you feel you must
respond, either do it privately or write a response that only
addresses PLUG and/or Linux issues and doesn't respond to the
personal nature of the attack.

wlancfg-DEFAULT
wlancfg-RENTRAK
wlancfg-WLAN

It seems to me that the connection "knows" the SSID of the network that it's

Am I missing something, or is what you are looking for a drawing tool?
In Word Perfect, you'd click Insert > Shape > ... and choose from a list
of lines, Draw Line, Horizontal Line, Vertical Line, etc. Since there's
something similar in MS Word, I expected to find it in OO Writer. When I
start OO Writer up, I have a tool bar down the left side of the window.
The top icon says "Insert" when I hover over it. The next line says,
"Insert Fields." The third one says "Insert Objects," and the fourth one
says "Show Draw Functions." Under that one I found the expected
selection of line, rectangle, ellipse, etc.

To test it, I typed a few lines on the page with some white space around
them, and put one of them over on the right side. Then, I drew a
horizontal line between the two on the left, and a vertical line between
them and the one on the right.

Is that the kind of line you're looking for?

In-Reply-To: <200301081624.59175.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Wed, 8 Jan 2003, Carla Schroder wrote:

> Well, you can create a frame, then make borders where you want lines. I don't 
> know of any word processor that does it any other way. Doesn't mean there 
> isn't another way....

  WordPerfect (from versions 4.0-8) allowed the user to place horizontal and
vertical lines (of user-selected thickness) wherever they were wanted. The
length, starting position and ending position were all set from a dialog
box. This is what I was using for 18 years and I became used to being able
to do such things.

  I suppose that the next time I do something like this I'll use another
WordPerfect trick: make the whole document a table and resize or merge cells
as required to achieve the desired look.

  FWIW, I sent a copy of the file to the state agency so they could put it
on their Web site, along with the useless pdf version. I also pointed them
to the OpenOffice.org Web site and suggested that they consider saving money
by adopting OO. Then they could use the template I provided them. :-)

Rich

This sounds like just the ticket, then. MS Word has similar drawing tools, I 
used to use them a lot back when I *shudder* worked for others. If one wished 
one's missive to be deemed important, it had to be tarted up with colorful 
boxes, drop-shadows, and silly clipart. The upside was it was OK to spend 2 
hours finely-crafting a two-paragraph memo.

Position your cursor over the 'show draw functions' button, then click and 
hold on the tiny arrow in the top-right corner of the icon. A menu showing 
the line tools pops up. You have to hold the mouse button down for a couple 
of seconds. Easy as pie. :)

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Jan  8 18:07:02 2003
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed Jan  8 18:07:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Printing with RH 8 - It Just Works!
Message-ID: <3E1CD8FB.61F3252C@attbi.com>

I'm fiddling with Cycas, a CAD system from Germany. I successfully
completed the basic tutorial exercises and decided to see what a print
out looked like. Then, I remembered that I hadn't set up a printer on
this system yet, and was a bit trepidatious about how successful that
would be. Turns out to be simple.

I plugged my HP 656c into the Thinkpad's USB port, clicked on the red
hat > System Settings > Printing. This brought up a password entry box
for root access. Then it started up the Red Hat Printer Config utility.
Clicking on "new" brings up a series of fill-in-the-blank boxes, that
had no problem finding everything it needed to support the HP 656c with
LPD. It was so quick and boring, that I wondered if it had done anything
at all. It actually took me a couple of minutes longer to figure out how
to set the print scale in Cycas, but once I had done that, and hit
print, the printer came to life and from it, a respectable drawing
emerged.

The last time I tried to set up the HP 656c was with a slightly older
distribution that didn't include hpijs. I eventually managed to get it
working with CUPS, but it took a lot longer.

Kyle Accardi wrote:

> One of the things that is really nice is the ability to toggle layers
> (visible or not), currently xfig only uses a numbering system, but the
> author has told me that soon the layers will be able to be labeled--does
> CYCAS have such a thing?

I haven't played with it yet, but CYCAS does support layers. From a
first glance, it looks as if there are only 10 layers, which is nowhere
near enough for serious work. I don't know if that's a limitation of the
free version, or just where they are at this stage of development. The
layers can be named, though.

Oops! I just took a closer look. There's a dialog box with 10 entries,
the first one named Layer 0 by default and all the rest named ***
Unregistered ***. There are also 10 tabs, numbered 0 through 9, and each
one of those has 10 entries too, so that's 100 layers. Not unreasonable,
although Corel CAD, and even Generic CAD (DOS program from the 80's) had
255 layers.

While it is possible to tell CYCAS to use feet or inches, the default is
metric, and dimensions entered by hand have to be done in centimeters.
That's a bit of a nuisance. I haven't tried showing dimensions, yet, so
I don't know how well they convert.

I've got a print-server machine running lprng.  My laptop is setup with

recently loaded Mandrake 9 on my wife's box and setup CUPS on that machine
to also sent printjobs to the print-server, but it doesn't work.  I've got

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Wed Jan  8 22:49:02 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Wed Jan  8 22:49:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS and printing to a remote server
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301082232360.32502-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301082232360.32502-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <863co2byy8.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Phil" == Phil Tomson <ptkwt at aracnet.com> writes:

Phil> I've got a print-server machine running lprng.  My laptop is
Phil> setup with CUPS and sends jobs to the print-server machine
Phil> without problem... but I recently loaded Mandrake 9 on my wife's
Phil> box and setup CUPS on that machine to also sent printjobs to the
Phil> print-server, but it doesn't work.  I've got CUPS configured
Phil> identially as it is on the laptop which can print, but nothing.
Phil> It seems like the jobs aren't making it to the printserver.

Phil> Any ideas on how to debug this?

You could try ethereal on the link.  Maybe attach strace to the lpd
(or equivalent) process on the server side.  Also, at least with
old-fashioned lpd, you can stop the print server (partially) and then
look at the print job in the queue before it gets sent to the printer.
Old-fashioned lpd puts two files in the spool directory, the job
content and a control file.  Examining the control file can sometimes
yield some useful information about what might be going wrong.
Another thing to check is hosts.lpd (or equivalent) to see if your
client host has permission to submit print jobs.

In-Reply-To: <7676.66.93.41.98.1042047798.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

	 <7290.66.93.41.98.1041977553.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>
