> > > > to something 'still viable?'
> > > 
> > > debian
> > 
> > <insert distribution flamewar here.>
> 
> What is the point in this?

"Debian is the answer" is a usual comment that come up when people ask 
about distributions.  Many of the Debian people (as well as others) are 
quite zealous on one side of the argument or the other.  

Personally I have some problems with Debian.  It does some things right 
and many things wrong.  It works if you run a pure Debian system, but does 
not react well if you do not.  (I had to deal with such an upgrade over 
the weekend.  2.2 to 3.0 does not upgrade as cleanly as the pro-debian 
crowd would like to believe.

> > I don't think he could install Debian.  He has a 56k modem line, if that. 
> > Most Debian distributions insist on downloading anything and everything.
>  
> Are you saying that Debian doesn't come on CD's? Also, what do you mean
> by "downloading anything and everything". Are you saying it won't
> download off the CD? Please clue me in, because I don't understand what
> your trying to say here.

Go to Debian.org and try to get current ISOs.  Damn near impossible.  (I 
tried.  I found them, but it took hours of searching.  And they were not 
"official".)  The current Debian discs I have found assume that you 
install enough to bootstrap and then download everything else via apt-get.  
That works if you have bandwidth.  

Guy does not have bandwidth.  (He lives in Warren, OR.  It is half way 
between here and the coast.)

As for the functionality of Debian...  My experiences do not match up to 
the ads.  Debian is not as trouble free as claimed, in my experience.  
(Especially during an upgrade.  Whoever decided to move /var/spool/mail to 
/var/mail and not move the spool and/or symlink things together needs to 
be *hurt*. By me.)

This conversation usually devolves into a religious war because some 
people believe that apt-get solves everything.  It doesn't.  Then again, I 
am at the point where I hate all distributions equally. Some more equally 
than others...

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jan 22 17:11:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Jan 22 17:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <20030122215228.B8F4A34A75@ados.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301221647310.4280-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

There are quite a few strong mature distributions.
Among these are:

      RedHat
      SuSE
      Mandrake
      Debian

All of these are very good distros, altho each has
certain advantages in particular situations.

If you like Mandrake, I would not jump ship until
I knew the ship was sinking.  Mandrake is a troubled
company, but certainly not a dead company at this
point.  Moreover, a lot of people love Mandrake Linux,
and Mandrake is Open Source.  Thus, if worse comes to
worse the Mandrake user community may take it over.
If Mandrake were close source, I would probably
recommend jumping ship NOW, but being OpenSource
makes the situation much more tolerable.

                                          Sincerely,
                                          David Mandel

The instructions for Gentoo assume that you have a cd-rom and a network 
card available at the same time.  It took some hacking to get around that.  
(Bootstrapping a network by hand is something I have not has to do since 
the Linux 1.0 days.)

It took about 2 weeks to get what I wanted installed on my little Vaio 
celeron 333.  It would have been better if I would have had the 40 gig 
drive in it at the time. (The current disk is faster.  The compiles took 
longer than they should due to a slow drive.)

One of these days I will build another Gentoo machine. For people who want 
to learn how things work under the hood, it is a good distro to go with.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jan 22 19:11:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Wed Jan 22 19:11:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <1043286178.11447.58.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301221842190.4889-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

I cut my list very very short, because I thought the original
poster wanted a short list.  However, there are a lot of fine
distributions out there.  Unfortunately, most distribution
makers have trouble getting continuous funding which leads
to problems maintaining and enhancing their distributions.

Sometimes I think the best way to build a speciality distribution
is to build it as a subset of one of the major distributions.
Thus, it is little more than:

         (1)  A script to grab debs or rpms
         (2)  Along with very specialized documentation

Unfortunately, even this approach gets complicated as one usually
needs software (not to mention data) which isn't in any of the
major distributions; and the major distribution's update procedure
may be too dangerous to use; and ...

                                                     Dave Mandel

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Jan 22 21:25:02 2003
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Jan 22 21:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  These threads on distributions are always interesting (except when they
degenerate into the "mine is bigger than yours" ego matches). I almost
always learn something useful. This most recent thread (initiated by the
possibility that Mandrake might roll over and float belly up in the ocean of
European bankruptcy laws) generated a couple of generic distribution
questions.

  My understanding is that underneath the hood all distributions will run
all end-user application software. Differences appear in installation tools
and techniques, degree of compliance with the linux standard base file system
hierarchy and file placement, administration tools and other comparatively
minor features. Each distribution targets a segment of the potential market
ranging from the click-and-drool crowd converting from an Etch-A-Sketch(R)
to the most deeply technical geek who won't use any distribution
comprehensible to mere mortals.

  I have some questions about distributions that I hope can be answered
without generating 'Net rage or wide diversions from the specific points.

  If I understand the concept of packages (and I don't care whose they are),
they make installation, upgrade and removal of an application easier and
quicker by tracking the libraries upon which the application depends and
notifying the user if those libraries are not present. If my understanding
is correct, how do users of non-package distributions (e.g., Slackware) cope
with dependencies when a new application (or an upgraded one) is installed
from source?

  I get notices from Red Hat when they have a package upgrade available that
welds shut a security hole in the existing package. This is a rather handy
tool for a non-SysAdmin like me who can't spend a lot of time each day
reading bug-tracking mail lists and other such sources to learn of
vulnerabilities removed. What do folks do to keep their systems secure when
the distribution they run is Slackware, gentoo, linux-from-scratch or
something else?

  In a non-critical way, I'm curious if a lot of the Red Hat x.0 (and
sometimes, x.1) bugginess is an unintended consequence of complexity from
wrapping tools in covers that make them easier for us
less-technically-sophisticated users?

  I would like to understand a bit better what's behind a lot of the tools
I've taken for granted for the past 4.5 years. I hope y'all can help
increase my knowledge and understanding without condemning any given vendor
or the folks who use the results of their efforts.

Thanks,

Rich





From hapibeli at attbi.com  Wed Jan 22 21:29:01 2003
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Wed Jan 22 21:29:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Ipcop install
Message-ID: <1043299658.1553.11.camel@localhost.localdomain>

The following is the page I have trouble with in telling my Ipcop
install where to go to pick up my ipcop.tgz file. Where do I put the
.tgz file so the install box can get it?
Dirk

 This step is only needed if you are installing from bootable floppy and
FTP/Web Server. In the root directory  /  of the iso image there is a
file named  ipcop.tgz. This file contains a compressed image of the
IPCop hard drive. Copy this file to a machine that is running a web
server or FTP server. Put it where the server can find it during
install. During the install, IPCop will log in to your FTP or web server
as anonymous. Most servers do not allow anonymous users to access files
out of the server's hierarchy. Even though a directory appears at the
top level of the server, such as  /pub  they really are somewhere else,
such as  /anonftp/pub.

If you are creating your private network for the first time, change the
IP address of the server machine to be on the private, GREEN, network,
using a static address. You only need to do this for the duration of the
install.

If your server machine is connected to the Internet, remove the
connection and physically connect your IPCop PC and other machines
together. See Appendix A, for a discussion of your choices. If you are
using 192.168.1.1 for the IPCop PC, 192.168.1.2 is a good address for
the server. Set the server up with a static IP address, temporarily. You
will need to reboot any Windows PC if you change its IP address.

Verify that the IPCop installation file is available via the FTP command
or entering its URL from a browser, even if you have to do it from the
server machine. You can cancel the download or close your browser once
you are sure the URL works.





From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Jan 22 21:51:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Jan 22 21:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1043301033.11447.142.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2003-01-22 at 21:21, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   If I understand the concept of packages (and I don't care whose they are),
> they make installation, upgrade and removal of an application easier and
> quicker by tracking the libraries upon which the application depends and
> notifying the user if those libraries are not present. If my understanding
> is correct, how do users of non-package distributions (e.g., Slackware) cope
> with dependencies when a new application (or an upgraded one) is installed
> from source?

Generally speaking, when you compile things from source they are built
to correspond to the libraries on your system.  You take a tarball,
compile it against glibc 2.2.5, then it works with glibc 2.2.5 and not
2.3.1.

So, compiling things from source gets rid of many of those
specific-version dependencies.  When you do a ./configure, a
well-written program will search out and make sure you meet the
requirements, and if not, it'll give you a report of what you need,
which you can then grab the source for and compile.

It takes more time than using precompiled packages, but I think it is
just as easy most of the time.

>   I get notices from Red Hat when they have a package upgrade available that
> welds shut a security hole in the existing package. This is a rather handy
> tool for a non-SysAdmin like me who can't spend a lot of time each day
> reading bug-tracking mail lists and other such sources to learn of
> vulnerabilities removed. What do folks do to keep their systems secure when
> the distribution they run is Slackware, gentoo, linux-from-scratch or
> something else?

When there's a known exploit of a Slackware package, Pat patches it as
quick as possible and then emails the slackware-security list.  Gentoo
has a similar system which is a bit more robust.  LFS folks are on their
own, I think.

>   In a non-critical way, I'm curious if a lot of the Red Hat x.0 (and
> sometimes, x.1) bugginess is an unintended consequence of complexity from
> wrapping tools in covers that make them easier for us
> less-technically-sophisticated users?

That is surely part of t... but a great part of it, too, is that they
often use unstable development packages of important things in their
system.  8.0, I understand, used a prerelease version of glibc that
causes problems with some things.

7.0, IIRC, shipped with a prerelease version of gcc that didn't compile
things very well, especially c++ code.

Rob




From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Wed Jan 22 21:55:02 2003
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Wed Jan 22 21:55:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <65174.12.224.134.103.1043301270.squirrel@mail.parkrose.k12.or.us>

Rich Shepard said:
>   I get notices from Red Hat when they have a package upgrade
> available that
> welds shut a security hole in the existing package. This is a rather
> handy tool for a non-SysAdmin like me who can't spend a lot of time
> each day reading bug-tracking mail lists and other such sources to
> learn of vulnerabilities removed. What do folks do to keep their
> systems secure when the distribution they run is Slackware, gentoo,
> linux-from-scratch or something else?

Gentoo's announce mailing list is largely announcements re: security
fixes. Even if you don't read those, as soon as the ebuild is updated
and unmasked, you'd see it in your "emerge rsync && emerge world -up
--deep" sequence. That is roughly equivalent to debian's "apt-get
update && apt-get upgrade -s". The recent CVS vunerabilities were
patched faily quickly by this route.

Regardless of what distribution you use, it's worth _at least_
scanning the headlines at lwn.net if just to know what vulnerabilites
are out there. Most of the high-profile ones show up there. Some
places take longer than others to release patched versions. Do you
really want to wait for your distribution to tell you about the remote
root exploit in foo-1.23?

-Dan Young

> That is surely part of t... but a great part of it, too, is that they
> often use unstable development packages of important things in their
> system.  8.0, I understand, used a prerelease version of glibc that

I'm not sure if RH x.0 is really that much more buggy. I went through pretty
much all versions of RH since 3.2 I think, and I can't say that x.0 were
worse than the rest. They were more different, so they were harder to migrate
to, broke more upgrades, and were less compatible with previous releases
than the upgrades with changes in minor numbers. This is not a bug,
this is exactly why RH rolls major number for these releases. According to
the rules of RH version numbering, they roll the major number when backward
compatibility is broken. So if you upgrade to the new major, expect
that all old stuff will break, and if something does not it's a free bonus.
In practice most old stuff still works (I found that I could install old
compatibility libraries from RH7 which provide compatibility with RH 6 onto
RH 8.0 and compine a binary which actually runs on 6, 7, and 8, I was sure the
old libraries would not work, but they do).

> 7.0, IIRC, shipped with a prerelease version of gcc that didn't compile
And it did really awful job on bad C++ code which should have never compiled
in the first place but previous versions of GCC allowed it. Don't believe
everything you read on the net, alot of the people who bitched about the
compiler just got lazy and didn't want to fix their broken C++.

From amunk at pdx.edu  Wed Jan 22 23:18:01 2003

You could put a sound-capable computer in each room.

You could connect the local analog sources to an audio input of each sound card.
(This is the usual way of playing audio CDs on a computer.) If you want to
distribute that local source to the other rooms, you could use a program like
liveice or darkice.

http://star.arm.ac.uk/~spm/software/liveice.html
http://darkice.sf.net/

For streaming video from a DVD, try VideoLAN. ( http://www.videolan.org/ ) It
claims to be able to do that, although I've never tried it.

> Local amplification.  The kitchen speakers need lots of eq which is only 
> feasible using line-level.

Many (most?) sound chipsets include an amplifier, albeit not a very good one.

> 
> Source selection.  The main stereo is in the living room, the mp3 server is 
> in the basement (visual browsing of mp3s would be very nice).
> 
> As few always-on devices as possible.

I don't see why you'd need to leave any devices always on, except that you
might want to leave them on to avoid having to turn them on and wait whenever
you want to use them (especially the server).

> 
> ==
> 
> What is currently working:
> 
> A wireless notebook can browse the basement fileserver and select mp3s for 
> the kitchen, but cannot change sources (like to FM radio), nor can it affect

> an aux input).

In what way do you want to affect the living room receiver? You could set it up so that the receiver gets its audio signal from a computer in the living room, and then control that computer from any of the other computers.

> I've run cat5 to every room in the house (except the bathroom).

> tunage, given an IR detector in the wall.  Problem is, I don't know what 
> such an IR recvr-->Ethernet device would be named, so as to google.

You could get a PDA and a CompactFlash-based Ethernet adapter for it. (Of
course, with a PDA you'd have the same problem as with the notebook -- its
amplifier, if it had one, wouldn't be good enough.)

> 
> I've been trying to hash this out for a while and am having trouble defining

>

It looks ok for a "turnkey" solution, but I think that a normal computer with a sound chipset can do most things that it can do. (Are there any sound cards that support digital audio in/out?)

> one...  Since the official website is currently useless, see here if

To avoid the noise and heat of the HDD, you could netboot it ( see

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jan 23 01:39:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jan 23 01:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301222050440.5286-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301230120510.20764-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   If I understand the concept of packages (and I don't care whose they
> are), they make installation, upgrade and removal of an application
> easier and quicker by tracking the libraries upon which the
> application depends and notifying the user if those libraries are not
> present. If my understanding is correct, how do users of non-package
> distributions (e.g., Slackware) cope with dependencies when a new
> application (or an upgraded one) is installed from source?

I guess I don't understand this question.

My desktop machine is built entirely from source by hand (without
automated installation programs or scripts like Gentoo or whatever
has).  It has never had any kind of package management system on it.

A package, to me, is a source tarball from the maintainer's public
archive.  I download it, uncompress it and untar it, then run the
configure script with the --help option to see what it can do.

If there are dependencies that aren't met, the output of the configure
script should tell me.  Either a feature will be disabled because a
library isn't found or the configure will come to a dead stop because a
necessary requirement is not present.  The configure script will usually
let you know what the minimum compatible version should be as well.

As another poster noted, the interdependencies aren't quite as strict with
software built from source because the binaries are constructed using
whatever libraries you've got on hand.  When you upgrade lopster or
something, you're getting a precompiled binary that was built against a
very specific set of libraries and so you need to have dependent binaries
that exactly match those of the packager.  When I upgrade lopster, it just
links against what I've got so long as the functions are present.

>   I get notices from Red Hat when they have a package upgrade
> available that welds shut a security hole in the existing package.
> This is a rather handy tool for a non-SysAdmin like me who can't spend
> a lot of time each day reading bug-tracking mail lists and other such
> sources to learn of vulnerabilities removed. What do folks do to keep
> their systems secure when the distribution they run is Slackware,
> gentoo, linux-from-scratch or something else?

Well, Slackware and Gentoo have distribution maintainers who keep on top
of those things.  Gentoo has a ports tree that is kept up-to-date with
relevant patches and so on.

For my desktop system (and, I assume, systems built using the LFS book),
I'm pretty much on my own.  I keep on top of important updates as much as
I can.  However, it's just my desktop system and it's not running any
services that are accessible through my firewall.

In my opinion, this is the one very positive feature of package management
systems.  I have had to maintain non-package-managed machines that were
running live services with active internet connections and it is no
feast.  All of my public servers (except one, which runs just a handful of
services that are fairly rigorously maintained) are Debian for this
reason.

My desktop machine ISN'T Debian because I am often playing with software
outside the maintainers' stable trees and don't want to have to build
*-dev packages for every weird library to keep my dpkg databse current and
functional.  Someday, I'll figure out how to easily do that and just
maintain my own apt source for bleeding edge packages.  Right now, it's
more effort than it's worth.

> In a non-critical way, I'm curious if a lot of the Red Hat x.0 (and
> sometimes, x.1) bugginess is an unintended consequence of complexity
> from wrapping tools in covers that make them easier for us
> less-technically-sophisticated users?

I think Fedor nailed this with x.0 vs X.Y(Y>0) distinctions.

I've never run Red Hat for many reasons.

hardware together and build a system from scratch.  You'll "get it" after
you've got a full working system with all the software you normally use

I'm serious.  It's a great learning experience.

Rob,

  If it wasn't at the end of a long day I would have realized this, too. Of
course, the packages are pre-compiled binaries and they need library
versions against which they were compiled. Thank you for reminding me.
 
> So, compiling things from source gets rid of many of those
> specific-version dependencies.  When you do a ./configure, a
> well-written program will search out and make sure you meet the
> requirements, and if not, it'll give you a report of what you need,
> which you can then grab the source for and compile.

  So true! I've had more than my share of aborted configuration runs when
something wasn't found.

  7.3, too.

well.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Jan 23 08:35:03 2003
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Jan 23 08:35:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301220808450.23802-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
References: <20030123003535.GA7611@blain.org> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301220808450.23802-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
Message-ID: <20030123163409.GA25495@rauhaus.org>

* alan <alan at clueserver.org> [030122 16:59]:
>
> As for the functionality of Debian...  My experiences do not match up to 
> the ads.  Debian is not as trouble free as claimed, in my experience.  
> (Especially during an upgrade.  Whoever decided to move /var/spool/mail to 
> /var/mail and not move the spool and/or symlink things together needs to 
> be *hurt*. By me.)

/var/mail is the standard location for mail files in most SysV OS's,
such as Solaris, HPUX, and AIX. The /var/spool/mail location was a
reflection of the BSD flavors. The Linux File Heirarchy Standard has
mail files in /var/mail, not /var/spool/mail.

Now, the person in RedHat land who decided to move init scripts from
/etc/init.d to /etc/rc.d/init.d must have really been hitting the crack
pipe.

--Stafford



From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Thu Jan 23 08:52:01 2003
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Thu Jan 23 08:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301230120510.20764-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0301230839070.14542-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Wed, 22 Jan 2003, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >   If I understand the concept of packages (and I don't care whose they
> > are), they make installation, upgrade and removal of an application
> > easier and quicker by tracking the libraries upon which the
>
> A package, to me, is a source tarball from the maintainer's public

The dependency tracking is not really a benefit of the packages at all,
at least not when you compare with building from tarballs. It's something
packages must provide in order to be usable at all, but the reason you
want to use them is totally different.
For the most part, it's file management.
What does the file /usr/lib/libfoo.1.3.4 symlinked to /usr/lib/libfoo do?
It's a file from a tarball you compiled some two years ago, do you still
remember which one? If your new tarball for SuperFoo creates libfoo2.4.1
during compilation, and wants to link that as libfoo, what should you do?
If you want to replace MiniFoo with SuperFoo, how do you uninstall all
files from MiniFoo if the package author did not provide "make uninstall"?
If WizBang1 used to install into /usr/bin and /usr/lib but WizBang2 now
installs in /usr/local/bin and /usr/local/lib, how do you make sure all of
WizBang1 files are deleted when you upgrade?

The package system allows you to easily handle situations like this. The price
for it is the dependency management, which the packages must do. Again,
you can make this problem somewhat easier if you get source packages and
rebuild them. Then, if source dependencies are correct, it won't even build
without the right stuff installed, but more often then not source dependencies
are incomplete, then "configure" will tell you what you're missing.
--

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Thu Jan 23 11:06:02 2003

On Wed, 2003-01-22 at 18:52, Preston Crawford wrote:

> Also depends on whether you want to wait weeks to have a usable system.
> Not sure a couple weeks of lost productivity is worth the nanoseconds of
> time you save because your apps run a hair faster.

Well.. Gentoo wasn't built around the idea of folks running K6-2 350's.

If you're running an old CPU on an old system, Gentoo could certainly
take a week to compile.  On this slow (cost me $708) 1.7GHz P4 laptop, I
had a usable system (with X and fluxbox) in roughly ten hours, total.  I
was only actually attending the system for about two of those hours, and
that was only because I was screwing around trying to get funny things
working.  I would guess most folks only spend about an hour on it.

On the typical system (this 1.7GHz P4 doesn't compile very much quicker
than my super-Duron 650) you should be able to have a productive system
in a weekend.... certainly you won't lose a couple weeks of
productivity!  And my apps run more than a hair faster... Mozilla loads
up about twice as fast, optimized, as un-optimized.  Gentoo loads up
quicker than Slackware, and Slackware loads up a ton faster than RedHat
or Mandrake, etc. (can't speak for Debian - when I was running that, it
was inside vmware)

Rob




From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Jan 23 11:39:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Jan 23 11:39:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] GRUB configuration
In-Reply-To: <20030123071334.85797.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20030123071334.85797.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20030123193829.GA27415@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

I've installed grub in the following manner:

$ grub
grub> root (hd1,5)  
grub> setup (hd0)
grup> quit

That alone should give you enough to get a system booted, although it
won't be loads of fun. Everything else is taken from your menu.lst at
boot time.

Something like this works for me:

title=Debian
root (hd1,6)
kernel /vmLinuz root=/dev/hdb7

title=Gentoo
root (hd4,5)
kernel /boot/bzImage root=/dev/hde6

title=Windows
rood (hd0,0) 
chainloader +1


That should get you up and running, keep in mind your devices will
probably be different. The important part is the first part,
installing grub on the correct device, if that is done correctly you
can boot anything, the menu.lst isn't critical, just convienent.

the hdc=ide-scsi param is only needed if you have a drive (hdc) that
needs scsi emulation. This is usually the case for cdr[w] drives. If
you have an ide cdr, you probably need a param like this.


Hope that helps,
-Rogan

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jan 23 14:04:02 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jan 23 14:04:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0301230839070.14542-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301231405330.28750-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> The dependency tracking is not really a benefit of the packages at
> all, at least not when you compare with building from tarballs.

For me, that's the greatest benefit.  Package management is fast and easy
because of automatic dependency checking and installation.

> It's something packages must provide in order to be usable at all, but
> the reason you want to use them is totally different.

Not my reason, sir.

> For the most part, it's file management.

I can see how you might feel that way.  That's not such a big deal to me
when I'm acting as full-time administrator.

> What does the file /usr/lib/libfoo.1.3.4 symlinked to /usr/lib/libfoo
> do? It's a file from a tarball you compiled some two years ago, do you
> still remember which one?

Google will tell you.

> If your new tarball for SuperFoo creates libfoo2.4.1 during
> compilation, and wants to link that as libfoo, what should you do?

Test it.  Write a little shell script that checks ldd and prints binaries
compiled against it.  Try the upgrade.  Modify the symlinks or update the
few packages that don't work.  Lots of options.

Yes, it's slightly more work.  Personally, I don't mind it for some
systems.  The dependency tracking is the thing I miss most.

> If you want to replace MiniFoo with SuperFoo, how do you uninstall all
> files from MiniFoo if the package author did not provide "make
> uninstall"?

./configure --prefix=/opt/foo <whatever>

Then `find /opt/foo` and some little scripts to delete the files it
creates.

Or, as some do, install each package in /opt/package and you can just rm
the tree.  (Or move it first and see if anything breaks -- remember, I'm
not advocating this for systems where stability is paramount.)

> If WizBang1 used to install into /usr/bin and /usr/lib but WizBang2
> now installs in /usr/local/bin and /usr/local/lib, how do you make
> sure all of WizBang1 files are deleted when you upgrade?

That's what --prefix is for.

> The package system allows you to easily handle situations like this.

I don't htink those situations are all that difficult to handle without
package management.  At least, I don't mind handling them.

> The price for it is the dependency management, which the packages must
> do.

The dependency management and assurance of reliability is the primary
reason to use the stable Debian tree.  One source.  Fairly rigorously
tested packages.  No dependencies that aren't readily available.  Free as
in beer and freedom.

> Again, you can make this problem somewhat easier if you get source
> packages and rebuild them. Then, if source dependencies are correct,
> it won't even build without the right stuff installed, but more often
> then not source dependencies are incomplete, then "configure" will
> tell you what you're missing.

Right.

As I said, if I end up with several desktops that I want configured
similarly with the kind of flexibility and updatability I can't get from
Debian, I'll start appropriately building deb packages and set up an
alternative sources.list on my local network.

But for now, with a couple of machines, it's easier to just manage them by
hand.

Again, reliability isn't the goal here.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

On 23 Jan 2003, Ed Sawicki wrote:
> http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&u=/cmp/20030123/tc_cmp/inw20030122s0011

And this might be the point at which we all pay for Linus' ethical
failure.

He insists on avoiding the political implications of the work and doesn't
have clean copyright authority over what exists to date.

If SCO finds anything, Linux is in serious danger and the GPL as a whole
could be compromised.

There is absolutely nothing stopping other organizations and individuals
from doing the same thing or, as Apple pointed out a couple of years ago,
adults who contributed source as minors from "changing their mind" and
demanding royalties from the every Linux distributor.

It is, however, important to note that no "license" (as SCO understands
the term) can be applied to works distributed already because those who
acquired the software never agreed to a usage restriction.  I think Boies
will understand that (but, as was seen in the Gore case, his apparent
ethics shift with his clients).

Thinking more about the HURD every day.

This is scary.

I'm sure there are some lost sales because SuSE doesn't release ISO

would just free load off of the ISO images and never pay for a copy of 
the product after they've had a reasonable amount of time to test it. 

I know alot of people complain about there being no ISO images for 
OpenBSD as well. I can't say it's that big of deal not having ISO 
images for OpenBSD as they have an FTP install process that works very 
well if you have a decent speed net connection. By going the FTP 
install route alot of people get the latest version of OpenBSD for 
free. I know it bothers Theo de Raadt to see more people downloading 
OpenBSD via FTP than what are buying CDs to help support their work.

Since I actively use both OpenBSD and SuSE Linux I purchase CD sets of 
both OS's as each new version is released to try to do my little part 
to support the development work of both operating systems. The nice 
thing though is that if people don't want to pay there are free 
versions of Linux available to them.

installed Xandros. Without really knowing how, he was able to get it up

have to configure anything. Anyway, I was impressed that he was able to
do all that from almost no Linux experience, and get a fully useful
machine in one day. I haven't seen it in person yet, but he says the
desktop is nicer than his WinXP desktop. It sounded like a great
distribution for intruducing Windows folks to the Linux world.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Jan 23 15:57:03 2003
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Jan 23 15:57:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] SCO Looks For Intellectual-Property Claim On Linux
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301231528460.11946-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301231605530.29639-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Phil Tomson wrote:
> Well, is it patents or is it copyrights we're dealing with in this
> case? I suspect it's the latter and if that's the case the Congress
> and Supreme Court seem to agree that copyrights can be extended
> indefinately - they ignore the clause in the Constitution about
> copyrights being granted for 'limited times', or they redefining what
> 'limited' means.

While I appreciate your sentiment, your understanding or articulation of
the issue isn't quite accurate.

Congress and the courts are interpretting "limited times" to mean any
duration that has, at a given instant, a specific endpoint.

Strictly speaking, that is within the bounds of the law.

But they can move that endpoint any time they want as far out into the
future as they want so long as the span can still be described as finite.

It's like saying a race is of "limited distance" because you set the
endpoint to be at some specific place.  If you move that endpoint to
another specific location while the runners are running, you've still got
a "limited distance" race.  And if you keep doing that every time a runner
gets within a block of the finish line, you're still not breaking the
rules even though the runners never finish.

J.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 23 16:06:01 2003
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Thu Jan 23 16:06:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] On the topic of distributions
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301231405330.28750-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301231405330.28750-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <867kcv8lac.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Fedor> If you want to replace MiniFoo with SuperFoo, how do you
Fedor> uninstall all files from MiniFoo if the package author did not
Fedor> provide "make uninstall"?

Jeme> ./configure --prefix=/opt/foo <whatever>

Jeme> Then `find /opt/foo` and some little scripts to delete the files
Jeme> it creates.

Jeme> Or, as some do, install each package in /opt/package and you can
Jeme> just rm the tree.  (Or move it first and see if anything breaks
Jeme> -- remember, I'm not advocating this for systems where stability
Jeme> is paramount.)

Fedor> If WizBang1 used to install into /usr/bin and /usr/lib but
Fedor> WizBang2 now installs in /usr/local/bin and /usr/local/lib, how
Fedor> do you make sure all of WizBang1 files are deleted when you
Fedor> upgrade?

Jeme> That's what --prefix is for.

Just to echo, I do this.  I've got a whole constellation of packages
built from source tarballs in a /packages hierarchy.  I run Debian
underneath this to let it take care of maintaining packages that I
don't.  Autoconf makes it easy.

  tar -C /src -xzvf foo-x.y.z.tar.gz 
  cd /src/foo-x.y.z 
  ./configure --prefix=/packages/foo 
  make

When I install a new version, I move the old version aside, as in:

  cd /packages 
  mv foo foo-old 
  cd /src/foo-x.y.z 
  make install

or, using symlinks, something like

  make install
  cd /packages
  mv foo foo-x.y.z
  ln -s foo-x.y.z foo

Package uninstall is 'rm -rf'.  Putting the /packages/foo/bin in the
$PATH ahead of /usr/bin means that if I remove my source compiled
package, path lookup falls through to the Debian package.

It's pretty trivial to set your sources.list to point to a cdrom instead
of the network.

You can get complete snapshots of the Debian archive from Cheapbytes.
<URL: http://www.cheapbytes.com/ >

The 3.0 Binary x86 set is 8 discs and runs about $18.  I think that's
pretty reasonable for someone who doesn't have a broadband connection.  

Then you add just ONE network deb source to your sources.list:  
security.debian.org.  Then you only use the dial-up to get things that you
REALLY need to keep current.

> Not to mention that Debian is not the most user friendly version of
> Linux.

I guess I don't understand what that means.

Debian has MORE applications available for productivity, so that can't be
it.

Just about the same automatic and graphical configuration tools are
available, so that's not it, either.

Is it that the installation requires a person to understand a little bit
about how disk partitions correspond to devices which correspond to mount
points?  That's a fairly small niggle.  I mean, it's the only part of the
installation I had to explain to my friend who had never even installed
Windows before and now has a perfectly functional Debian system on her
desktop.

OK, so if "user friendly" means "encouraging ignorance by hiding every
possible functional element from the human being who is expected to use
and maintain the system", then yes.  Debian is terribly lacking in "user
friendliness".

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Thu Jan 23 19:25:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)
Date: Thu Jan 23 19:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <20030123080313.2d0b99a7.paul@pflnet.ws>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301231849220.7410-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>

On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Paul wrote:

> > Agreed. SuSE is excellent.
>
> Ya, but no ISOs since 7.3 -- what's up with that!?!?
>

SuSE is an excellent distribution.
In fact, I run SuSE on my personal workstation - at home - at work -
everywhere.  For this use, I greatly prefer it to every other distro
I have used.

However, I don't use SuSE as a base for building my own distros
in part because I don't fully understand their licenses.

SuSE includes yast and yast2 which are nice admin tools, but they
are not Open Source.  SuSE owns these and seems to use them to
restrict redistribution of their complete distribution.

Thus, SuSE has decided not to put ISOs of their distro on the web
and I don't think anyone else could legally put SuSE ISOs on the web
without removing a few programs (like yast).

Actually, this kind of goes back to the question of "how do you
make money on OpenSource Software".  Programmers all have to face
this problem.  And so do distribution makers.  SuSE's solution
has been to hold back little utilities like yast.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Thu Jan 23 21:15:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Jan 23 21:15:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] New monitor
In-Reply-To: <1043381856.6043.23.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301232104020.25743-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 23 Jan 2003, Jim Webb wrote:

> I'm going to upgrade my monitor from a 15" to a 19" monitor.  Will I
> need to go into the xf86 file and change the values there?  I've
> never changed hardware before on a linux box.

In your XF86Config file[1], the only changes you'll need to make are
to the 'HorizSync' and 'VertRefresh' settings. You ought to be able to
get those range settings right out of the manual or, lacking that,
from the manufacturer's web site.

Less needful, but perhaps more pleasing, are changes to the resolution 
setting. My hunch is that you'll be moving from either 800x600 or 
1024x768 on the 15" monitor to 1280x1024 on the 19". The directive
you'll want to edit is 'Modes,' which is nested in a Screen section, 
e.g.,

  Section "Screen"
    # stuff
    Subsection "Display"
      # stuff
      Modes  "1024x768" "800x600"
    EndSubsection
  EndSection

Make your preferred resolution the first Modes setting. That should do 
it.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] Try 'locate XF86Config' to find its location on your system. On 
    Red Hat boxes, it's in the /etc/X11 directory.

    Oh, and the actual name of your XF86Config file might be 
    XF86Config-4. If you tell us what distro (name, version) you're 
    using, someone is bound to know exactly which file you'll need to 
    edit.

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Thu Jan 23 21:25:03 2003
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Thu Jan 23 21:25:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301231849220.7410-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301231849220.7410-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com>
Message-ID: <200301232124.05132.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Thursday January 23, 2003 19:11, David Mandel wrote:
> On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Paul wrote:
> > > Agreed. SuSE is excellent.
> >
> > Ya, but no ISOs since 7.3 -- what's up with that!?!?
>
> SuSE is an excellent distribution.
> In fact, I run SuSE on my personal workstation - at home - at work -
> everywhere.  For this use, I greatly prefer it to every other distro
> I have used.

This has been my experience as well,  but then I haven't had the time to 
get my Gentoo partion in shape and move the data over...

However, my experience with 8.1 hasn't been so good.  For reasons unclear 
to me Mozilla insists on printing everything in A4 size.  Given that I 
don't have any A4 paper around, this makes it a little frustrating.  Other 
things print fine in Letter size.

> However, I don't use SuSE as a base for building my own distros
> in part because I don't fully understand their licenses.

I would second this. I'd never make my own distro off of SuSE.  

> SuSE includes yast and yast2 which are nice admin tools, but they
> are not Open Source.  SuSE owns these and seems to use them to
> restrict redistribution of their complete distribution.

It happens that there's a lot of history here.   The following was 
explained to me by one of the former SuSE Germany employees I once met.

SuSE was one of the very first companies founded to try to make money with 
Linux, somehow.  I think it was founded in 1992.  Shortly after founding, 
another German company got SuSE's floppy images (no CDROMs then) and made 
their own distro.  From what I'm told the first version was SuSE's 
floppies with the names changed.  The next few revs weren't much better.  
Apparently, it got so bad that SuSE was in danger of going out of business 
(marketing has never been their strong point).

So, I think SuSE's had a once-burned-twice-shy attitude toward this for a 
long time.  They had the CDs out there primarily to counter-act any spin 
from Red Hat, but gave it up.  Note that Red Hat's high end server 
packages are also not available for download as ISOs and contain non-free 
software.

Yast source is available (on the web site too I believe), but it is not GPL 
nor does it meet Debian's free software guidelines.

> Thus, SuSE has decided not to put ISOs of their distro on the web
> and I don't think anyone else could legally put SuSE ISOs on the web
> without removing a few programs (like yast).

I think you can, but you cannot charge for them I believe.  I'd have to 
read the license again.  The Yast stuff walks near to open source, but it 
definitely is not open source (or free in the speech sense).

> Actually, this kind of goes back to the question of "how do you
> make money on OpenSource Software".  Programmers all have to face
> this problem.  And so do distribution makers.  SuSE's solution
> has been to hold back little utilities like yast.

Given that Mandrake is a very popular disto and they are in bankruptcy 
while SuSE is probably only marginally more popular and they have a much, 
much larger company (which isn't entirely solvent either), SuSE might have 
the right idea.  SuSE claims to have more developers than Red Hat.  I'm 
not sure of the truth of that, but I suspect they are at least close in 
size.

All the arguments about making money on Linux seem to assume that you have 
to make money selling the thing.  A lot of companies make money on Linux 
by using it to sell their other products.  HP just announced that they 
sold $2B worth of goods and services due to Linux last year.  Not bad.  
Somehow this just doesn't catch the eye of the press or most people.   I 
think that is where the real money is in Linux and why the uptake is 
large, but quiet.

Linux "revenue" comes from two major sources right now:

1) savings over buying other OSes and use of cheaper hardware.

2) used to sell other products. "We'll sell you this nice high-end computer 
system and throw in the OS for free!"

Neither of those look as spectacular as Microsoft until you start adding up 
how much money this must represent.    But, a lot is in savings, which 
means the whole pie is shrinking.

When a market gets commoditized, it can shrink, sometimes dramatically.

Best,
Kyle

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Thu Jan 23 22:42:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Thu Jan 23 22:42:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <200301232124.05132.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301231849220.7410-100000@sco302.DavidMandel.com> <200301232124.05132.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <200301232240.45385.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Regarding the paper size problems and SuSE...Make sure in your printer 
setup in YaST2 that you've got the proper paper size specified for your 
printer configuration. I know I somehow got A4 in their somehow for my 
locally connected inkjet printer and had to go back and correct the 
paper size. I've never had any weirdness since I corrected the paper 
size problem and I'm printing from a variety of KDE programs, Netscape 
7.x and OpenOffice 1.x without any problems now.

About my only problem has been dealing with a remote BSD system for a 
laser printer. For some reason I have extra large top margin on every 
page I try to print remotely through CUPS. For this reason I had to 
fall back and use LPRng intead. CUPS worked very nice for my locally 
connected inkjet printer but I need access to both printers and CUPS 
and LPRng are mutually exclusive. YasT2 even goes so far as to remove 
one or the other depending what printer daemon/spooler you choose to 
use.

If only CUPS supported a non-filtered forwarding queue to a remote 
printer like LPRng supports. I know the remote printer handles the 
Postscript output of all the programs I use but for some reason CUPS 
insists on performing local filtering first before sending the remote 
printer the data.

Tony

> In your XF86Config file[1], the only changes you'll need to make are
> to the 'HorizSync' and 'VertRefresh' settings. You ought to be able to
> get those range settings right out of the manual or, lacking that,
> from the manufacturer's web site.

I'm running RH 8 and migrating from a Viewsonic 15" monitor to a Dell P990 19" 
monitor.  I see in the manual that they list under specifications a heading 
called deflection frequency of Horizontal of 3 - 96 kHz and a vertical
of 48 - 120 Hz.  In another section they list several different values
for horizontal and vertical e.g. 1280 x 1024 the horizontal range from
64 - 91 kHz and the vertical range from 60 - 85 Hz.

TIA,
Jim

> Less needful, but perhaps more pleasing, are changes to the resolution 
> setting. My hunch is that you'll be moving from either 800x600 or 
> 1024x768 on the 15" monitor to 1280x1024 on the 19". The directive
> you'll want to edit is 'Modes,' which is nested in a Screen section, 
> e.g.,
> 
>   Section "Screen"
>     # stuff
>     Subsection "Display"
>       # stuff
>       Modes  "1024x768" "800x600"
>     EndSubsection
>   EndSection
> 
> Make your preferred resolution the first Modes setting. That should do 
> it.
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
> 
> [1] Try 'locate XF86Config' to find its location on your system. On 
>     Red Hat boxes, it's in the /etc/X11 directory.
> 
>     Oh, and the actual name of your XF86Config file might be 
>     XF86Config-4. If you tell us what distro (name, version) you're 
>     using, someone is bound to know exactly which file you'll need to 
>     edit.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Jan 24 06:57:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Jan 24 06:57:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] New monitor
In-Reply-To: <1043410237.6033.47.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301240651080.25743-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 24 Jan 2003, Jim Webb wrote:

> > In your XF86Config file[1], the only changes you'll need to make
> > are to the 'HorizSync' and 'VertRefresh' settings. You ought to be
> > able to get those range settings right out of the manual or,
> > lacking that, from the manufacturer's web site.
> 
> I'm running RH 8 and migrating from a Viewsonic 15" monitor to a
> Dell P990 19"  monitor.

The P990 will serve you well. I had one at my last job, and it was 
great. Here are the settings that worked for me:

   HorizSync   30.0-107.0
   VertRefresh 48.0-120.0

I ran it in 32-bit/1280x1024 mode, though you'll want to see what 
modes are supported by your video card.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From derek at infotects.com  Fri Jan 24 09:46:02 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jan 24 09:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Locking up again.
In-Reply-To: <20030124014951.GD28183@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0301231625390.29639-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <861y338hfu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com> <20030124014951.GD28183@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1043430303.4008.271.camel@dereklinux>

On Thu, 2003-01-23 at 17:49, Rogan Creswick wrote:
> > For what it's worth, I ended up getting a SuperMicro
> > something-or-other, another dual P3 motherboard.  It was physically
> > bigger and had a different RAID chipset (Promise instead of HT (??)),
> 
> 
> Did / have you had any luck with the promise raid controller?

The promise RAID controller that I played with last weekend was not a
true RAID controller; it requires special drivers to work properly,
which makes it a software RAID.  However, I got linux to boot it up and
run as a non-RAID controller (even though the BIOS on the controller is
convinced it is mirroring the drives), then implemented linux style
software RAID.  At that point, I realized that I didn't need the Promise
controller that badly (the RAID access was very slow), and switched the
whole RAID setup to the normal IDE, and it works very well.

If you need more IDE channels, don't waste money on the "RAID
controllers", just get a regular controller, linux can't really tell the
difference.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree
>  
>

Subject: [PLUG] debian 3.0 adding xterm to fluxbox menu using debian menus
Message-ID: <1043389761.478.20.camel@laptop>

I am running debian "woody" and have recently install fluxbox as my
windowmanager (previously:blackbox), and I was trying to get a shortcut
to xterm on my right-click menu in the main section "Debian".  

I read the man pages for menus under debian and have tried creating a
.menu file in my home directory that contains the fluxbox menu, like
this:

?package(fluxbox):needs=fluxbox section="Debian" title="Xterm"
command="xterm -rv"

eof

After saving it, I've run update-menus -v and it appears to be
processing my ~/.menu directory, just like the man page said it would,
but I get no Xterm after quitting and restarting the X server.

I have also tried creating a ~/.menu-methods with the file fluxbox in
there that looks like this:

#!/bin/sh

cat > /home/bprew/out

eof

just like the man page said to do when you are trying to debug what
update-menus passes to menu-methods.  Running update-menus -v after that
shows it to be processing ~./menu-methods, but the file /home/bprew/out
does not exist.

So, this would lead me to conclude that nothing is getting passed to
menu-methods, but I cannot imagine this is the case as it has created
menus in the past when I have installed new debian packages and
continues to do it after my little tests when I install a new one.

So, this ultimately leads me to believe that I am mis-interpreting the
man pages and doing something wrong.  If anyone has any suggestions or

From mindglow at got-roots.com  Fri Jan 24 12:00:02 2003
From: mindglow at got-roots.com (Doug Davis)
Date: Fri Jan 24 12:00:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] debian 3.0 adding xterm to fluxbox menu using debian
	menus
In-Reply-To: <1043436407.2546.9.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>
References: <1043389761.478.20.camel@laptop>
	 <1043436407.2546.9.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>
Message-ID: <1043438565.2534.14.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>

> On Fri, 2003-01-24 at 10:59, Benjamin Prew wrote:
> > I am running debian "woody" and have recently install fluxbox as my
> > windowmanager (previously:blackbox), and I was trying to get a shortcut
> > to xterm on my right-click menu in the main section "Debian".  
> > 
Why don't you just edit the menu file by hand? Its a lot less
complicated. With my fluxbox 0.1.14 install is under ~.fluxbox/menu.
With your favorite editor, add the following line under the submenu that
you wish:

	[exec] (xterm) {xterm -rv}

[exec] = executable command
(*)= Title
{*}= Command

for more info see: 
http://fluxbox.sourceforge.net/docbook/en/html/c653.html

-- 
Doug Davis <mindglow at got-roots.com>




From derek at infotects.com  Fri Jan 24 12:19:02 2003
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Jan 24 12:19:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] debian 3.0 adding xterm to fluxbox menu using debian
	menus
In-Reply-To: <1043389761.478.20.camel@laptop>
References: <1043389761.478.20.camel@laptop>
Message-ID: <1043439497.4008.327.camel@dereklinux>

On Fri, 2003-01-24 at 10:59, Benjamin Prew wrote:
> I am running debian "woody" and have recently install fluxbox as my
> windowmanager (previously:blackbox), and I was trying to get a shortcut
> to xterm on my right-click menu in the main section "Debian". 

If it is installed, it should have a menu entry under "Debian/Xshell". 
Look in /usr/lib/menu, all default menu entries are there and I've had
great success with adding new entries there (don't forget to run
"update-menus" after you add the new listings).

Here is what I did after installing OpenOffice:

?package(local.openoffice):needs=X11 section=Apps/Tools title="OpenOffice" command="~/OpenOffice.org641/soffice"
>  
> 
> I read the man pages for menus under debian and have tried creating a
> .menu file in my home directory that contains the fluxbox menu, like
> this:
> 
> ?package(fluxbox):needs=fluxbox section="Debian" title="Xterm"
> command="xterm -rv"

There is actually no Debian "section".  I think the window manager may
consider everything in /usr/lib/menu to be "Debian menus". I haven't run
fluxbox, so I don't know what it does with menus, though.

HTH

Derek Loree

Is this not the default behavior of cron?  It sends any stderr output to
the job owner via system mail.

You might want to just wrap the whole thing up so the error falls through
and maybe includes an echo to stderr in the event of failure to make sure
cron has SOMETHING to mail.

> What I tried was to modify my ping-the-servers script, which has lines
> in it like this (this is just one line):
> 
> ping -c 3 www.infotects.com >> ${LOGFILE} || echo "The web server is
> down, fix it now!" | mail -s "Web server is down" derek at infotects.com

See, there's where I'm confused.  I'm using vixie cron and dcron and they
both just send mail all on their own if the job exits with an error.

> This sends me an email only if the ping command fails (that is what
> the double pipe does, it is a command level OR).  But in my copy
> script, I have (again just one line):
> 
> cp -Rp /home/test/* /home/test2 || echo "copy failed, better fix it" |
> mail -s "Copy Failed" derek at infotects.com
>
> Which sends me an email even when the copy is successful!

This works just fine for me.  Perhaps you're not using the same shell?!?

From siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org  Sat Jan 25 09:43:02 2003
From: siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org (L. Siobhan Elliott)
Date: Sat Jan 25 09:43:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] help! attachment hell
In-Reply-To: <20030125074352.Z20224@defiant.ncplus.net>
References: <20030125074352.Z20224@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <20030125174252.GA5602@sdf.lonestar.org>

On Sat, Jan 25, 2003 at 07:43:52AM -0800, Bruce Kingsland wrote:
> My sister is still living in the darkside of computing, and just got
> herself a brand new 'latest and greatest' system all set up. Now, my
> email that is sent with gpg signatures (which she used to get just
> fine) shows up with only a subject line and an attachment. She deletes
> all messages with attachments - the virus thing.
> 
> Any ideas how I can direct her to fix this problem, short of me
> sending my email in the clear?

Outlook Express, which she is probably using does not support
handling PGP/mime signatures properly (which mutt, your mua, creates
by default when you sign your mail).  For all its other flaws,
Outlook proper does have better mime support and so it will display
such signed mails properly, that may have been the mailer she was
using before. She can either use a mail client that supports PGP/mime
(most Windoze clients don't -- standards, what's that? =( )... or
if she doesn't want to switch, you could clear-sign your emails to
her. What I have in my .muttrc for sending signed mail to OE users
is:

macro compose S "Fgpg -a --clearsign -u <MY KEY ID>"

So from mutt, in the compose window I just hit 'S' to clear-sign
the mail, making it readable in OE... but which is kind of a pain
to do :/... since you'll have to turn off autosigning, if you have
it enabled, for these 'special cases'.

Kind regards,
-- 
L. Siobhan Elliott
Mail: siobhan at sdf.lonestar.org (finger me for my public key)
AIM: chordchemist999

From dgc at easystreet.com  Sat Jan 25 11:20:02 2003
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Sat Jan 25 11:20:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] A new approach to pass mail filters
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301250901110.13662-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301250901110.13662-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1043522381.5780.13.camel@merrivale.dhs.org>

There was a paper on this and another new technique at the recent MIT
spam conference.  If I understand correctly, what's happening below is
that the spammer's program is automatically inserting random html
between words to try to confuse body filters.

That paper said there is also another spammer tool around that uses html
tables to try to ensure that at no point two letters of the same word 
adjacent to each other in the raw message body.

Assuming you can't just arbitrarily reject messages with html comments,
a message body preprocessor that eliminates html comments before any
filtering happens should be feasible.  Or have the body filtering system
really understand html.

Protecting against the table method sounds harder.  Maybe you'd need an
ascii message body html renderer?

dgc

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Jan 25 22:38:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Jan 25 22:38:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] gaim-applet and redhat 8
In-Reply-To: <1043561655.1514.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1043561655.1514.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200301252241.32712.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 25 January 2003 10:14 pm, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I just upgraded my machine to RedHat 8.0 and am having trouble getting
> my gaim-applet to install.  I keep getting this error:
> libpanel_applet.so.0 is needed by gaim-applet-0.59.8-1
>
> What is this and why am I getting this error (obviously
> libpanel_applet.so.0 is not installed, but why not)?
>
> Any help will be greatly appreciated.  I don't relish the thought of
> having to keep gaim open in only one terminal.

Well, a quick Google search indicates that it is part of gnome-core 1.4. RH8 
uses Gnome 2. Try to find a version of gaim-applet built for Gnome 2. If 
there isn't one, do a search on your system to see if any version of 
libpanel_applet.so is installed. If there is a newer version, make a 
libpanel_applet.so.0 soft link to it, and see if that fixes things.

If not, it may be possible to copy libpanel_applet.so.0 to your system, if you 
can find it separately. I don't think you want to install gnome-core 1.4. I 
don't know for certain, but I suspect it will mess up your Gnome 2 
installation.

> libpanel_applet.so.0 is not installed, but why not)?

Based on the other responses, I'd recommend seeing if you can get a
gaim-applit source RPM, (the one that's .src.rpm) and rebuild it with
rpm -ba x.src.rpm) and install the x.i386.rpm that it builds.  It might
work, because it will link with the new libpanel in GNOME2.  (It might
fail because the API changes sufficiently between the GNOME 1.4 and 2.)

Looks like your hostname is screwed up.  Once you get logged in, type:
hostname.  If it comes back with the a0-00-9e-xxxxxxx, then retype
hostname <name of system>.  Check your host file in /etc.  Is your
hostname and IP address there?  If you are with attbi, then they are
giving you that hostname when you connect with their DHCP settings. 
Others can give you advice using attbi.com settings.

Ken

Essentials.

differently, and I don't see any "conflict" specific rpm flags that

Any more ideas?

Oh bloody (the letter that comes after K)!  This works:

rpm -vv -U --force --nodeps TiMidity++-2.11.3-1mdk.i586.rpm timidity-instruments-1.0-15mdk.noarch.rpm

The command line _IS_ order dependent.  I guess that might make sense 
if one could turn force/deps on and off between package names listed 
on the command line.

BTW, I should have added that the HTTP response your Apache server sent back
(405) is "Method Not Allowed" - so you have nothing to fear. See...

http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/httpclient/api/org/apache/commons/httpclient/HttpStatus.html

...for a complete listing of response codes.

Sandy

My daughter's ifconfig shows;

eth0  Link encap:ethernet  HWaddr 00:A0:C9:74:9E:51
inet addr:12:224:187:4     Bcast:255:255:255:255
Mask:255:255:255:0   blah, blah, blah
RX packets:2872       TX packets:108 

all with 0 errors.

Her lo is Linkencap:Local loopback

From svanhoosen at yahoo.com  Mon Jan 27 19:25:02 2003
From: svanhoosen at yahoo.com (Scott Van Hoosen)
Date: Mon Jan 27 19:25:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re:RH 8 install goof
In-Reply-To: <1043723958.3285.16.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <20030128032337.68205.qmail@web40812.mail.yahoo.com>

If her IP address is set statically, then she simply
might not be connected. If she's set with DHCP and
acquiring an IP address but still can't ping, then
she's connected, but might be filtering TCP packets. I
believe DHCP uses UDP packets, so under those
circumstances, she could be acquiring an address but
not be able to ping. Check her firewall settings.

-Scott

From mindglow at got-roots.com  Tue Jan 28 09:45:03 2003
From: mindglow at got-roots.com (Doug Davis)
Date: Tue Jan 28 09:45:03 2003
Subject: [PLUG] More RH8 Trouble
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301280923270.1994-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301280923270.1994-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1043776098.23291.44.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>

On Tue, 2003-01-28 at 09:26, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On 28 Jan 2003, Derek Loree wrote:
> 
> > Debian. It isn't perfect, but at least it asks if you want to hose your
> > config files.
> 
>   Actually, so did Red Hat. From 4.0 (or 4.1, I forget which was the first I
> installed) through 6.2 I was told either that the old config file was being
> saved as *.sav or that the new one was placed on the hard drive as *.rpmnew.
> Never before did the installer behave as it did then.
I think the issue is that you are doing a major upgrade that also
includes upgrading the application itself as well in a lot of cases. The
config files have often changed substantially and its not possible to
use the old file. Also, the versions of libraries and things that the
application is dependent on get upgraded as well causing a potential
break in the application. Even if you compiled it yourself, these things
are likely to happen since the act of compiling from source utilizes the
existing libraries on you system.

Just my $0.02.
-- 
Doug Davis <mindglow at got-roots.com>

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jan 28 10:23:01 2003
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Jan 28 10:23:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] More RH8 Trouble
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301280613100.1369-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <1043727121.980.7.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <5.2.0.9.0.20030128094404.01986dd0@localhost>

At 06:17 AM 1/28/2003 -0800, you wrote:
>   To satisfy my curiosity, please tell me why any linux OS upgrade
>(regardless of distribution) should break installed -- end user -- software?

As you pointed out, incompatible library versions is the first thing I 
think about.

>   In my naivety I believe that if I install all my software in /usr/local or
>/opt then config files should be left untouched by the OS upgrade and only
>incompatible library versions would cause problems if the old versions are
>removed.

In theory, yes. But it all depends on where the program is storing said 
config files. Yes, it should be /opt/etc or /usr/local/etc, but sometimes 
they still store this stuff in /etc. This is also why a full backup is 
always recommended prior to any changes to your system. Given the vast 
complexity of any system, and the fact that it's impossible for a 
programmer to account for ALL contingencies, a backup becomes a necessity. 
On the surface, it appears that all they need to do is ignore /opt and 
/usr/local, but there may be cases where that's not possible.

>   I, too, had major problems with config files being overwritten without my
>knowledge or permission when I upgraded from RH 6.2 to 7.3. Am I wrong in
>thinking that this shouldn't happen? What am I missing here?

Well, if the package manager isn't used to install the "user" software, 
then it's not going to know about the package during the upgrade. Very 
rarely do I install things without the package manager. Even a tarball of 
source can be compiled into an RPM for installation. It's a little more 
work, but it saves in the long run when you upgrade.

Just my thoughts... YMMV and TIMTOWTDI


Russ Johnson
Dimension 7/Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

"Life does not have to be perfect to be wonderful." - Annette Funicello

I don't think I'd call a Red Hat .2 or .3 release "bleeding edge".  In
the year+ since the .0 was released, they get pretty stable.  I don't
think I'd call Debian's releases "stable" either--I'd call them
obsolete.  I mean, if you want that level of "stability", you could go
farther and install from this Slackware 3.0 CD I have from the Nov 1995
InfoMagic CD-ROM.  Ships with a good, solid 1.2.13 kernel.

One of the first things you should always do when upgrading is to look
at the {/root,/tmp}/upgrade.log and find out what config files were
renamed.

Wil

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Jan 28 14:56:01 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)

Subject: [PLUG] Gnome Panel Menus
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301281447330.19024-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

I've spent quite a bit of time looking but I can't find a decent anwser or 
pointer.  Possibly I've got the wrong terms.
   I just installed RHL 8.0 from a downloaded set of ISOs.  No upgrade
since I had a new SCSI hard drive and contoller and a mostly stock
Workstation configuration.  Back in my RHL 7.x days I had my desktop
pretty much like I wanted it and I did save all the .desktop files for use
later.  The problem is I can't figure out how to get a drop-down (pop-up)
menu on the panel likeI had before.  There is nothing I can find at the
Gnome site or the on-machine help that explains how.
   On the old system I had a directory in ~/.gnome/apps/ called Connect 
and it had subdirectories which had .desktop files.  Thinking I'd be 
clever I copied the Connect directory in to .gnome/apps/ (and 
.gnome2/apps/ to be sure) but no joy.  Any ideas or pointers to how to do 
this?

This does bring up one of my really big conplaints about the Linux
desktop.  There seems to be a race to have the 'coolest' looking desktop
but no real effort to make it personally functional.  Have you noticed it
is very difficult to really customise.
   On the up side I didn't have to fiddle with the /etc/X11/ stuff to get
ssh-agent running - it is.  I just open a window and do a ssh-add and can
securely connect to the world with minimal hassle.

From sandy at herring.org  Tue Jan 28 15:52:01 2003
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Tue Jan 28 15:52:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Gnome Panel Menus
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301281447330.19024-100000@main.cyber-office.net>; from raanders@acm.org on Tue, Jan 28, 2003 at 03:12:47PM -0800
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301281447330.19024-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <20030128155151.A31953@kippered.herring.org>

    Working With Panels
    1.7.2. To Add a Drawer to a Panel

    From any menu

    You can add a menu as a drawer object to a panel. To add a menu as a
    drawer to a panel, open the menu from the panel. Right-click on any
    launcher in the menu, then choose Entire menu->Add this as drawer to
    panel.

Sandy

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Jan 28 17:46:02 2003
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue Jan 28 17:46:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how do I run a program without having to maintain a remote terminal?
In-Reply-To: <XVRQ08A7B0XTE9C9JHUT5Z5YC9DAGF21.3e372c6f@mike>
References: <XVRQ08A7B0XTE9C9JHUT5Z5YC9DAGF21.3e372c6f@mike>
Message-ID: <20030129014451.GA3144@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>

$ (program-name&)

the ()'s detach this process from it's parent (the terminal), the &
makes it run in the background. You should be able to do that, then
logout.

Another option is to use screen, then you can re-attach a terminal to
the process at same point. (screen -r)

ie:

$ screen <program>

C-ad detaches the current screen sesion, then logout.

$ screen -r # reattaches to this terminal, so you can interact
            # with the program again.

-Rogan

From shahms at shahms.com  Tue Jan 28 17:47:01 2003
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms E. King)
Date: Tue Jan 28 17:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] how do I run a program without having to maintain a
	remote terminal?
In-Reply-To: <XVRQ08A7B0XTE9C9JHUT5Z5YC9DAGF21.3e372c6f@mike>
References: <XVRQ08A7B0XTE9C9JHUT5Z5YC9DAGF21.3e372c6f@mike>
Message-ID: <1043804888.3988.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>

well, assuming you're using ssh to connect, (which, of course, you are
;-)), simply append the command you want to execute to the ssh command
line. Since it's an X app, you probably want ssh to background itself,
so you'd launch a remote xterm, for example, like:

$ ssh -f host xterm

or more specifically:
$ ssh -f user at host /usr/X11R6/bin/xterm

-- 
Shahms E. King <shahms at shahms.com>

nohup setiatihome&

Redhat INCREASED to 6 CDs with the 7.3 release. 3 binaries, 2 source, and 1 
doc.

7.0 had 2 binaries, one source, and one doc, and then the powertools CD.

Redhat 6.2 had one binary CD, one source, one doc and then the powertools CD.

The powertools CD had lots of stuff on it, but it was both binaries and 
source for that, in one CD.

SuSE currently ships 6 CD and one DVD that contains the same as the 6 CDs. 
It's still binaries, source and docs, so it's about the same.

As far as I know, none of the distributions will support the third part 
apps they include with their distribution. Redhat has always stated that 
your support is for "Installation only". Caldera and SuSE say the same 
thing. I know, as I've written both of them. At one point, the NIS stuff 
shipped with SuSE didn't play well with Redhat, but they wouldn't support 
it, as they didn't write it, and it DID install correctly.

OK, I don't want to leave the wrong impression here. I doubt that any of the 
distros offer support for every weirdo app that comes down the pipe. Sometime 
back I asked them about the problems with Abiword and Gnumeric, and a few 
other issues, and this was the response:

"To preface, in Red Hat Linux 8.0 we take the best of breed applications 
and spend
resources to refine that specific set.  Open Office and Mozilla are 
perfect examples.  Abiword and Gnumeric are examples of applications 
that are included as "extras" in our menus whereas Open Office is really 
our preferred office application."

This is where being on the bleeding edge left some apps behind; Abiword and 
Gnumeric do not yet support Unicode. Lots of other apps don't either. The fix 
was reported in the release notes. The release notes are quite comprehensive; 
combine them with the bug tracker and the user list, and you ought to be able 
to figure most things out. This is the price of using a bleeding-edge 
distribution. 

For users who just want things to work, and have less hassle, previous 
versions of Red Hat are still available. 7.3 is solid.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jan 29 07:43:01 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jan 29 07:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Post-installation USB, er, installation
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301290721110.5850-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

One of the systems I support, a generic Dell box running Red Hat 8.0, 
wasn't initially configured with any USB devices. Then its user got 
one of those nifty 64MB NexDisk USB storage devices that's about the 
size of a rabbit's foot.

It took me a while to figure out how to get Red Hat to work and play 
with USB hardware when it wasn't part of the initial installation. So, 
in case anyone's wondering, here's the recipe, no reboots required:

  # first, figure out whether you've got an ohci or a uhci usb 
  # controller
  modprobe usbcore
  modprobe usb-uhci
  # no error messages means you've probably got a uhci device,
  # though it's worth checking dmesg just to make sure. if not,
  # see if the ohci stuff will work:
  modprobe usb-ohci

  # once you've got that down then add it to your modules config
  # so that red hat's init scripts will load the usb stuff 
  # automatically at next boot time
  cat 'alias usb-controller usb-uhci' >> /etc/modules.conf
  # or, if you've got an ohci controller
  cat 'alias usb-controller usb-ohci' >> /etc/modules.conf

  # now mount the usbdevfs
  mount -t usbdevfs usbdevfs /proc/bus/usb

  # take a look at the USB world you've inherited...
  lsusb

Then connect the USB device and let /sbin/hotplug do its thing.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed Jan 29 08:50:02 2003
From: dmandel at pdxLinux.org (David Mandel)

Subject: [PLUG] Rat off a Sinking Ship?
In-Reply-To: <20030124010226.GA457@nellump.net>

On Thu, 23 Jan 2003, Paul Mullen wrote:

>
> I'm surprised no one is mentioning Knoppix. It's meant to be a
> CD-ROM-based distro, but it does have a handy little script on it that
> make copying the contents of the CD over to a HDD a snap. I installed
> Knoppix on a "new" Celeron 700 system a few weeks back, and it was by
> far the easiest install I've ever done (even easier than that "other"
> OS). Everything was auto-detected by the boot scripts. No problemo. Of
> course, it *is* based on Debian, and that seems to give some PLUG
> members absolute fits. <que foreboding music here>
>

I thought about mentioning Knoppix, but didn't because:

          -  I wanted to keep my list short
          -  Altho Knoppix works fine from a hard disk, it was intended
             to run off of a CD.  Because of this, I classify it as
             a speciality distro rather than a general purpose distro.
             On the other hand, I would certainly use certain Knoppix
             elements if I designed and built another distribution
             myself.  Indeed, I consider using Knoppix as the primary
             base distribution and I wouldn't normally consider using
             a speciality distribution for this.  Well, except for the
             distro building distributions.
          -  The software portion of the Knoppix distro seems very
             mature, but supporting items such as documention is
             not yet mature.  (Yes, I know one can generally use any
             Linux/Unix documentation, especially Debian docs; but
             still ...)

The bottom line is that I like Knoppix and I'm using it more and more;
but I still use SuSE on my desktop and based most of my servers on
RedHat.
