From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Wed Jan 29 09:51:01 2003
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Wed Jan 29 09:51:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging help?
Message-ID: <E18dwMF-000447-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Good morning.
I think, what I have, is a failure to read a man page properly.

I'm running iptables on a redhat box.
IPTables:iptables v1.2.6a
RedHat: 8.0 (with most of the current updates, nothing related to iptables or
syslogd).

In my firewall script is this line:

--> /sbin/iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport 1434 -j LOG

which results in this line from "# iptables -L"

--> LOG udp -- anywhere anywhere udp dpt:ms-sql-m LOG level warning

Which "looks" right. Except I can't find any messages in any of my log files
related to it, which seems wrong at this point.  I haven't tried something more
general. 

I'm assuming that those messages will go to /var/log/messages- but there are no
"warning" level lines in /etc/syslogd.conf, so I don't know for sure where those
logging messages will go.  
Here are my questions;

What is the syslog "facility" for iptables? So I could control the syslog messages?

How do I use "--log-level info" in my iptables rule? If I try to change the
logging level from "warning" to "info," (because of the *.info line in
syslogd.conf), when I run the firewall script I get "unknown arg --log-level".

Any help would be appreciated, of course :)

-Russ



From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Jan 29 10:17:02 2003
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Jan 29 10:17:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging help?
In-Reply-To: <E18dwMF-000447-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301291013280.5850-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 29 Jan 2003 gilmanhunt at attbi.com wrote:

> In my firewall script is this line:
> 
> --> /sbin/iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport 1434 -j LOG
> 
> which results in this line from "# iptables -L"
> 
> --> LOG udp -- anywhere anywhere udp dpt:ms-sql-m LOG level warning

The section of the iptables(8) man page that deals with the 
--log-level option is fairly cryptic. Try this

  /sbin/iptables -A INPUT -p udp --dport 1434 -j LOG --log-level INFO

Also, you may need to load the logging module manually: 

  modprobe ipt_LOG

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>




From gilmanhunt at attbi.com  Wed Jan 29 11:28:01 2003
From: gilmanhunt at attbi.com (gilmanhunt at attbi.com)
Date: Wed Jan 29 11:28:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] iptables logging help?
Message-ID: <E18dxrd-0004vF-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

I didn't have the logging module loaded- that's the first thing. Looks like
that's going to fix my (these) problems. Thanks Paul!

should work equally.

Others here may have better advice

From robbert at vafam.com  Wed Jan 29 16:22:01 2003
From: robbert at vafam.com (robbert at vafam.com)
Date: Wed Jan 29 16:22:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
Message-ID: <104388607201@leo.hosting4u.net>

I learned PHP last year after only having experience with Visual Basic and HTML.  It took me a short period of time using Wrox's Beginning PHP 4.  I recommend this book and the friends I've lent it to have the same rave reviews as I do (in fact I'm having trouble retrieving it from the friend who has it now because he loves it so much). It won't teach a lot on object oriented programming, but is a great intro to such elementary topics as variables, looping, file manipulation and database connectivity.

Robbert van Andel

> And so, suspecting that writing little programs that can be run on the
> web would be more fun than doing exercises from K&R, I've been
> thinking of using PHP to introduce these two to programming.
> 
> Does this strike anyone as an unusually good, or stupid, idea?

Programming purists would have a cow over the idea. It isn't strongly
typed, it isn't OO, etc. They would probably recommend something like Java,
Objective C, or <insert your favorite LISP variant here>.

On the good side, it's a lot better than the HP or Microsoft BASIC many of
us cut our teeth on. It's easy to get started. They can learn the theory
after they've been hooked.

Dan

> web would be more fun than doing exercises from K&R, I've been
> thinking of using PHP to introduce these two to programming.
> 
> Does this strike anyone as an unusually good, or stupid, idea?

Does she want to learn how to program or learn how to program correctly.

PHP will not teach proper structure for writing good programs.  (Due to 
the stateless nature of HTTP.)

It may give her more imediate gratification, but be more harmful in the 
long run if those bad habits become ingrained.

c or Java or something more vaguely procedural would be better.

If she really wants to learn programming, teach her assembly language.

From raanders at acm.org  Wed Jan 29 16:36:02 2003
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Wed Jan 29 16:36:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <20030129160245.E1591@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301291634240.5568-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Wed, 29 Jan 2003, Eric House wrote:

> And so, suspecting that writing little programs that can be run on the
> web would be more fun than doing exercises from K&R, I've been
> thinking of using PHP to introduce these two to programming.
> 
> Does this strike anyone as an unusually good, or stupid, idea?

There is the issue of not only trying to learn to program they are also
probably having to learn HTML.  The reason I dislike VisualBASIC (which
the local college uses) so much in a teaching atmosphere.  How do you
teach the basic concepts of programming when you're fighting the GUI.  
(If you ever look at VB you'll notice it doesn't even follow the Windows
standard layout/behavior.)

<soapbox>
Go for the command line stuff first.  Maybe not as cute as a graphical
presentation but the student can concentrate on programming first then
play with the presentation later.  And my personal favorite is Perl.  
This is based on learning using BASIC, followed by FORTRAN, back to BASIC,
C, (god forbid but I started understand some old COBOL code I was
debugging), C++, Perl, Tcl, Perl, shell (bash), Perl.  And did I mention
Perl?  :-)  Then one day I was encouraged (required) to teach VisualBASIC.  
I spent more time in the class room trying to get the code window 
reopened on students computers then getting them to enter code.
</soapbox>


Rod
-- 
  "Open Source Software - Sometimes you get more than you paid for..."

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Jan 29 17:08:01 2003
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] What flavor?

On Mon, 2003-01-27 at 23:14, The Kerstings wrote:
> I am a complete Linux novice but can find my way around a DOS box
> pretty well.
>  
> Can someone suggest a flavor of Linux that will run with GUI on my old
> P75 machine?  I understand that RH 8 wants a 200 MHz machine.....

How much RAM?  It'll be a tight squeeze if you have less than 64MB... a
very tight squeeze if you're at 32MB, and maybe impossible if you're at
16 or 8MB of RAM (think command line only).

I would suggest trying Slackware with the 3.3.6 X server from the extras
directory.  That will be a little bit difficult to set up, though, if
you are un-familiar with Linux at all.  Google is your friend, though.

Debian, if they still have a 3.3.6 server available, would probably be
almost as fast.

Other than that, perhaps you would have luck with a super-old distro....

But, FWIW, there are a ton more command-line apps for Linux that are so
much more powerful than you get with DOS.  As a former DOS power user
myself, I was shocked at how powerful bash was by itself.  :-)

Rob

On Mon, 27 Jan 2003, The Kerstings wrote:

> I am a complete Linux novice but can find my way around a DOS box pretty well.
> 
> Can someone suggest a flavor of Linux that will run with GUI on my old P75 machine?  I understand that RH 8 wants a 200 MHz machine.....

You are not going to find many implementations of Linux that will run a 
GUI well on a P75. Depends on how much memory you have and what kind of 
video card.

EvilWM or FVWM might run on something that slow.  (As long as you avoid 
Gnome and KDE apps.)  

A machine like that will work well as a mil server or something that does 
not need a GUI, but not very well for anything GUI related.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Wed Jan 29 17:47:01 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Wed Jan 29 17:47:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <3861.192.168.1.251.1043886955.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <20030129160245.E1591@tpol.peak.org> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0301291634240.5568-100000@main.cyber-office.net> <3861.192.168.1.251.1043886955.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <200301291746.05629.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I'm not sure Pascal is even taught anymore in any college course. Pascal 
was the second programming language I learned after cutting my teeth on 
BASIC. As I recall I saw the computer science department at the college 
I attended dropped their Pascal course offerings in favor of C. I felt 
this was a mistake as I had the "horror" of maintaining C code from 
someone that had only learned BASIC. 

I still remember the pain of one program that my supervisor wrote at my 
first programming job. He wrote a program that among other programming 
horrors contained a huge set of if/else if statements that spanned 54 
pages of green bar paper. My supervisor managed to accidently delete a 
curly brace in the wrong place. The C compiler was easily confused in 
those days and couldn't report the actual line number the syntax error 
occurred on.

My supervisor soon tired of his task to try to fix this problem so he 
gave up and assigned the problem to me. I used our company's huge 
conference room and laid the print out on the floor over an area of 
20-30 feet. I went through the printout with a red felt pen drawing 
brackets to show where the curly brackets matched. In the end I found 
where a curly bracket had been accidently removed and so I added it 
back and all was well.

I never saw anyone that had learned to program in Pascal first write 
this sort of crap code but it seemed to be common with some C 
programmers that came from a BASIC-only background. Again this was many 
years ago when most programmers didn't even know what the C programming 
language was since COBOL, BASIC and/or Pascal were probably the most 
commonly used high-level programming languages at the time.

Tony

From alex at daniloff.com  Wed Jan 29 19:19:01 2003
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)
Date: Wed Jan 29 19:19:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <20030129160245.E1591@tpol.peak.org>
References: <20030129160245.E1591@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <03012919192900.06093@gate>

Eric,
I've tried to experiment with PHP for web applications, and to me it looks 
like stripped down and bastardized Perl. 
So far, I found Perl more superior to PHP. 
It's easy to learn and very powerful in almost every aspect language.
Especially, if you're writing Web applications using Perl CGI.pm module 
and run them in FCGI mode on Apache. 
The performance and speed of such approach blows away all these
Java scripts, ASP's,SSI's and PHP altogether.

Here are the links for your reference on the performance of Perl in FCGI mode:
http://istlab.dmst.aueb.gr/~george/articles/dynweb/present/siframes.html
http://www.dmst.aueb.gr/dds/pubs/conf/2002-SANE-DynCont/ html/dyncont.pdf 

Alex

From felix.1 at canids.net  Wed Jan 29 19:33:01 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Wed Jan 29 19:33:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <200301291746.05629.aschlemm@attbi.com> on Wed, 29 Jan 2003 17:46:05 PST.

Anthony Schlemmer <aschlemm at attbi.com>:
> I never saw anyone that had learned to program in Pascal first write 
> this sort of crap code but it seemed to be common with some C 
> programmers that came from a BASIC-only background.

I think this happens when people learn programming in
isolation, without spending much time reading other programs
or having other people read their programs.  they end up
with the delusion that programming is about telling the
computer what to do.

programming is about telling other people what you want the
computer to do.  if you get that right, I don't think the
language you start with matters that much.

	 <1043897677.995.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1043899110.980.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I found a partial solution, in case anyone is interesting.  Apparently
it's an issue with firewire.  I have firewire pci card sitting in my
computer for use with my Windows Partition (unfortunately, I cannot get
it to work with Linux).  Any the fix is:

Add the following to line 67 of /usr/share/hwbrowser/DeviceList.py :

kudzu.CLASS_FIREWIRE : _("Firewire"),

The fix was found at 

http://www.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=74956

I'm still getting many errors related to the gnome-canvas-path-def.c
file, but at least the hardware browser works.

Robbert

> I'm a "professional" C/C++/Java programmer who dabbles in perl cgi

>

> thinking of using PHP to introduce these two to programming.
>

> Any suggestions on PHP books that might be suitable for all of us?  Or

> exercises for the "class"?

Is PHP really a programming language, I mean I hear it's good for web
apps, but what about stand alon projects? ;-)

OK, I'll throw my favorite programming language in the mix (why not?
everybody else is doing it :) - I've programmed in C/C++, Java, Perl, some
Tcl (yuk!) I even tried out Python one afternoon but didn't like that
indentation was part of syntax...  but my favorite for the last couple of
years is Ruby.

The best way to quickly describe Ruby is that it's SmallTalk meets Perl.
The syntax is clean and expressive and the object oriented features in
addition to things like iterators are very consistently used in all of the
standard libraries.

Give it a look:
http://www.ruby-lang.org
You can find the book "Programming Ruby" online, free at:
http://rubycentral.com

Phil




From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Wed Jan 29 20:26:01 2003
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Wed Jan 29 20:26:01 2003

On Wednesday 29 January 2003 08:01 pm, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
>  The damn firewall will NOT go below High no matter how I try
> to set it lower using redhat config and the GUI supplied in the distro.
> I even reinstalled and specified NO firewall and was ignored.

The RH8 gui firewall utility uses iptables, edit iptables directly and you 
should be fine. 

On older red hats the gui firewall tool configured ipchains, which led to some 
rude surprises and confusion when you set up iptables. Those 'dangit, I know 
I did it right, what the heck is wrong!' moments, only in more colorful 
language. Then the d'oh moment, remembering lokkit uses ipchains, which was 
gumming up the works. Life on the edge....

On Wed, 2003-01-29 at 07:57, alan wrote:
> PHP will not teach proper structure for writing good programs.  (Due to 
> the stateless nature of HTTP.)

PHP won't "teach" proper structure because it isn't a bondage and
discipline language, rather than because it's used for stateless web
stuff.  B&D languages don't teach it either, they force it down your
throat.  Also, PHP has applications outside of the web, I use PHP for
quite a bit of general scripting in addition to web applications.

I found that PHP was easy to learn, but then I know a fair number of
languages already.

But I do think PHP would be an excellent language to get somebody "into"
programming, it's a pretty tactile experience to type something in an
editor and then hit reload in your browser and see the changes.

Besides the online documentation, books that I think are good for
beginners are "Core PHP Programming" by Leon Atkinson and "PHP
Developers Cookbook" by Sterling Hughes - neither will take you very
far, but they're handy to get started with.

--Brent

From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 30 11:43:01 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu Jan 30 11:43:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <200301301638.h0UGcGB05545@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301301122240.28041-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>



On Thu, 30 Jan 2003, Felix Lee wrote:

> Steven Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>:
> > So are you saying is that PHP and other Apache/DHTML environments (perhaps
> > Apache::Asp or Cold Fusion) will teach better habits?
>
> no.  I already said earlier in the thread that I don't think
> first language matters much.  I'm fond of Scheme, but I
> don't think it will work for everyone.  Smalltalk and Logo
> are also fun choices.

Well, the first language can certainly matter since it will give the
learner certain impressions about the practice of programming that might
be hard to change later.  Way back in the mid 70's I learned BASIC in
highschool and it probably took me a decade to completely unlearn some of
the bad habits that are just inherant in BASIC.

Also, you don't want a language that gets in your way when you're teaching
non-programmers - it's interesting to note that no one on this thread has
seriously suggested that you should teach C/C++ to new programmers.  C++
is great if it's used in the right places, but I just can't imagine
teaching it to new programmers.

I'm convinced that it's best to  teach object orientation up front to new
programmers, especially young ones.  That said, I'll reiterate my
suggestion of Ruby as a first language.  Why?:

1) Ruby is _very_ consistently object oriented (on par with SmallTalk).
Examples:
  #even numeric literals can accept messages:
  3.times { print " Hey " } #->  Hey Hey Hey

  string = "This is my string"
  string.length #-> 17
  (NOTE: In python to get a string length you have to do:
   length(string)
   which doesn't seem very OO to me.)
2) Ruby has builtin regex facilities on par with Perl.
3) Ruby has sigils, but they are used for indicating scope, not type as in
Perl, so they tend to show up less in Ruby code than they do in Perl code
(readability).
4) Indentation is not a syntactical element as it is in some other P
language.  This can be important because a new programmer probably hasn't
used programming editors before and therefore may not be able to
differentiate between tabs and spaces which can lead to all manner of
frustration when it certainly looks as though their code is indented
correctly, but one line uses a tab and another uses spaces.


[BTW: I do know someone locally who has taught eight-year-olds to program
in Ruby.]

>
> one idiotic problem with Perl is it doesn't do function args
> like any other language.  it takes at least 3 lines of code
> to do what most other languages do in 1.  this _doesn't
> matter_.  a problem like this just means you teach someone
> the 3 lines instead of the 1, probably with an explanation
> of why it's necessary.  though too many digressions like
> this may get in the way of learning the meat of programming.

Much as I used to like Perl, I never did like the kludgy way you had to
deal with function args...  I think that's changing in Perl 6 thankfully.

Phil




From ptkwt at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 30 12:14:02 2003
From: ptkwt at aracnet.com (Phil Tomson)
Date: Thu Jan 30 12:14:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Programming languages...
In-Reply-To: <200301300953.26951.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301301156320.29637-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>


Kind of related to the thread about PHP for new programmers (Hey is
there a language called PHB for managers? :-):

In the book "The Pragmatic Programmer" by Dave Thomas and Andrew Hunt
(good book, BTW) the authors suggest that you learn a new programming
language every year because different languages help you to look at
problems differently.  Now I'm not sure about every year, but I would
suggest that perhaps every other year would be a good schedule; two years
gives you plenty of time to master a language (unless it's C++ in which
case give it about five ;-).  My language of the last two years has been
Ruby and so far it's my favorite; I suspect it will continue to be my
language of choice for many projects where it makes sense, but now I'm
looking to learn OCaml and Objective C.  OCaml because I want learn more
about functional programming and it's also compiles to very fast
executables.  Objective C because I really tend to prefer it's object
model over C++'s (Obj-C is much more dynamic than C++, more decisions are
made at runtime in Obj-C) and Obj-C is the basis for a lot of GUI
programming on MacOSX (and the cocoa framework (basically the same API as
GNUStep) is said to be a joy for creating GUIs).

Anyway, my point is don't get stuck forever in one language 'local
minima'.  As you try more languages you'll find that some are better
suited for some tasks than for others and even if you have to use C/C++,
Java or C# at work you'll find that your acquaintance with several of the
other less commercial languages will enrich your toolbox of knowledge and
actually help you when you're programming in those more commercial
languages as well.

Phil

You have to understand that if the first language is either difficult or not 
productive then the student is much more likely to lose interest and quit 
(especially young students). Show them that it's fairly easy to create and be 
productive and they will likely stick it out. Originally I suggested shell or 
Perl scripting because of availability, free documentation, ease of use and 
full of features.

> one idiotic problem with Perl is it doesn't do function args
> like any other language.  it takes at least 3 lines of code
> to do what most other languages do in 1.  this _doesn't
> matter_.  a problem like this just means you teach someone

You don't like having all of your parameters flattened into @_  :)  (I share 
that feeling).   And I beg to differ, every Perlmonger that turns to C for 
the first time appreciates the fact that Perl passes parameters badly and 
conforms to the new language with pleasure (in that respect). Now here's a

> I think good programming habits have little to do with

> precisely, and obsessive paranoia.  Perl is a little worse
> than average in supporting those, so I'm puzzled why you

Quite simply, experience tells me that learning concepts by example is much 
more powerfull than by idiology and theory. We'll have to agree to disagree 
when it comes your theories of good (code) writing habits - I'm really 
puzzled why you would think that someone with no knowlege of the language 
could write code precisely and clearly (I liken that to me speaking fluent 
Japaneese without studying that lanquage).

caused them to be eliminated in Java - some would say it was the 
implementation of pointers in C++ that promoted said pointer to be commonly 
misused.

> big deal.  Perl is ok.  PHP is ok.  if someone's going to

I can't agree with that statement more.  Every language has it's pros and 
cons, there nothing but tools. So when introducing someone to programming it 
could be said that the language needs to be one that the student finds 
facinating.

Subject: [PLUG] Important trivia question : number of TCP ports available

We have a server that's a mail secondary.  The primary went down and mail is 
flooding to the secondary.  The machine has at any given moment ~325 to 380 open
or half open TCP connections.  


[root at cmcservant net]# cat ip_conntrack  | wc -l ;  cat ip_conntrack  | grep 10.10.10.25 | grep dport=25 | wc -l
    365
     91
[root at cmcservant net]#

[root at cmcservant net]# cat ip_conntrack  | wc -l ;  cat ip_conntrack  | grep 10.10.10.25 | grep dport=25 | wc -l
    389
    107
[root at cmcservant net]#

10.10.10.25 is the internal mail server that's down.

Now, should my linux box be able to function well with this many open connections?  Is there a way to increase
the number that it can keep open while we fix the problem on the primary mail server?

Yes, the primary is Exchange, yes, we have a linux based secondary to ensure that mail can be delivered.

As far as I know your box should be able to do fine with that many connections opened (provided it's beefy enough).  I believe that there are 65,536 ports available.  The ports < 1024 being privileged ports.  If your secondary is a p100 with 32 MB RAM, then you might have problems keeping a large number of ports open, but on a PIII or so with a couple hundred megs of RAM, I think you should be fine.

From m at pdxlug.org  Thu Jan 30 16:30:23 2003
From: m at pdxlug.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Jan 30 16:30:23 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Important trivia question : number of TCP ports available
In-Reply-To: <20030130162133.A14970@patch.com>
References: <20030130162133.A14970@patch.com>
Message-ID: <58144.12.47.207.4.1043972989.squirrel@webmail.pdxlug.org>

I don't have an answer to your question, but as a suggestion to further
keep Exchange away from the public 'net, you should setup your Linux mail
server as a relay for Exchange.  So mail comes into the Linux (Postfix,
right?) server and then is forwarded onto Exchange on the inside network. 
If the Exchange box is down, then Postfix would hang on to the incoming
mail until Exchange became available again.  You could also setup webmail
(using Squirrelmail or IMP) for traveling employees on the Postfix box
which would make an IMAP connection to the Exchange server on the inside. 
This way you block the outside from ever directly touching Exchange.
~M

> ensure that mail can be delivered.

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu Jan 30 18:16:22 2003
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Thu Jan 30 18:16:22 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <200301310156.h0V1uow10511@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301300929470.25298-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Thu, 30 Jan 2003, Felix Lee wrote:

> Phil Tomson <ptkwt at aracnet.com>:
> > Well, the first language can certainly matter since it will give the
> > learner certain impressions about the practice of programming that might
> > be hard to change later.
> 
> big deal.  everyone in this thread has been talking about
> procedural programming languages, which are going to be
> obsoleted by functional programming or logic programming Any
> Day Now.

I have heard that about OO languages and structured languages and every 
other programming fad that comes along.

C is still the primary language used in Unix and the rest of the 
programming world.

> > I'm convinced that it's best to teach object orientation
> > up front to new programmers, especially young ones.
> 
> sure, whatever.  I suspect object-oriented programming is a
> passing fad, but it'll last as long as, oh, Fortran.  after
> all, you can do object-oriented programming in Fortran now.

Fortran has good points and bad points.  It is not a good language to 
teach object oriented code to the young however.  (Besides, I think you 
can get jail time for that in some juristictions.)

Object oriented methods are a tool to be used to solve a specific class of 
problems.  They are not the end-all and be-all of programming, no matter 
what the proponents of OOP claim.  For some problems, it adds a level of 
obfuscation that makes debugging next to impossible.

Best to start out teaching kids a language that requires them to be able 
to solve the problem clearly and cleanly.  They need to learn the problem 
solving skills first or else they spend the rest of their lives writing 
code that the rest of us have to fix.

Style is important. Clarity is important.  These are skills that are not 
stressed by most programming books and/or teachers.

From dcf at aracnet.com  Thu Jan 30 18:59:02 2003
From: dcf at aracnet.com (David Fleck)
Date: Thu Jan 30 18:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <200301301320.h0UDKFF05002@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
References: <200301301320.h0UDKFF05002@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>
Message-ID: <20030130184919.E17125@grond.sourballs.org>

On Thu, 30 Jan 2003, Felix Lee wrote:
> ummmm... no.  Perl encourages sloppy programming.  it's far
> too irregular and has too much magic behavior.
>
> simple example.  this:
>
>     while (my $line = <IN>) { ... }
>
> does not do the same thing as this:
>
>     sub in { return <IN>; }
>     while (my $line = in ()) { ... }
>
> and there's no warning for that.

I won't debate the suitability of perl as a teaching language; its
ability to let people write idiosyncratic and baffling code is well known
- personally I'd recommend something a little more structured.

But I think you're wrong - the two examples above do the exact same thing.
You can't stick them together in a row like this, because you've read from
an input stream in the first, and you have to close and reopen the stream
before you can read from it again.  (Not an uncommon occurrance in many
languages, I believe.)  If I stick your two examples into separate
scripts, they produce identical results; I just tried it.

Again, I'm not defending perl as a learning language, just defending its
honor in general here.

--
David Fleck
dcf at aracnet.com

From bd2u at andrew.cmu.edu  Thu Jan 30 21:27:02 2003

Date: Thu Jan 30 21:27:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Latex column headings and tables...
In-Reply-To: <mailman.1043897359.14326.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
References: <mailman.1043897359.14326.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <3E3A0909.8040006@andrew.cmu.edu>

I think the column description you want is 'p' (instead of 'l', 'r', or 
'c').  It creates the column element as a parbox of a width specified as 
an argument.  The parbox implies that the contacts will be wrapped.  I 
don't have my LaTeX referenece in front of me right now, so I can't give 
you the exact syntax.  If you want this different than the other rows, 
you can of course put in in a \multicolumn to change the format 
specification for that row.

-- 
Brian Diggs

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Jan 30 21:34:01 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Jan 30 21:34:01 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <200301301554.49425.stevea@nwtechops.com> on Thu, 30 Jan 2003 15:54:49 PST.
Message-ID: <200301310533.h0V5XIg10637@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Steven Adams <stevea at nwtechops.com>:
> You have to understand that if the first language is either difficult or not
> productive then the student is much more likely to lose interest and quit
> (especially young students).

yes, which is why PHP is fine.  generating web pages is
interesting.  Perl doesn't do anything terribly interesting
until you have a lot of Perl, unless you like doing sysadmin.

> I'm really puzzled why you would think that someone with
> no knowlege of the language could write code precisely and
> clearly (I liken that to me speaking fluent Japaneese
> without studying that lanquage).

I didn't say you could write clearly and precisely without
knowledge of a language.  knowledge of the language is a
prerequisite, and that's why Perl is less than ideal.  it's
_hard_ to know Perl.  there are too many complex
interactions between its various parts.

most computer languages are not very complicated and not
very different, it's not that hard to learn a new one.  it's
not like learning Japanese.  if I had to use an unfamiliar
language like Ruby, I'd sit down with the reference manual,
spend a day reading it, another day reading other people's
programs, and that's probably enough for me to start writing
reasonable Ruby programs.

Perl is a lot harder than that.  it takes a long time to
read its manual and learn how all its parts interact.  Perl
tricks you into thinking there's an easy learning curve,
that you can just learn a little of it at a time, but that's
not really true.
--

On Thu, 2003-01-30 at 11:42, Phil Tomson wrote:

Right away I spot of couple of errors in your understanding of Python
(and I'm just barely a novice):

> 1) Ruby is _very_ consistently object oriented (on par with SmallTalk).
> Examples:
>   #even numeric literals can accept messages:
>   3.times { print " Hey " } #->  Hey Hey Hey
> 
>   string = "This is my string"
>   string.length #-> 17
>   (NOTE: In python to get a string length you have to do:
>    length(string)
>    which doesn't seem very OO to me.)

$ python2
Python 2.2 (#1, Apr 12 2002, 15:29:57) 
[GCC 2.96 20000731 (Red Hat Linux 7.2 2.96-109)] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> "123".__len__()
3

IIRC, 'length()' is an operator in Python, not a function--the
obj.__len__() is the way Python implements operator overloading.  So it
really is OO, even if it doesn't look like it.

> 2) Ruby has builtin regex facilities on par with Perl.
> 3) Ruby has sigils, but they are used for indicating scope, not type as in
> Perl, so they tend to show up less in Ruby code than they do in Perl code
> (readability).
> 4) Indentation is not a syntactical element as it is in some other P
> language.  This can be important because a new programmer probably hasn't
> used programming editors before and therefore may not be able to
> differentiate between tabs and spaces which can lead to all manner of
> frustration when it certainly looks as though their code is indented
> correctly, but one line uses a tab and another uses spaces.

Before I learned Python, I thought that was a problem too--but have only
rarely had it be an issue.  I think the only time funny things happened
was when I got my hands one a source file with DOS linebreaks (or maybe
it was an X cut & paste gone awry).

From felix.1 at canids.net  Thu Jan 30 21:59:02 2003
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Thu Jan 30 21:59:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <20030130184919.E17125@grond.sourballs.org> on Thu, 30 Jan 2003 18:58:01 PST.
Message-ID: <200301310558.h0V5wEQ10661@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

David Fleck <dcf at aracnet.com>:
> > simple example.  this:
> >     while (my $line = <IN>) { ... }
> > does not do the same thing as this:
> >     sub in { return <IN>; }
> >     while (my $line = in ()) { ... }
> > and there's no warning for that.
> 
> But I think you're wrong - the two examples above do the exact same thing.

nope.  the first loop will stop when IN hits eof or error.
the second loop can stop before that.  discovering the place
this is explained in the perl man pages is left as an
exercise to the reader.

> If I stick your two examples into separate
> scripts, they produce identical results; I just tried it.

right.  this is sloppy programming practice.  "identical
results in one case" is not the same as "identical results
in all possible cases".  you're unlikely to find the
difference between those two loops from random testing.  the
inadequacy of testing is one reason so many programs have
weird bugs and security holes.
--

> >   3.times { print " Hey " } #->  Hey Hey Hey
> >
> >   string = "This is my string"
> >   string.length #-> 17
> >   (NOTE: In python to get a string length you have to do:
> >    length(string)
> >    which doesn't seem very OO to me.)
>
> $ python2
> Python 2.2 (#1, Apr 12 2002, 15:29:57)
> [GCC 2.96 20000731 (Red Hat Linux 7.2 2.96-109)] on linux2
> Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
> >>> "123".__len__()
> 3
>
> IIRC, 'length()' is an operator in Python, not a function--the
> obj.__len__() is the way Python implements operator overloading.  So it
> really is OO, even if it doesn't look like it.
>

OK.  Not to get too much into language wars ;-) but Ruby has _real_
operator overloading:

class Foo

  def +(other)
    #do whatever you need to do to add foo's together
  end

  def [](index)
    #do whatever you need to do to index into your foo
  end

  def []=(index,value)
    #assign some foo index a value
  end

end

....not a complete example, of course...
I find Python's __operatorname__ way of doing operator overloading
annoying.

> > 2) Ruby has builtin regex facilities on par with Perl.
> > 3) Ruby has sigils, but they are used for indicating scope, not type as in
> > Perl, so they tend to show up less in Ruby code than they do in Perl code
> > (readability).
> > 4) Indentation is not a syntactical element as it is in some other P
> > language.  This can be important because a new programmer probably hasn't
> > used programming editors before and therefore may not be able to
> > differentiate between tabs and spaces which can lead to all manner of
> > frustration when it certainly looks as though their code is indented
> > correctly, but one line uses a tab and another uses spaces.
>
> Before I learned Python, I thought that was a problem too--but have only
> rarely had it be an issue.  I think the only time funny things happened
> was when I got my hands one a source file with DOS linebreaks (or maybe
> it was an X cut & paste gone awry).
>

Yes, lots of Pythonisas say this.  For me I found it caused trouble from
the first Python program I tried to type in.  I played with Python for
about three hours and then decided it wasn't for me mostly based on
this indentation as syntax thing (but also, it seemed odd to have to
pass in self everywhere to your instance methods, at least in their
definitions, and all those __xyz__ method names)...  I think the
Python/Ruby choice is one of taste - they
both have a lot of similar features.  I also tend to  find that if you're
coming from Perl you'll probably prefer Ruby.

Phil

> On Thursday 30 January 2003 09:05 pm, Phil Tomson wrote:

> > http://rubycentral.com/book/index.html
> > ... or in dead tree version at Powell's.

> > the month.  If you want to be on the PDX.rb mailing list send me an email.
>
> Hey Phill,
> I have never heard of Ruby, could you post a quick overview?
>

The quick overview of Ruby:

It was developed by Yukihiro Matsumoto in Japan in the mid-90's.  He liked
a lot of Perl's power (regexen, string manipulation, arrays, hashes, etc)
but he wanted something much more object oriented (on par with SmallTalk).
He didn't find Python to be object oriented enough to suit his tastes so
he developed his own language: Ruby.  In developing Ruby he borrowed
a lot of ideas from Perl, Lisp and  SmallTalk.

*Ruby is a dynamically typed language (but 'type' is primarily determined
by what messages an object can respond to).
*Ruby's object model is single inheritance with mixins
  - you can mixin modules of methods into a class (thus adding both
    interface and implementation, unlike Java which only allows you to
    add interface and you add the implementation seperately)
  - you avoid the trouble with multiple inheritance but can get
    implementation and interface from multiple mixins.
*Ruby is extremely dynamic:
  - classes are always open, so you can add methods to them at runtime
(for example)
  - there really isn't much difference between runtime and compiletime
    which allows you to do things like conditional inheritance or
    conditional mixins (and lots of other cool things).
  - you can add methods to individual objects (singleton methods)

Here's a Ruby intro article I wrote for Freshmeat about a year ago:
 http://freshmeat.net/articles/view/358/

Here's a good article on Ruby in Software Development magazine:
http://www.sdmagazine.com/documents/s=7726/sdm0212d/sdm0212d.htm

Also:

http://www.ruby-lang.org  -  Ruby's home
http://www.rubycentral.com - online "Programming Ruby" book available here

...that should get you started.
Have fun.

Phil

stuff like how and when to write comments, spacing and
formatting guidelines, methods for naming variables and
functions, programming idioms to use or avoid, etc.  do a
Google search of "programming style".  there are lots of
different style guides.  consistency is more important than
quibbling over details.  the purpose is to encourage
code that's easy to read and maintain.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Fri Jan 31 00:10:02 2003
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Fri Jan 31 00:10:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Important trivia question : number of TCP ports available
In-Reply-To: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014D9E@gilligan.gijoes.com>
References: <76CAC90361FD1B4EABBCDEE0B822B844014D9E@gilligan.gijoes.com>
Message-ID: <200301310009.13708.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Each socket connection on a port requires the use of a file descriptor  
so realistically you won't be able to have all 64K ports in use at any 
one time. The maximum number of ports available on a system is going to 
be based on how large the file descriptor table is on a given system.  

Also depending on what sort of processes are being run, you also have to 
contend with the fact that many programs take up 3 file descriptors by 
default...One each for stdin, stdout, and stderr. The number of file 
descriptors in use by a given process will go up further if the process 
opens other files, sockets, or any other resources that consumes file 
descriptors.

Tony

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Fri Jan 31 07:40:02 2003
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Fri Jan 31 07:40:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Is PHP a good intro programming language? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Fri, 31 Jan 2003 07:11:15 PST."
             <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301310709270.3247-100000@serpentor.cobrala> 
Message-ID: <200301311539.h0VFdeg22745@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

I don't necessarily disagree with anything that has previously been
said.  However, if any of your young programmers have aspirations to
be a hardware designer, they might be better off learning C or even
assembly (preferably not x86).  The advantage of C is that it is relatively
easy to predict what instructions will generated by the compiler, which
makes controlling hardware a little easier.

The ideal situation would be a single
board computer with lots of interesting I/O (LEDs, switches, audio, etc.),
combined with the appropriate cross tools.  This would require a fair
amount of hand holding at the beginning, but I can't think of a better
way to really get to know hardware, short of designing and building
it yourself.

galen

From trnutt at aracnet.com  Fri Jan 31 09:09:02 2003
From: trnutt at aracnet.com (TRNutt)
Date: Fri Jan 31 09:09:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
References: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>

Tricks I've found:

For getting to the second floor, check the space around the plumbing stack
and then come down from the attic.

For putting a jack on a 2nd floor external wall where there is a window,
firebreak etc. bring in the wire elsewhere and hide the wire behind the
baseboard to where you want it.

don't run parrelel to power lines.

t

From sean at fork.com  Fri Jan 31 09:16:02 2003
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Fri Jan 31 09:16:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>
References: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <20030131171518.28404C5CF@max.seansdomain.org>

Wireless.  

Depending on what you want to do, the Acceptable Use Agreement between Cable 
and DSL varies widely.  If you want to download only than cable is right for 
you.  If you want to have more symmetrical bandwidth or servers on the 
Internet at your house than DSL, is probably what you want.

Qwest runs the lines but look at somebody else for the service.  I've used 
Earthlink over pppoe for more than a year and it's been ok.  DSL Northwest, 
Speakeasy, Pacifier are also other solutions.

Try wireless.  I installed a wireless router (DLink 614+) into my 
father-in-law's old house (ground floor) and I could surf anywhere in the 
house (upstairs/downstairs).  There are some pretty good wireless to ethernet 
adapters that would allow you to put your access point in the basement, put 
the wireless access point on the first or second floor and connect that to a 
hub.


Sean

purpose distributions), but weren't in a good position to make money
on auxilary goods and services.  This made it very difficult.

I would actually like to try doing another speciality distribution, but
this time I would Open Source it completely from day one and combine
it with a book so one could get it into book stores.  Altho one
wouldn't get rich doing this, it might get the distribution enough
attention that one could use it to sell installation and other services
from the distros web site.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Jan 31 09:21:02 2003
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Fri Jan 31 09:21:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] broadbrand advice
In-Reply-To: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>
References: <20030131085434.C6779@zaphod.axian.com>
Message-ID: <20030131171932.GB29400@dalsemi.com>

On Fri, Jan 31, 2003 at 08:54:34AM -0800, Alice Corbin wrote:
> I'm thinking about getting a broadband connection to the internet
> and am looking for advice.
> 
> I'm thinking along the lines of a hub/firewall in the basement,
> with cables running up to the first and second floors.
> 
> I'm not too thrilled with either ATT or Qwest, but they seem to be
> the only games in town.  But I'm really apprehensive about the
> wiring.  I live in a 1920's wood-frame house, with gobs of windows 
> and blown-in insulation.
> 
> Any suggestions?

It's really not hard to pull wire through walls, even with blown in
insulation.  Here's a list of materials:

----------------------------------------------------------------

1 box Cat 5 (may want to put in 5e for future 1000BaseT networking)

1 wire tape (also called a snake, but not a plumbing snake)

1 stout drill

1 drill bit large enough to accomodate the head of the snake, which
  is bigger than the Cat 5.

Several plastic remodeling/rework boxes.  These are standard plastic
electrical boxes with little tabs that turn out in order to lock
the box into place.  It's worth the cost to get the deep ones if
your walls are deep enough to accomodate them.

Networking wall jacks.  Home Depot sells some great modular ones
that you can mix with phone jacks, cable jacks, etc.

1 helper to be on the other end of the wire tape.

Tools to cut holes in walls and do patch work.

Measuring tape.

----------------------------------------------------------------

Home Depot has some great self-published how-to books on how to do
wiring when remodeling as well as techniques on how to avoid cutting
large holes to accomodate the drill.  Using channel hardware (which is
a plastic cover for wire exposed on a wall) could be a great time
saver, but keep it to unobtrusive corners if you're into decorating.

You can save a lot of work through careful planning.  For example, if
you can do your routing through interior walls, you can avoid the
insulation altogether.  I've also heard of people who route wire
through duct work, but if I remember right, that's against electrical
code unless you use a higher grade of wire (more insulation due to
heat/vibration).  Of course, you're doing it yourself so that may only
be a problem during an inspection (for example, if you decide to sell
your house someday).

You may also want to think about alternative network solutions.

1) Power-line networking.  This is expensive (last check 3 months
ago) but it's massively convenient.  You may have problems with
older wiring and fuse boxes (people who use a lot of X10 home
automation have a lot of experience with this.)  Depending
on how your house is wired into the main on the street, you
may also share your networking connection with your neighbors,
which could be good or bad :)

2) Wireless.  802.11b stuff is getting dirt cheap.  A few
months ago Frye's had 802.11b cards for $20 each after rebate,
but most people think with an 802.11b card you get what you
pay for, so do be careful.  You may end up sharing your
network with your neighbors as well.

3) Phone-line networking.  Not many people I know use it, or think
highly of it.  But it is available as an option.

Good luck!
Colin

  I'm in Verizon country, not Qwest (although a neighbor, around the corner,
works for them as an installer/repairman). Anyway, Verizon carries the ADSL
line from the outside wall of the house to Aracnet/SpiritOne in Beaverton.
The line was lit on 1 June 1999 and I am completely satisfied with the
services provided by GTE/Verizon and Aracnet/SpiritOne.

  There have been problems with the line and "modem", but not for over a
year now. I guess all the settling's done so it's nice and stable. The
service with both has been outstanding and prompt.

  Because I don't watch TV I don't have cable coming in the house. I could,
but I much prefer to stay with the TelCo to my ISP. If I was in your
situation I'd run cat 5 cable up through the walls. If you don't want to do
it all yourself I can recommend a fellow based in Gresham who's done all the
internal telephone wiring I've not been able to do myself. Your windows and
blown-in insulation won't deter a competent cable runner.

> I agree, incidentally. I mean, I think a good backing in a C or C++ is

> etc. you can actually start manipulating input, creating buttons, etc.

I find this whole 'web centric' approach a bit amusing... I mean most GUI
apps are still developed in C/C++.  Yeah a lot of web apps are developed
in Java now and apparently PHP is the web programming language de jour,
but most desktop applications are written in C/C++.

However, I wouldn't recommend teaching C/C++ to kids, but not because you
can't do anything 'terribly interesting' in those languages.... I suspect
that the GUI you typed that in was written in C or C++ ;-)

Of course. Why is that amusing, though? I don't think anyone is saying that web-apps are superior. They're just superior in certain situations. They're superior when you don't want to have to distribute an installer. They're superior when you want something relatively cross-platform. And in the case of teaching kids, they could be seen as superior because you can show them tangible exciting results without having to learn a complicated GUI toolkit. Seems reasonable to me.

>They're superior when you don't want to have to distribute an installer.

>in the case of teaching kids, they could be seen as superior because you

I guess what I found amusing was the suggestion that you couldn't do
anything 'interesting' in C/C++... Where 'interesting' was defined as
being able to create clickable buttons, menus, etc.  The implication being
that you could only do these things with web apps - or maybe it would be
better to say 'apps that run inside of a browser'.  True, the web browser
is just another platform and (for the most part) it's a uniform platform
that runs on other platforms (but I've heard the horror stories about web
apps that run fine under Mozilla, Konqueror and Galeon, but do not work
under IE).

Most of the major scripting languages allow you to develop GUI apps which
work cross-platform so they can offer the same advantages as web-apps.

BTW: Given that the browser is just another platform, you could even use
C/C++ to develop web apps given the right libraries (not that I'm
advocating that :).

BTW2: Mozilla is becoming a platform in it's own right which you can
configure using XUL (XML based, so it's not really a programming
language) - it'll be interesting to see how many apps come out
using Mozilla as the GUI.

Phil




From me at prestoncrawford.com  Fri Jan 31 12:42:01 2003

----- Original Message -----
From: Phil Tomson

To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
Subject: Re: Re: [PLUG] Is XYZ a good intro programming language?

> I guess what I found amusing was the suggestion that you couldn't do
> anything 'interesting' in C/C++... Where 'interesting' was defined as
> being able to create clickable buttons, menus, etc.  The implication being
> that you could only do these things with web apps - or maybe it would be
> better to say 'apps that run inside of a browser'.  True, the web browser
> is just another platform and (for the most part) it's a uniform platform
> that runs on other platforms (but I've heard the horror stories about web
> apps that run fine under Mozilla, Konqueror and Galeon, but do not work
> under IE).
> 
> Most of the major scripting languages allow you to develop GUI apps which
> work cross-platform so they can offer the same advantages as web-apps.

I don't think the contention was that nothing interesting could be done with C/C++. The contention was that it would be quicker and easier to get to the point of doing interesting GUI things with a web application. This is true. That doesn't mean PHP is better or more interesting than C/C++, it just means that you can put together a web app in a matter of minutes, whereas it's a little more difficult to do GUI work (especially for kids) using standard compiled languages.
 
> BTW2: Mozilla is becoming a platform in it's own right which you can
> configure using XUL (XML based, so it's not really a programming
> language) - it'll be interesting to see how many apps come out
> using Mozilla as the GUI.

Interesting, but for learning purposes probably not terribly practical. I think the big advantage of PHP is that it has a C-Like syntax. So PHP as a first language would be awesome, not only because you get to see results immediately, but you get to learn syntax that will translate roughly to many other languages such as JavaScript, C, C++, Java, etc. (please note that by syntax I mean how it treats whitespace, math, ++, semi-colons, superficial things that a kid learning a language would be able to easily translate to another language).

The only downfall I can see, personally, is that it's not typed. Maybe non-typed languages are the wave of the future, but I somehow doubt it.

Preston




From mark at ecl.us  Fri Jan 31 13:07:02 2003
From: mark at ecl.us (Mark Roberts)
Date: Fri Jan 31 13:07:02 2003

A lot of focus on the best language but what about debugging.  I nice
IDE goes a long way towards making a language usable for learning.  Ease
of debugging can make or break ones willingness to learn a language.

I've been having trouble finding a good open source debugger for PHP. 
What does everyone do to debug PHP code, put in lots of print type
statements?

As for perl I havn't seen much in the way of IDE's either.

Being able to set breakpoints, single step and check variables
interactively can be the quickest way to learn what your code is doing. 
Nothing like the ease of learning in an integrated edit, compile, go
environment.

I'd be interested to see this discussion focus more on debuggers and
development environment, and less on the languages, not that the
language itself is not important.

Mark

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0301311118450.18250-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>

On Friday 31 January 2003 11:33 am, Phil Tomson wrote:

> I guess what I found amusing was the suggestion that you couldn't do
> anything 'interesting' in C/C++... Where 'interesting' was defined as
> being able to create clickable buttons, menus, etc.  The implication being
> that you could only do these things with web apps - or maybe it would be
> better to say 'apps that run inside of a browser'.  True, the web browser
> is just another platform and (for the most part) it's a uniform platform
> that runs on other platforms (but I've heard the horror stories about web
> apps that run fine under Mozilla, Konqueror and Galeon, but do not work
> under IE).
>
> Most of the major scripting languages allow you to develop GUI apps which
> work cross-platform so they can offer the same advantages as web-apps.
>
> BTW: Given that the browser is just another platform, you could even use
> C/C++ to develop web apps given the right libraries (not that I'm
> advocating that :).
>
> BTW2: Mozilla is becoming a platform in it's own right which you can
> configure using XUL (XML based, so it's not really a programming
> language) - it'll be interesting to see how many apps come out
> using Mozilla as the GUI.
>
> Phil

Wow, the original thread has really gone astray. The intent was to look at 
what a good introductory language to teach a 10 year old would be. That's why 
you haven't heard anything about the C family, teaching concepts like 
malloc(), polymorphism, inheiritance, operator overloading, C style pointers 
and the likes is probably not appropriate for most 10 yo's (they work for me 
though, I love that stuff). I don't think anyone that's been contributing 
intended to imply that nothing interesting could be done in C, after all - 
without C we would not have *nix workstations and servers: How interesting 
would that be? The discussion was on what would get the interest of a beginer 
and provide a good introductory path to programming, and the web/script stuff 
certainly fits that bill (not to say that C would be out in all cases but a 
10 year old that could hook into C and stick with it's probably rare).



From fixin at peak.org  Fri Jan 31 15:45:02 2003
From: fixin at peak.org (Eric House)
Date: Fri Jan 31 15:45:02 2003
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Is PHP a good intro programming language?
In-Reply-To: <20030131230602.19663.85643.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>; from plug-request@lists.pdxlinux.org on Fri, Jan 31, 2003 at 03:06:02PM -0800
References: <20030131230602.19663.85643.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20030131154459.F16195@tpol.peak.org>

> A lot of focus on the best language but what about debugging.  I nice
> IDE goes a long way towards making a language usable for learning.  Ease
> of debugging can make or break ones willingness to learn a language.
> 
> I've been having trouble finding a good open source debugger for PHP. 
> What does everyone do to debug PHP code, put in lots of print type
> statements?
> 
> As for perl I havn't seen much in the way of IDE's either.
> 
> Being able to set breakpoints, single step and check variables
> interactively can be the quickest way to learn what your code is doing. 
> Nothing like the ease of learning in an integrated edit, compile, go
> environment.

This is an excellent point.  I remember that my intuitive
understanding of what my programs were doing -- and my confidence that
the computer was doing what I told it to -- went up quite a bit when I
started using source-level debugging.

So: what are good OpenSource source-level debuggers?  I've used gdb in
emacs for years, but only happily with C.  With perl and with java it
sometimes works, sometimes doesn't.  And I'm not sure I want to throw
the complexity of emacs into a 10-year-old's life.  Are there "free"
VC++ act-alikes available for Linux for any of the languages we're
discussing?

Fascinating discussion, BTW.  Thanks for all the ideas!

--Eric

On Fri, 2003-01-31 at 09:34, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   ... and a tool to put the RJ-45 plugs on the ends of the cable. I have one
> of these. Handy little thing even though it's not much used.

If you're going to use keystones, the tool should come with the
keystones, if you get the right ones.... in which case it is just a
dinky piece of plastic to push the wires down ... or let your thumb-nail
grow for two weeks and you're good to go.  Alternatively, I also have
one of 'dem little thingies.

If you're going to have cable running out of a hole in your wall, then
you want a crimper, but I wouldn't suggest doing that... outlets look *a
lot* nicer.  The RJ-45 outlets in this house (about 15 of them) look
like regular phone jacks, just a little bigger.

Rob

I must have had just shoddy luck with wireless or something.  A friend
and I set up a wireless network for a not-to-be-named small business
near Salem (they were *crap* to work for and had some *moron-run*
software company selling them really overpriced and buggy software)...
we could barely get range through a half inch of plywood.

Sight to sight and we were good to go - but introduce any walls (these
were not insulated and most were cheapo wood - we're talking a renovated
barn, more or less) and the signal went to hell in a handbasket.

In a related incident, the same guy needed to link two networks together
over 100 feet of pavement (think accross the parking lot) so got two
wireless access points to act as a bridge.  They dropped all their
packets running through one pane of glass and 100' of air until $100 in
cable and an antenna was purchased....

Is this just a wierd experience or is such stuff common?  I have a
friend interested in wireless networking ... he has a newer house (7
years old) and would be running it through a floor to his wife's
computer in the room roughly right under him.  Do you guys think 802.11b
will be able to cut through a floor?

Rob

AthlonRob said:

> we could barely get range through a half inch of
> plywood.

My experience has been quite favorable. I regularly use my wireless
through 2 to 4 walls (2x4s and drywall) at home. I've _never_ had a
reception problem anywhere in/around my house, though I've probably
never bothered to go more than 50 ft from the access point. I've got
an SMC access point/NAT box, an Orinoco PCMCIA card, and a mini-PCI
Orinoco in my laptop.

> In a related incident, the same guy needed to link two networks
> together over 100 feet of pavement (think accross the parking lot)
> so got two wireless access points to act as a bridge.  They dropped
> all their packets running through one pane of glass and 100' of air
> until $100 in cable and an antenna was purchased....

I've also used wireless kit to bridge over a distance; maybe a mile or
so. This was using more Orinoco gear:
http://www.orinocowireless.com/products/all/orinoco/outdoor/PtoP/index.html

It was spendy (we didn't have to pay for it in this instance), but
worked like a charm. We did have line of sight and were less than a
quarter of it's rated distance, FWIW.</Orinoco Ad>

I'd love to see semi-directional anntenne for access points. Mine is
on the far side of the house, wasting db out the window towards the
neighbors. I guess I should just tinfoil that side of the house. And
make a hat while I'm at it.
